column43: "Vietnam experiences the highest unemployment for a decade due to COVID-19. Many care leavers lost their jobs and are unable to pay their bills. Although the government has announced support packages to benefit people affected by the pandemic, some care leavers have trouble accessing it." Phong Le is a 28-year old care leaver of SOS Children’s Villages Vietnam and an advocate for sustainable development. Today he spoke at the virtual forum on COVID-19 and alternative care in the South East Asia region. https://www.sosphilippines.org/blog/article/142/policy_brief__covid_19_response_towards_the_alternative_care_of_children_in_southeast_asia

column43: “We all heard the horrible news about the devastating explosion in Beirut yesterday evening that hit the country in the midst of an economic and health crisis. We are relieved to hear from our colleagues at SOS Children´s Villages Lebanon that only the building of the National Office in Beirut was partially damaged, but there were no casualties. Children as well as co-workers in Lebanon are fine and safe. There is no damage at the SOS Children´s Villages as they are not located in Beirut. Our thoughts, hopes and best wishes are with our colleagues and the people of Lebanon. We are very concerned about the loss of lives and the many people who were injured and lost their homes in this tragedy. SOS Children’s Villages Lebanon and the International Office are currently looking into how SOS Children’s Villages can best support.” - Tom Malvet, International Director for the Middle East Region, CEE/CIS SOS Children’s Villages - (Photo: A programme of SOS Children's Villages Lebanon).

column43: "We saw the civil war in Beirut. But an explosion like this: Never!" says Afifa Arsanios Dirani, Honorary President of SOS Children's Villages in Lebanon, as she looks through the broken windows of the SOS office in Beirut. "Even before the corona crisis and the explosion in the capital, families and children in Lebanon were living on the brink: the collapse of the economy, poor medical care and food security, with many families threatened with poverty and hunger. The explosion escalates an already dramatic situation. The people of Beirut are deeply shaken. The situation is fragile: hyperinflation, poverty, protests, corona lockdown - now the explosion. What's next?" "Lebanon is badly hit, so we will focus on what we do best - protecting families and children. Our biggest concern is for the families and children who live close to the port and in urban areas." column43: “I am lost, I don’t know what my children and I will do,” says Rula*, a mother of three who lives east of the Port of Beirut. On the afternoon of Tuesday, 4 August, she was at home with her children when the two violent explosions hit the Lebanese capital. “We ran out of our home with nothing but our blood-stained clothes,” Rula says. “I was wounded, my daughter’s hand was broken, and my son was also hurt and he is still in pain. But I am thankful that we survived.” Rula spent the first night after the explosion at her brother’s house as the blast damaged three-quarters of her home. With support from volunteers and SOS Children’s Villages Lebanon, Rula and her children moved the next day to a temporary house where they can stay until it is safe for them to return home. The SOS team is contacting service providers to repair her house. Since the explosion, Carla Choueifaty, the SOS family strengthening coordinator in Beirut, has been in contact with families such as Rula’s to check on their needs. “The blast is catastrophic, too many people dead, wounded and disappeared. Everyone in Lebanon is affected in some way,” Carla says. “If the families we work with are good physically, this does not mean that they are good. Their relatives, friends and neighbors were hurt. The shock and the psychological effects on children and adults are significant. They all need psychological support,” she says. Learn how SOS Children's Villages is responding to the crisis in Lebanon. https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/humanitarian-appeal-for-children-in-lebanon *The name of the mother was changed to protect her privacy

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: SOS Children's Villages is deeply concerned about the safety and wellbeing of all children and young people in Belarus. All children and young people living in the SOS Children's Villages programmes in Belarus are safe at the moment. For security reasons, the young people living in the youth home in Minsk have been temporarily relocated. In all four SOS Children's Villages in Belarus, we offer free psychological counseling over the phone and in-person to children and parents who have witnessed violence and abuse. The physical and psychological well-being of children has always been the focus of the work of SOS Children's Villages in Belarus, which started as a result of the Chernobyl disaster in 1986. Today, SOS Children's Villages Belarus cares for 1,000 children in need of parental care and in youth programmes, and supports 2,000 children from at-risk families.Learn more about our work in Belarus: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/where-we-help/europe/belarus

column43: We are there for children and families in emergencies & crises. On today’s World Humanitarian Day, we recognize the courage and tireless efforts of our colleagues and partners who provide care and safety to children and help keep families together in difficult circumstances. #WHD2020 #WorldHumanitarianDay
column46: WORLD HUMANITARIAN DAY 2020 In 2019, sos Children's Villages responded to emergencies in over 20 countries and territories. Our focus is always on caring for children, protecting their rights and keeping families together. SOS NEPAL In an emergency, emergency, we provide: Interim care for unaccompanied and separated children, making every effort to reunite them with family members 刚 Child-friendly spaces where children are supported and protected Mental health and psychosocial support for children and their caregivers Education and direct services to prevent family separation and increase resilience sOS CHIL DREN'S VILLAGES INTERNATIONAL LET CHILDREE CHILDREN www.sos-childrensvillages.org

column43: "After 33 years of helping others, I am now famous in the community for being a person who lends a hand to those who need it, which is nice but at the same time difficult when I feel unable to solve all the problems. "We have many success stories where we could help children and families change their lives; this makes me feel that all these years of work had positive results. Many families were about to collapse but we could intervene to keep them together," says Ihsan Redwan, a humanitarian worker in Palestine. column43: The news of just one week: - Dozens of children and families have drowned in the Mediterranean. - Children and families are reportedly detained in hotels in the US, an unregulated system left to the management of a private security company and eventually expelled without the necessary safeguards. - The death rate of children in the Al-Hol camp in Syria has tripled since the beginning of the year. This list of rights violations could be continued. The safety and rights of children and young people should never be put at risk just because of their origin, status or circumstances. We call for every child’s equal right to care and protection. (Photo © Alea Horst: Child in a programme of SOS Children’s Villages Greece in a refugee camp in Lesvos). #children #refugees #migration #childrensrights

column43: “It is often a little difficult to know what is wrong with them, because most children here suffer from the loss of a mother or a father, or both. That is why they often come to me, even though they might not always need it. Just a little headache is enough for them to come to me, because they want to feel good," says Kamala from Nepal. ⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣ “There is a huge misunderstanding about mental health in our society. I want to reach out those people who are having problems and tell them mental health is as important as our physical health.” ⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣ 𝘒𝘢𝘮𝘢𝘭𝘢 𝘪𝘴 𝘢 𝘯𝘶𝘳𝘴𝘦 𝘢𝘵 𝘚𝘖𝘚 𝘊𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯'𝘴 𝘝𝘪𝘭𝘭𝘢𝘨𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘚𝘢𝘯𝘰𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘮𝘪, 𝘕𝘦𝘱𝘢𝘭 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘢𝘬𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘴𝘶𝘳𝘦 𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦𝘨𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘳𝘴 𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘴𝘢𝘧𝘦 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘩𝘦𝘢𝘭𝘵𝘩𝘺 𝘦𝘴𝘱𝘦𝘤𝘪𝘢𝘭𝘭𝘺 𝘥𝘶𝘳𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘱𝘢𝘯𝘥𝘦𝘮𝘪𝘤. column43: At a time of year when children usually prepare to go back to school, the COVID-19 pandemic has created a new educational reality where many children will learn online. ⁣ ⁣ "Digital learning, no matter its intrinsic inadequacies or advantages, is the method of instruction, which, for the near future, will be taking a prominent role in education," says Adelise Baha, advocacy advisor for SOS Children's Villages for West, North and Central Africa.⁣⁣ ⁣ Read the full article 👉 https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/digital-divide-puts-millions-of-students-at-risk ⁣ ⁣ #InternationalLiteracyDay #BackToSchool
column46: sos CHILDREN'S VILLAGES Many children are not able to go back to school due to the pandemic. All children need tools for remote learning and ccess to education materials to continue their studies

column43: “It was a headache for me that children had to find new ways of learning after COVID-19 kept us from going to school. My mother could not afford to buy a television or radio for school broadcasts; she was already struggling to feed my little brother and I. Her exact words when I discussed this with her were: ‘education would have to wait’.⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣ "One month after we had been out of school, the SOS team came and supported us with a solar powered radio so I could listen to school broadcasts.⁣⁣⁣ ⁣ “We do not have a table in our house, so during lessons I place the radio next to me. I write quickly to capture what the teacher says. I study hard to achieve my dreams. That is the only way I will manage to build my mother a better house," says Tigist.⁣⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ ⁣𝘛𝘪𝘨𝘪𝘴𝘵* 𝘭𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘌𝘵𝘩𝘪𝘰𝘱𝘪𝘢 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘩𝘦𝘳 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘺 𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘦𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘴 𝘴𝘶𝘱𝘱𝘰𝘳𝘵 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘺 𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘨𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘨𝘳𝘢𝘮𝘮𝘦. column43: "The fire in the Moria refugee camp is yet another result of unacceptable treatment of children and families desperately seeking protection and a better life. It is an appalling consequence of the European Union’s refusal to share responsibility for arriving migrants and refugees. We cannot rebuild the same system of inhumane conditions from the ashes of Moria. All those affected by the fire need immediate access to shelter, healthcare, food, care and psychosocial aid. This fire is a wake-up call for an overdue response that would reflect Europe’s commitments to human rights, to international protection, to solidarity, and to children’s rights. The EU must walk the talk, and put its commitments into practice." - Steffen Braasch, CEO of SOS Children’s Villages International. #Moria #MoriaCamp

column43: We are excited to announce the #ArenaOfChange partnership between SOS-Kinderdörfer weltweit and FC Bayern München! The Arena of Change programme focuses on each child's well-being to develop courage and competence through creative arts, sports and science. Partnering with FC Bayern can help each child discover their talents and build resilience as they learn to play football together. ⚽🏆⁣ In the photo, Karl-Heinz Rummenigge, Chairman of Executive Board of Bayern Munich, and Petra Horn, Executive Board member of SOS-Kinderdörfer weltweit, sign the partnership agreement for “Arena of Change” ⁣ Read about the Arena of Change programme and the partnership with #FCBayern 👉 https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/partnership-with-fc-bayern-munich

column43: SOS Children’s Villages invites children and young people around the world to share photos of their new reality during the #COVID19 pandemic. ⁣ ⁣ The past months have changed everyone’s lives. Recently, SOS Children’s Villages in the Latin America and Caribbean region organized a photography competition for the children and young people they support, called “Your reality from inside your home in time of COVID-19”. ⁣ ⁣ Wilker, from SOS Children's Villages in La Canada, Venezuela and the winner of the photography contest, shares his thoughts and feelings on how the pandemic has affected him through his photographs. ⁣ ⁣ “𝘈𝘳𝘵 𝘪𝘴 𝘮𝘺 𝘧𝘰𝘳𝘮 𝘰𝘧 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘴𝘪𝘰𝘯, 𝘵𝘩𝘳𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩 𝘪𝘵 𝘐 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘴 𝘮𝘺 𝘦𝘮𝘰𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘧𝘦𝘦𝘭𝘪𝘯𝘨𝘴, 𝘶𝘴𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘮𝘺 𝘤𝘳𝘦𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘷𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘦𝘹𝘱𝘳𝘦𝘴𝘴𝘪𝘰𝘯, 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘴𝘢𝘮𝘦 𝘸𝘢𝘺, 𝘐 𝘤𝘢𝘯 𝘪𝘮𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘮𝘺𝘴𝘦𝘭𝘧 𝘢𝘴 𝘢𝘯 𝘢𝘳𝘵𝘪𝘴𝘵,” 𝘴𝘢𝘺𝘴 𝘞𝘪𝘭𝘬𝘦𝘳. ⁣⁣ Over the next few weeks, SOS Children’s Villages will share submissions from children and young people in the region who participated in the photography contest. ⁣⁣ You can join our virtual photo exhibition by posting photos on Facebook, Instagram, or Twitter of your new reality during the #COVID19 pandemic. ⁣ Share your thoughts, tag us on your photos SOS Children's Villages International and use #SOSExhibit. ⁣ Aldeas Infantiles SOS Venezuela

column43: "Living as a refugee can be very frustrating and stressful since you are never sure about your life and your future since other people are deciding for you. ⁣⁣ ⁣ "If you had asked me a year ago, I would have never thought that I would ever be able to study again. It has been a really hard journey since I tried to study here. I have faced many challenges and I am making myself ready for the ones that I will face.⁣⁣ ⁣ "Here in Greece I desire to continue and finish what I have started. By being in school in this situation and seeing other kids, I start to feel a little normal again which helps me forget about my life in the camp or what I have been through. "⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣ 𝘒𝘰𝘶𝘳𝘰𝘴𝘩, 𝟷𝟽, 𝘢𝘳𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘥 𝘸𝘪𝘵𝘩 𝘩𝘪𝘴 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘺 𝘰𝘯 𝘓𝘦𝘴𝘷𝘰𝘴 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 𝘐𝘳𝘢𝘯 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘪𝘴 𝘦𝘯𝘳𝘰𝘭𝘭𝘦𝘥 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘚𝘖𝘚 𝘊𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯'𝘴 𝘝𝘪𝘭𝘭𝘢𝘨𝘦𝘴 𝘦𝘥𝘶𝘤𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘨𝘳𝘢𝘮𝘮𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘒𝘢𝘳𝘢𝘛𝘦𝘱𝘦. column43: Oba* and his two younger brothers lived with a relative in a brothel in Lagos, Nigeria. It was a terrifying place for a child and Oba says he saw a lot that is hard to forget. ⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ Now 20 years old, Oba is studying mechanical engineering at a technical school. Oba and his brothers still attend therapy sessions occasionally, to address the lingering effects of their past.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣⁣ Read Oba’s full story 👉 https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/nigeria⁣ ⁣⁣ #WorldMentalHealth #MentalHealth ⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ *𝘕𝘢𝘮𝘦𝘴 𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘥 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘢𝘤𝘺
column46: SOSCHILDREN'S VILLAGES Therapy helped me identify the burning emotions from my childhood Dealing with my past has helped me change my mind about myself and about life. " Oba, 20, from Nigeria

column43: 📣 📣 Calling innovators who want to change the future of fundraising in the private sector! ⁣ ⁣ The world is experiencing the changing realities and the fundraising sector has to adapt its attitude to the “new normal”. Share your ideas and concepts through the new 𝐎𝐩𝐞𝐧 𝐈𝐧𝐧𝐨𝐯𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐂𝐡𝐚𝐥𝐥𝐞𝐧𝐠𝐞 𝐟𝐨𝐫 𝐅𝐮𝐧𝐝𝐫𝐚𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐧𝐠. It can include a new business model, innovative ways to engage with existing or new donors, ideas about how NGOs can adapt to the new realities. Who can participate? NGOs, start-ups, companies, agencies, academic institutions, fundraising practitioners, and individuals. ⁣ ⁣ Not only the best ideas will be pitched for investment and implemented by numerous organizations, they will be incorporated into a digital Fundraising Innovation Playbook and seen by a vast audience. ⁣ 🎨 Roll up your sleeves and start creating! ⁣ ⁣ 𝐃𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐞: 𝟖 𝐍𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫, 𝟐𝟎𝟐𝟎 ⁣ More info 👉 www.reimaginingfundraising.org:=:http://www.reimaginingfundraising.org ⁣ ⁣ ⁣ #reimaginingfundraising

column43: “On paper, the government says that you don’t have to leave care until you are 21 if the child needs it, but in real life everyone has to leave by age 18 or when they are finished with their education. There are so many children who are not ready to live alone at the age of 18. We want to change this. “I think this is abrupt end. All of a sudden you are alone and have to get your life together. I know how important it can be when you have the right help and the right people behind you. I know what it is to live alone, stand alone, and do everything alone, I want to help other children have it better… to have a community where all the care leavers can join. Having a community and having a network is very important. “Don’t give up. I think it is strange to say ‘I need help’ and to look for help. But there is always a way. Don’t be afraid to ask for help.” 𝘙𝘦𝘣𝘦𝘤𝘤𝘢 𝘣𝘦𝘭𝘰𝘯𝘨𝘴 𝘵𝘰 Care Leaver Österreich , 𝘢𝘯 𝘢𝘴𝘴𝘰𝘤𝘪𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯 𝘢𝘥𝘷𝘰𝘤𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘪𝘮𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘢𝘭𝘵𝘦𝘳𝘯𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘷𝘦 𝘤𝘶𝘳𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘵 𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘴𝘺𝘴𝘵𝘦𝘮 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘩𝘦𝘭𝘱 𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘴𝘦 𝘢𝘧𝘵𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘺 𝘭𝘦𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦. column43: "We eat in the late afternoon. It's our only meal of the day. We can't afford to eat more often. I hear Elvira's tummy grumble, but she tells me she's not hungry,” says Sanela, Elvira*'s mom. With food packages she received from SOS Children’s Villages, Sanela stretches out the food to last longer, but it’s not enough for her family to have more than one meal a day. “Still, it keeps us alive,” she says. Fighting poverty, strengthening families who face challenges, and investing in programmes supporting them has to be a priority. This is the only way to prevent negative outcomes of the pandemic, including that families become destitute and parents cannot care for their children. Click to read Elvira and her family's full story👉https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/hungry-and-forgotten-in-the-time-of-covid-19 #EndPoverty #COVID19 #SDGs #IDEP2020 #GlobalGoals *𝘕𝘢𝘮𝘦𝘴 𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘥 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘢𝘤𝘺

column43: SOS Children's Villages in Ukraine runs two multisensory stimulation rooms as part of the family strengthening programme. In Luhansk and Donetsk, the effects of armed conflict, socio-economic and health crisis has led to psychological problems for parents that affect their competencies to care for their children. Multi-sensory rooms can help improve children's cognitive skills, emotional reactions and leads to better socialisation. For parents, the rooms improve parental skills to better understand their children and create a healthy environment for the child to grow. What does a multi-sensory room look like? The rooms have items that require children to engage with more than one sense and help create feelings of comfort. A ball-pit, transforming armchair, gym mat, comforting ottoman, balancing chair, hug bags and illuminated sandbox are some items inside a multi-sensory room. #Ukraine #children #learning #familystrengthening #multisensory

column43: “Don’t worry about the beauty of your face. It doesn’t matter how you look. Your mother, brothers, and sisters will always love you. For this, you need to help and be kind to others," says Raj* from Nepal. ⁣ ⁣ Raj suffered burns to 80% of his face and body in a house fire that took his mother’s life and left his father severely injured. ⁣ ⁣ “When he joined the SOS family, Raj* was traumatized,” says Pooza Shrestha, a counselor in SOS Children's Villages in Jorpati. “He could be reserved and isolated.” ⁣ ⁣ In the journey of dealing with his trauma and appearance anxiety through counseling and therapy, Raj formed a different attitude about himself and tells others not to feel worry about their appearance. He now lives with his SOS mother and siblings until his father is able to care for him again.⁣ Read Raj's full story here: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/boy-heals-from-visible-and-invisible-scars ⁣ 𝘚𝘖𝘚 𝘊𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯’𝘴 𝘝𝘪𝘭𝘭𝘢𝘨𝘦 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘪𝘥𝘦𝘴 𝘲𝘶𝘢𝘭𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘨 𝘱𝘦𝘰𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘪𝘯𝘤𝘭𝘶𝘥𝘦𝘴 𝘴𝘶𝘱𝘱𝘰𝘳𝘵𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘢𝘭 𝘸𝘦𝘭𝘭-𝘣𝘦𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘰𝘧 𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘶𝘨𝘩 𝘱𝘴𝘺𝘤𝘩𝘰𝘭𝘰𝘨𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘭 𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘢 𝘴𝘢𝘧𝘦 𝘦𝘯𝘷𝘪𝘳𝘰𝘯𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘵. ⁣ ⁣ *𝘕𝘢𝘮𝘦𝘴 𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘥 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘢𝘤𝘺 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘵𝘦𝘤𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯

column43: “When we turn 18, we are alone. We do not have anyone to advise or support us. When we leave the orphanage or foster care, we do not know how to manage every day affairs." - Nahla from Care Leavers' Network, Egypt. Leading up to the International Care Leavers' Convention, SOS Children's Villages hosted a webinar focused on the need to create peer-support networks for care leavers and the role of civil society organisation in assisting them. column43: One year on from the adoption of the UN Resolution on the Rights of the Child focusing, for the first time ever, on children without parental care, a lot of the commitments have not become a reality for children. With increasing numbers of children pushed into vulnerable situations, there is no time to wait. The expertise is there. We need to come together in a multi-stakeholder partnership to make this work. Read the full opinion piece: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/un-resolution-one-year-on #childrensday2020 #WorldChildrensDay #ChildRights

column43: "Why are others, not leading my life, making decisions about my life? We are left alone in my place(s), with our house of thoughts. Some get lost. No one to share our thoughts with us. We are left alone. "We are talking success stories, those here, we are all success stories in a way. What about those who have lost their way in this journey? We need to hear and bring them into these discussions.’’ - Care Leaver Yesterday the first International Care leavers convention kicked off virtually. Over 750 participants from over 80 countries were in attendance, including care leavers, researchers, academics, policy makers and other partner organisations. SOS Children's Villages is proud to partner with Udayan Care, Stichting Kinderperspectief and Stiftung Universität Hildesheim to empower care leavers to speak up, bring their concerns into discussions, and enable them to partake in decisions that affect their lives. column43: “The adults around me always encouraged me to take my own decisions in my everyday life. They always listen to me before making any decisions about me and my life,” says 15-year-old Pratikshya. Pratikshya became involved with the Child Club at the SOS Hermann Gmeiner School in Gandaki, Nepal since she was in grade 6. This opened opportunities for Pratikshya to participate in conferences for child activists around Gandaki province and speak up for child rights and welfare. “Child participation can be improved by enhancing children and young people’s skills. Focusing on the development of self-confidence, speaking and leadership skills is most important for children and youth when growing up. All children should be able to participate equally. A child friendly environment has to be created for that.” #YouthParticipation *𝘗𝘦𝘳𝘴𝘰𝘯 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘱𝘩𝘰𝘵𝘰 𝘪𝘴 𝘯𝘰𝘵 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘢𝘶𝘵𝘩𝘰𝘳

column43: “A gang leader wanted to marry me. After I refused several times, the threats began. I was afraid for my family and myself, so the only option I had was to flee home and my sister joined me," says Jimena. ⁣⁣ ⁣ “I feel free here [at SOS Children's Village in Comitan], we are not locked up and we can go outside,” says Fernanda. “After going through so much, plus the pandemic, I feel safer because we have a place to stay, we are cared for and advised on our future.”⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ Because of the violent threats in Honduras, Jimena (16) and her sister Fernanda (17) fled to Mexico. After arriving at SOS Children's Village in Comitán, the sisters are learning English and how to read and write. While Jimena loves to cook for her SOS Family and dreams to be a chef, Fernanda dreams of becoming a policewoman to help others.⁣⁣ ⁣⁣ 𝘚𝘪𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝟸𝟶𝟷𝟾, 𝘚𝘖𝘚 𝘊𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘳𝘦𝘯’𝘴 𝘝𝘪𝘭𝘭𝘢𝘨𝘦𝘴 𝘔𝘦𝘹𝘪𝘤𝘰 𝘩𝘢𝘴 𝘴𝘶𝘱𝘱𝘰𝘳𝘵𝘦𝘥 𝟼𝟶 𝘶𝘯𝘢𝘤𝘤𝘰𝘮𝘱𝘢𝘯𝘪𝘦𝘥 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘵𝘩 𝘵𝘩𝘢𝘵 𝘦𝘴𝘤𝘢𝘱𝘦𝘥 𝘷𝘪𝘰𝘭𝘦𝘯𝘤𝘦 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘥𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘳 𝘪𝘯 𝘊𝘦𝘯𝘵𝘳𝘢𝘭 𝘈𝘮𝘦𝘳𝘪𝘤𝘢, 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘷𝘪𝘥𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘤𝘢𝘳𝘦, 𝘨𝘶𝘪𝘥𝘢𝘯𝘤𝘦, 𝘤𝘢𝘱𝘢𝘤𝘪𝘵𝘺 𝘣𝘶𝘪𝘭𝘥𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘴𝘶𝘱𝘱𝘰𝘳𝘵 𝘧𝘰𝘳 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘪𝘳 𝘢𝘴𝘺𝘭𝘶𝘮 𝘢𝘱𝘱𝘭𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘤𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘵𝘳𝘺. Learn more about Fernanda and Jimena's journey. 👉https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/brave-sisters-escape-violence

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: "Schools were shut down; we could not meet or play with our friends. We had to stay indoors for our own safety. The biggest challenge we, as students faced, was to move to distance learning."⁣ ⁣ "Not everyone has a smartphone, tablet or a computer. It is mostly the poorer students who are missing out. If a student manages to get the device, buying data may be a challenge or they may not have enough support at home to complete your lessons as parents and/or caregivers may not know how to use the technology. ⁣ ⁣ "Responsible and inclusive education is one of the keys to support children’s learning during COVID-19 pandemic. This can only be achieved when parents, teachers, and children can collaborate to create a good learning system. After all, children are the assets of the nation and the future is in their hands." ⁣ 𝘈𝘥𝘪 𝘚𝘰𝘶𝘮𝘦𝘯𝘢, 𝟷𝟽, 𝘪𝘴 𝘢 𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥 𝘳𝘪𝘨𝘩𝘵𝘴 𝘢𝘥𝘷𝘰𝘤𝘢𝘵𝘦 𝘧𝘳𝘰𝘮 SOS Children's Villages Indonesia. column43: “Other single mothers like me turn to prostitution to provide for their children. I didn’t want to go down that path," says Assanatou a single mother of three in #Cameroon. In Cameroon, 39% of the population lives below the poverty line, a rate that rises to 51.1% for women alone, according to UN figures. Like Assanatou, nearly 80% are underemployed, and only 1.6% own a property title in their name. Assanatou joined the SOS Children’s Villages Family Strengthening programme in 2016 and has come a long way since then. She set up a boutique in front of her house and also became the president of a nine-member strong village loans and savings association called “innovation” and recently convinced three members to invest in a chicken farm. “I learned a lot through the trainings I received from SOS and was particularly interested in the ones on children’s rights," says Assanatou. "In my community people look at me in a different way today. Now, I feel like I can make a difference." Read Assanatou's full story here: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/struggling-but-enduring-a-story-of-single-parent 📸 Moritz Elnrieder, Jean-Pierre Kepseu & Sebastien Taylor

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: "My childhood was in war. It wasn't a nice childhood to remember. In 1995, I was 15 when my father and I fled through the woods. At 15, a child still, you don't know what's a gun, or what it means – a dead person, without an arm, without a leg, without a head. I lived through all of that and saw all of it," says Esnaf, a survivor of the Bosnian War and the Srebrenica massacre. Today marks the 25th anniversary of the official signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement, which brought an end to nearly four years of conflict in former Yugoslavia. Between 1992 and 1995, around 100,000 people were killed and over 2.2 million people were displaced, making the Bosnian conflict the most devastating conflict in Europe since the end of World War II. SOS Children's Villages supports Esnaf's family through the Family Strengthening programme in Srebrenica. Read more 👉 https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/remembering-childhood-during-the-bosnia-war #Dayton25

column43: The International Car Leavers' Convention (CLC), held from November 23-25, 2020, had given care leavers around the world a platform to speak to share their experiences and bring about change. 🙌 Joined by policymakers and other NGOs, care leavers discussed the support they needed to successfully transition into leading an independent live. This includes increasing the age of living care, being included in all decision-making processes affecting their lives, and building an international network care leavers and organising the next CLC in 2022. 👉 Read more about the three-day virtual event, supported by SOS Children's Villages, Udayan Care, Kinder Perspectief, and Stiftung Universität Hildesheim: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/care-leavers-speak-up-at-the-iclc Voices Of Care Leavers Care Leaver Österreich Stichting Kinderperspectief
column46: sos CHILDREN'S VILLAGES an Who knows about care leavers? It is not a familiar term. However, care leavers are important part of the society. They need to be seen and recognised. column43: "I want to design the first 'made in Gambia' car and mass-produce it here," says Ida a mechanics trainee at our vocational training center in Bakoteh. Finding employment and decent work is key for young people to become self-reliant members of their communities, but 68 million young people around the world are unemployed. Together with our partners and the young people themselves, we have been developing innovative ways to empower young people for a better future. 🏆 Learn more ➡️ https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/publications/reports/annual-report-2019/youth-employability

Cirque du Soleil began sponsoring workshops for children and youth in our programmes in Mexico in 2014. The programme has since expanded to Brazil, Canada, Peru and South Africa. As a learning organization we are always looking for new ways to address the root causes of family breakdown and to strengthen the individual development of children, young people and families. 🎉👉Read more about our innovative programmes https://lnkd.in/gKFqzGk:=:https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/annual-report-2019

column43: Every child has a right to education. Yet, 64 million primary-age children worldwide are missing out on school because of poverty, discrimination, violence, family illness and other reasons. We promote child-centred quality education across all of our programmes focusing on the child as a resourceful individual with unique skills and capabilities. No child should miss out on education!📚

column43: Worldwide, 1 in 10 children is affected by child labour and millions of more children are at risk of being pushed into child labour due to Covid-19. One of the greatest challenges to addressing child labour is the complex web of reasons why children work and the inextricable link to poverty and a lack of social protection. Together with communities, we work to end child labour practices by connecting children and young people with training opportunities. #StopChildLabour 📸Lars Just

column43: Nine-year-old Diego* from Bolivia misses going to school and receiving formal education. Diego's school has been closed for months, as necessary tools and internet connection are lacking. In Latin America and the Caribbean alone, 137 million children have been missing out on their education due to Covid-19, says a recent UNICEF report. Today, on the International Day of Education, we raise our voices for the millions of children around the world who do not have the opportunity to receive an education. All children have the right to go to school. 📚🧒🎓 #CommitToEducation #InternationalDayOfEducation #SDG4 #QualityEducation 📸 Alejandra Kaiser *𝘕𝘢𝘮𝘦 𝘤𝘩𝘢𝘯𝘨𝘦𝘥 𝘵𝘰 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘵𝘦𝘤𝘵 𝘤𝘩𝘪𝘭𝘥’𝘴 𝘱𝘳𝘪𝘷𝘢𝘤𝘺

column43: As armed clashes resumed in Bouar in the Central African Republic, many families from the community fled the violence and sought shelter inside the SOS Children’s Village. Four hundred people, mostly women and children, are being housed and cared for inside the SOS Children’s Village for more than a week now. As armed groups cut off the main supply route, food prices have risen steeply raising fears of serious food shortages. In emergencies, children are the most vulnerable. The children and families of Bouar need your help. 👉Find out now how you can help: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/central-african-republic-appeal

column43: 𝐂𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐬 𝐔𝐩𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐞- 𝐂𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐀𝐟𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐑𝐞𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜: Since last week, more internally displaced people have sought shelter inside SOS Children’s Village Bouar due to armed violence in the region. More than 1300 people are now being sheltered inside the village. Our team in Bouar is continuing to support the distressed families by providing food and supplies, creating a safe and protective environment for children as well as offering trauma counselling. While the SOS Children’s Villages convoy of food, health and sanitary supplies finally arrived on Monday, needs are still pressing to provide everyone inside the village with food in the upcoming weeks.

column43: 23-year-old Aaden* from Somaliland is a shining example of how education can be the difference between poverty and prosperity. After receiving support through our family strengthening programme, Aaden was able to join a local technical school to learn the art of making aluminium installations. Due to his stellar performance, he became a teacher at this school and is now able to provide for his family. Aadens dream is to open his own workshop that produces and installs modern windows one day. 𝘞𝘦 𝘰𝘧𝘧𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘢𝘪𝘭𝘰𝘳𝘦𝘥 𝘴𝘶𝘱𝘱𝘰𝘳𝘵 𝘵𝘰 𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘨𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘯 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘪𝘦𝘴 𝘪𝘯 𝘯𝘦𝘦𝘥, 𝘩𝘦𝘭𝘱𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘵𝘰 𝘬𝘦𝘦𝘱 𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘮 𝘵𝘰𝘨𝘦𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳. 𝘐𝘯 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘭𝘢𝘴𝘵 𝘵𝘸𝘰 𝘺𝘦𝘢𝘳𝘴, 𝟷𝟸𝟶 𝘺𝘰𝘶𝘯𝘨 𝘱𝘦𝘰𝘱𝘭𝘦 𝘪𝘯 𝘚𝘰𝘮𝘢𝘭𝘪𝘭𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘩𝘢𝘷𝘦 𝘳𝘦𝘤𝘦𝘪𝘷𝘦𝘥 𝘵𝘦𝘤𝘩𝘯𝘪𝘤𝘢𝘭 𝘢𝘯𝘥 𝘷𝘰𝘤𝘢𝘵𝘪𝘰𝘯𝘢𝘭 𝘵𝘳𝘢𝘪𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘢𝘴 𝘱𝘢𝘳𝘵 𝘰𝘧 𝘵𝘩𝘦 𝘧𝘢𝘮𝘪𝘭𝘺 𝘴𝘵𝘳𝘦𝘯𝘨𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘯𝘪𝘯𝘨 𝘱𝘳𝘰𝘨𝘳𝘢𝘮𝘮𝘦. column43: The traditional coffee ceremony is an integral part of social and cultural life in Ethiopia. During the pandemic, staff from SOS Children's Villages Ethiopia also include information about Covid-19 in this ritual. Women from the community come with their children to attend the coffee ceremony, as well as learn how they can protect themselves and their family from the disease. With strong families, whole communities prosper!

Access to mental health and psychosocial support needs to be guaranteed to safeguard the future of children. 📸 Jacob Stærk Jacobsen

column43: On the occasion of today’s Care Day, we raise our voices to give visibility to all children and young people in care or in need of care. There are many different reasons why a child cannot grow up with their family. All children and young people have the right to care and protection, to grow up with healthy bonds and relationships to become their strongest selves. #ChildRights #AlternativeCare #NoChildAlone
column46: Care Day is a really important celebration for me, because it touches so many children around the world. It is very important to bring up the good experiences and successes, as foster care and child welfare are usually seen negatively. å SOS CHILDREN'S VILLAGES -Eveliina, 21, Finland "

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: Homeschooling has become the norm for children at the Herman Gmeiner School in Tema, Ghana. In order for the children to maintain a sense of normality, teachers reacted quickly and ensured that all children had access to education regardless of digital devices. Children without internet access can use a pick-up system to collect assignments and teaching materials once a week. But for millions of children worldwide, there is no such thing as homeschooling during lockdown. Education is central to children's development and well-being. Investments need to be made to ensure every child has access to quality education.

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: 𝐂𝐫𝐢𝐬𝐢𝐬 𝐔𝐩𝐝𝐚𝐭𝐞 - 𝐂𝐞𝐧𝐭𝐫𝐚𝐥 𝐀𝐟𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐚𝐧 𝐑𝐞𝐩𝐮𝐛𝐥𝐢𝐜: The situation in Bouar has improved over the past few days and all internally displaced people who had found shelter in the SOS Children's Village were able to return to their homes. Schools are supposed to reopen soon, allowing children to go back to a certain degree of normality. “We are relieved families could return home. However, we will continue to closely monitor the situation as the conflict has not yet come to an end and the situation remains volatile.” - M. Toure, National Director of SOS Children’s Villages Central African Republic. *𝘚𝘺𝘮𝘣𝘰𝘭𝘪𝘤 𝘱𝘪𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: On the one-year anniversary of the pandemic, as many wait for life to return to a “new normal,” we must not forget those uniquely challenged by #COVID19: the millions of children and young people growing up without parental care. Above all, we must listen to their voices and stay responsive to their needs in the face of uncertainty. Our actions today are tomorrow’s legacy. 👉 Read the opinion of SOS Children's Villages' CEO, Ingrid Maria Johansen https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/covid%E2%80%99s-lost-generation #YouthCan #PartneringForOpportunitiesThatWork #decentjobsforyouth #SustainableDevelopment #SDGs #CSR Allianz Johnson & Johnson AkzoNobel TK Elevator DHL Siegwerk
column46: sOS CHILDREN'S VILLAGES The pandemic has erased years of progress for a generation of young people growing up alone. Working with partners, we give them access to digital can tools, mentors and online skills training so they can get back to building their future. " Ingrid Johansen Chief Executive Officer sos Children's Villages Internationa

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: Children growing up in a stable and caring family in a supportive community have a greater chance to realise their full potential and lead an independent life. They better develop basic life skills such as communication, cooperation, problem-solving and setting personal goals. They also build self-confidence, determination and resilience. 👨‍👩‍👦‍👦💪 #NoChildAlone 📸 Alea Horst

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: While public schools are officially closed in Ghana, our team in Kumasi has started an extraordinary project. Thanks to 28 volunteer teachers and a well-implemented hygiene concept, 712 children in Kumasi are able to attend school lessons again. Close attention is paid to hygiene standards: personal protective equipment is provided, there is one empty chair next to each child as well as a hygiene station to thoroughly disinfect before and after classes. The SOS Children's Village team is already working to expand the project to offer lessons to disadvantaged children at other schools as well. 📸 Alea Horst
column47: Photos from SOS Children's Villages International's post

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: How have you been keeping yourself busy during lockdown? 📚👨‍🍳🗯️ Children and young people often have a hard time adapting to the #COVID19 reality, as they are used to meeting friends, going to school and having a daily routine. Caregivers at SOS Children's Villages Mexico City have come up with family activities, such as cooking and gardening, to relief stress and promote empathy among children and young people in their care. These family projects seek to sensitize children to their environment as they understand the importance of team work, commitment and responsibility. 👨‍👩‍👦‍👦🤲

column43: The COVID-19 pandemic and related measures have posed major challenges for young people pursuing their professional dreams. Besides less job opportunities and an increased risk of poverty, there have been practical challenges to access training opportunities. Our global partnership YouthCan! supports young people who leave alternative care or live in families facing challenges to train their skills and start an independent life. Read more in our latest YouthCan! report 👉 https://fal.cn/3dUvN:=:https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/getmedia/1c9b89b2-e643-42ab-8a43-1a7632f5e8a3/SOSCV-YouthCan-Facts-and-Figures-2020-LR.pdf?utm_content=&utm_medium=SOS+Children%27s+Villages+International&utm_source=facebook #YouthCan #PartneringForOpportunitiesThatWork #decentjobsforyouth #SustainableDevelopment #SDGs #CSR AkzoNobel Allianz DHL Johnson & Johnson Siegwerk TK Elevator
column46: å究 SOS CHILDREN'S VILLAGES already graduated as a catering agent but restaurants, bars and hotels were closed. That's why I followed Plowed several online classes, and applied everything learned at home. YouthCan! taught me many things: how to search for an internship and WWW how to be organized to find a job. Now I'm sure I'm able to reach " Kawtar,19,Morocco everything hope for.

column43: "Mental health is not the absence of illness, it is the sense of overall wellbeing where a person thrives in their life and they are able to function properly. We need to include a mental health approach in whatever we are doing and not wait for disaster to happen to intervene and do damage control."- Teresa Ngigi, child psychologist and mental health expert for SOS Children's Villages. As we mark the one-year anniversary of the #Covid19 pandemic, it is crucial to develop more protective factors for children, young people and adults, in order not to be paralyzed by its effects.

column43: "When my friends ask me if I think about my biological parents or why they would have left me, they are surprised when I tell them I do not think about them so much. I have had such a good life and such a caring family. My life is full of love so my mind doesn’t often go there," says Sneha , who grew up in SOS Children's Villages in Guwahati. column43: “Today we are an average family. We have food to eat, clothes to wear and I have businesses to run,” says Christiana who lives in Owe, a rural community in south-central Ghana. “My children can go to school without shame because they have proper uniforms and learning materials.” After Christiana's husband died, her family was facing financial hardship. She had to use her business capital to feed her children, leading to the collapse of the business. With the support of the SOS Children’s Village family strengthening programme, she was able to revive her business and provide for her children again. column43: The siblings Eva, Alex and Davit* love traditional Easter rituals like dyeing eggs and "egg tapping". 🐣 The SOS mothers at SOS Children's Villages Kotayk, Armenia, make sure to celebrate holidays and traditions to provide children and young people with a sense of identity and belonging. 👨‍👩‍👦‍👦 Every child should have the opportunity to simply be a child. column43: “I participate in the ECOSOC youth forum because we the youth can no longer remain just hopeful that things are going to get better while our world is being eroded by climate change, epidemics, a pandemic, poverty, hunger, war, rape, drug abuse, domestic violence, poor health, etc. I know that young people are a considerable portion of the world’s population. Therefore, we need to be given the opportunity to stand up and speak out on issues affecting our future.” - Wilmot, 22, Liberia Learn more: https://www.un.org/ecosoc/en/content/ecosoc-youth-forum-2021

column43: Radica, like 28 other young people from SOS Children’s Villages programmes, participated in conversations with youth and decision-makers on reducing inequalities, action for our planet and sustainable development during the first day of the two-day Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) Youth Forum. #YouthLead #Youth2030 Follow debates live: #YouthLead: Young People in the Driver’s Seat to Build Back Better - 2021 ECOSOC Youth Forum https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r-DipbbCjKI
column46: These international meetings give us motivation and inspire us to continue working for the rights of young people and exploring new opportunities for an independent and quality life. SOS CHILDREN'S VILLAGES Radica, 18, Kosovo "

column43: After last week's deadly attacks in the Palma District of northern Mozambique, thousands of people are on the move escaping violence and seeking protection. “Displaced persons are flooding into Pemba town seeking safety and aid. There is an urgent need for us to act. We have emergency supplies in stock and are working with the provincial and local government as well as partners to distribute what we can. However, as the political instability and crisis escalates, more will be needed," says Clemence Langa, National Director of SOS Children’s Villages Mozambique. The conflict is affecting mostly women and children who are exposed to different types of violence, such as trafficking, exploitation, abuse and neglect, sexual and gender based violence, sexual exploitation, and psychosocial distress.

column43: Heba is a changemaker like many of the young people participating in the two-day Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) Youth Forum to share their innovative ideas to pressing challenges with decision-makers. Heba’s initiative focuses on supporting young women leaving alternative care who have no family support. #YouthLead #Youth2030
column46: This conference will add to my knowledge and expand my horizons of ambition and pursuit, and enable me to help and support the young women who are without family support. SOS CHILDREN'S VILLAGES " Heba, 22, Jordan

column43: These days, many young people from around the world actively contribute to debates with decision-makers on pressing challenges and global solutions at the Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) Youth Forum. This includes 29 young people alone from SOS Children’s Villages programmes worldwide! Challenges and barriers, however, remain to actually guarantee meaningful child and youth participation in advocacy. Our new toolkit aims to improve that by providing those who support children and young people with step by step guidance and safeguarding practices: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/getmedia/2ee87f70-bf9f-4c06-ba6f-5d9738d53586/CYPA_toolkit_web_ENGLISH.pdf #YouthLead #Youth2030 #ChildYouthParticipation #ECOSOCYouthForum

column43: "The rising cost of living is a headache for us and we are finding it difficult to cope. Food and non-food items are available in the nearby market but the prices are high," says Zewdie, a foster mother of three boys in Ethiopia. column48:
ALIMA / AMCP-SP (Alliance Médicale Contre le Paludisme- Santé Population), et leur partenaire Terre des hommes lancent aujourd'hui officiellement le projet AIRE au Mali 🇲🇱 . La cérémonie de lancement s’est déroulée en présence du  Ministère de la Santé et du Développement Social.

Le projet AIRE vise à améliorer l’identification des détresses respiratoires de l’enfant grâce à l’utilisation de l’oxymètre de pouls et pourra ainsi permettre de réduire la mortalité infantile dans le district du projet.

✨Merci à tous les partenaires du Consortium ainsi qu’à UNITAID pour leur précieux soutien à ce projet.

👉Pour plus d'informations sur le projet AIRE, rendez-vous sur https://alima.ngo/blog/2020/11/11/loxymetre-de-pouls-un-outil-simple-et-essentiel-pour-detecter-les-detresses-respiratoires/"

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: As the conflict in northern Ethiopia’s Tigray region enters its sixth month, attention and concern is growing with news of alleged atrocities and a worsening crisis. The conflict has cost thousands of lives and has displaced more than a million people. An estimated 4.5 million people in the region need humanitarian assistance. SOS Children’s Villages Ethiopia is currently implementing a project that focuses on addressing emergency wash, nutrition and health needs in Mekelle and the surrounding Enderta district. Similar activities are planned to be implemented in Tigray’s three districts in the southern part of the regional state. “In total, we hope to reach over 50,000 individuals, a majority of which will be children,” says Binyam Asfaw, Humanitarian Response Coordinator for SOS Children’s Villages Ethiopia.

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column43: Crime and insecurity are spreading throughout Haiti. Cases of violence, armed robbery, and kidnapping for ransom are recorded throughout the country, with a significant incidence in Port-au-Prince. According to UNICEF, 73 women and children in Haiti have been targeted by gang violence this year alone. “Bandits are taking possession of increasingly larger territories. Not a day goes by without violence in the streets of the capital,” says Faimy Loiseau, national director of SOS Children’s Villages Haiti. “As the situation is rapidly deteriorating, we are putting on strategies to ensure the safety of all children and staff in our different programmes.” 📸 Alejandra Kaiser *𝘚𝘺𝘮𝘣𝘰𝘭𝘪𝘤 𝘱𝘪𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦

column43: Our global partnership #YouthCan! successfully expanded in 2020 and ensured young people had continued access to training and mentoring resources. column43: 28 young people from SOS Children’s Villages programmes around the world took part in the annual United Nations Economic and Social Council (ECOSOC) Youth Forum earlier in April. Due to the pandemic, participation was virtual allowing over 19,000 young people from over 190 countries to participate. The key focus of debates was how the pandemic and related measures impact young people’s lives. Despite the challenges, youth presented innovative ideas and initiatives in debates with UN and government representatives. Find out more about the young people’s experience: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/young-people-share-challenges-and-ideas-with-un #YouthLead #Youth2030

column43: We remain grateful for our volunteers who work selflessly to keep children healthy, safe, and stay connected throughout the ongoing pandemic. Here are some updates from across our global communities: 🌎 In Manila, former sponsored youth Zharina and the Philippine Coast Guard are working to provide COVID-19 swab tests to overseas Filipino workers. 🌎 In India, our volunteers are working to provide hygiene products like hand sanitizer to ensure healthy habits and slow the spread of COVID-19. 🌎 As part of our response in Zambia, our team has donated boxes of soap to local hospitals through a partnership with @CleantheWorld.

column43: If you work with children who have experienced alternative care and/or the child protection system, or you have experience of care, you may be interested in finding out more about the UN Committee on the Rights of the Child Day of General Discussion (DGD) on “Children’s Rights and Alternative Care,” which will be held in September of this year. The Committee is seeking input from anyone who is interested in contributing, whether adults, children or young people, as part of a global public consultation to help feed into the discussions at the DGD. Find out more about the DGD and how you can help shape this important event: https://www.ohchr.org/EN/HRBodies/CRC/Pages/Discussion2020.aspx #DGD2021 #ChildRightsAndCare

column43: “The burden of not knowing how to feed my children or how to send them to school was very heavy on me,” says Helena, a mother of three from Ghana. For almost a year, Helena’s 17-year-old daughter, Abena, had to sell nuts on the streets of Ghana instead of going to school. She had to provide for her family as Helena was ill and could not work. Helena’s family received support through our #familystrengthening programme in 2019 and has come a long way since then. Helena has a maize farm and can now provide for her family, while Abena was able to return to school to follow her dream of becoming a nurse.

column43: We recognize with deep sadness cases of failings within our organization that, in some instances, have been systematically hidden from view. We have now introduced new measures to support victims, prevent further harm and improve existing systems, to consistently ensure quality care for all children in our programmes. More information can be found here: https://www.sos-childrensvillages.org/news/sos-children%E2%80%99s-villages-responds-to-failures
column46: We are deeply saddened that there have been cases within the organization where leaders did not listen to children or our own staff members where we did not take sufficient action against perpetrators where we did not follow the correct procedures. On behalf of the federation, apologise to the children and young people who have been subject to harm. will not rest until| am confident that the light of the truth has shone on all wrongdoing. " CEO, Ingrid Johansen, sos Children's Villages International

column43: Samjhana was among many daily wage labourers who lost their livelihoods during the second wave of the pandemic in South Asia. Before lockdown, she earned a living as a street vendor to provide for her two-year-old daughter. Samjhana and her daughter receive support through the family strengthening program of SOS Children’s Village Sanothimi. The socio-economic impact of #COVID19 is felt hardest by the world’s most vulnerable families. It is crucial to provide social protection services that support families’ income and wellbeing.

column43: Today is World Day Against Child Labour. In 2021, declared the International Year for the Elimination of Child Labour, 160 million children worldwide are still forced to work, according to the latest report by International Labour Organization and UNICEF. It threatens their mental, physical and social development, poses risks to their health, and interferes with their schooling. We must make sure that the pandemic doesn’t reverse years of efforts to #endchildlabour. It is time to act now and prioritize investments to break the cycle of poverty. #EndChildLabour2021 #ChildLabour #WorldDayAgainstChildLabour 📷 Conor Ashleigh *𝘚𝘺𝘮𝘣𝘰𝘭𝘪𝘤 𝘱𝘪𝘤𝘵𝘶𝘳𝘦

column43: Today, EU Member States adopted a historical recommendation establishing the European Child Guarantee. The Guarantee will support the growing number of children living in vulnerable situations in the EU. #EUChildGuarantee
column46: sOS CHILDREN'S VILLAGES of We are delighted to see that the specific challenges and needs children who cannot grow up with their families or are at risk of losing parental care have been addressed as we recommended. We are now eager to further engage with EU Member States to develop and implement robust national action plans that will turn the ambition of the Guarantee into reality for children. " Ingrid Johansen Chief Executive Officer sos Children's Villages International

column43: Only 16% of children in Africa were covered by social protection before the pandemic, compared to 90% of children in high-income countries. In the #COVID19 era, inequalities rise. Today is International Day of the African Child. 🌍 Children all over the world have the right to social protection services. We must strive for equality to make sure no child is left behind. #DayoftheAfricanChild #DAC2021

Because of your support, she's been able to continue her studies at home throughout the lockdown. "In these difficult times I can be calm, it gives me a lot of security to know that I can count on their support." - Didra Stay tuned to see how you can help youth like Didra adjust to their "new normal."

Bret F., DONOR children international®

column43: Today we mark the 102nd birthday of Hermann Gmeiner, the founder of SOS Children’s Villages. He envisioned a new way to care for children left without parents after the Second World War. Through this concept, he hoped that no child in the world would have to grow up alone. Today, his vision can be seen in 137 countries around the 🌎. 💙 #SOSChildrensVillagesDay #HermannGmeinerDay

But thanks to the kindness of your donations and partners like the Buffalo Dream Center, Dolly and her family received the food and essentials they were finding difficult to come by. You can provide food and essentials to families like Daisy's that are struggling due to Coronavirus. column43: The primary reason why families are admitted to our family strengthening programmes is poverty. Lack of access to basic supplies and income insecurity have dramatic long-term consequences and increase the risk of family separation. With coordinated global effort, we can support families facing hardship and prevent children from losing parental care. 📷 Alejandra Kaiser

column43: Your support is helping children and youth across our global communities throughout the COVID-19 pandemic and today on World Literacy Day. Tiyasha, sponsored youth in Kolkata lives with her parents. Her father is a daily wage earner and her mother is a homemaker like many other parents in the community. Here, she sees some of the most impoverished conditions and fights to continue her education. A few months ago, Tiyasha found herself having to stay home because of social distancing guidelines and the closure of her community center - making daily life even more challenging. "Education has always been my passion. I would like to thank Children International and supporters. Now I am confident that I can fulfill my dreams of becoming a nurse." - Tiyasha Because of you, we've distributed study kits to children and youth like Tiyasha across our communities to keep them engaged and learning. #LiteracyDay

column43: Summer isn't easy for food-insecure families. Often they have to choose between paying increase electric bills, or buying groceries and other essentials for the home. That's why it is so important during this time of year to keep our trucks on the road to deliver food to the families struggling through these hard months. For every dollar you donate, you supplement up to 6 meals. column43: Taking care of the planet is taking care of the future of children. For over 10 years now, young people from SOS Children’s Villages programmes have visited our eco-village in Tenerife to learn how to protect the environment and prevent climate change. The eco-village offers workshops on biodiversity, sustainable construction and farming. Together, young people can turn their dream of a greener future into action.

column43: Each day, we're inspired by women across our global communities who are finding other ways to stay afloat. Before the COVID-19 pandemic, Claudia supported her family through her work as a seamstress and other domestic work around her community. Recently, in the face of the crisis, she found herself forced to stay home, without work. "We decided to make masks because we're all out of work. And for us, it's a pleasure to do this because it helps the economy. Thank God that right now the sale of these masks is helping us because we no longer have an economy." - Claudia Visit https://chldrn.org/3k5V0rb:=:https://www.children.org/see-the-impact/charity-programs/crisis/covid to learn more about the crisis and how you can help right now.

column43: Some 200 million children under the age of 5 suffered from #malnutrition in 2020. Today, hunger looms over families in many regions as a result of the global health crisis and local conflicts. Malnutrition in early childhood impairs growth and cognitive development, stopping children from reaching their full physical and mental capacity. Through our family strengthening programme, we provide families with knowledge and tools so that they can build nurturing and safe homes for their children, support their children’s development and take care of their needs. 📷 Faham Foorodi

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: Megan’s wish from Make-A-Wish Alabama for a puppy transformed her life. Though she continues to deal with her gastrointestinal disorder on a daily basis, Dove, her cuddly English Cream Golden Retriever, keeps her spirits bright. Seven years later, Megan and Dove have formed an unbreakable bond. Inspired by her wish, Megan regularly supports Make-A-Wish by attending and supporting various events – Dove has even accompanied Megan on occasion! Megan and her mom love helping to raise funds for Make-A-Wish because they have witnessed firsthand the life-changing impact of a wish. Wishes need stars like you. Help us make every wish come 1 at wish.org.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: A few facts about Malawi: Its population is around 18 million. It is known as "The Warm Heart of Africa" because of the kindness of its people. It is landlocked but home to Lake Malawi. On average, children only receive 4.5 years of schooling. 12% of babies are born with low birth weight. And 37% of children are affected by stunted growth. In Malawi, we have made significant progress in improving the nutritional status of the communities we work in; increasing access to education; promoting healthy behaviors among children and their caregivers; and empowering communities to become self-sustaining as they overcome poverty. Learn more about our work in Malawi: https://bit.ly/2DbAGnZ:=:https://www.feedthechildren.org/our-work/around-the-world/malawi/ #Malawi #ZeroHunger #Nutrition #Community

She misses church, helping people, and serving. She's been getting more creative with how she's getting food during COVID and also making sure her grandkids are fed. #Covid19 #ZeroHunger

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: Diagnosed with a blood disorder when he was just two days old, wish kid Edward took a special interest in medicine over the course of his life. In high school, Edward decided he wanted to study pediatric nursing after graduation, a decision that coincided with him considering his wish from Make-A-Wish. A laptop, pens, pencils, notebooks -everything a college freshman needs, started arriving at his house. The gifts were a mystery until Edward open up a package sharing that Make-A-Wish Mid-South was sending him to nursing school. We are so excited for Edward's new journey. Help us make every wish come 1, donate now at wish.org.

Cheyenne, who lives with a nervous system disorder, hopes to use her new pool to spend more time with her family and as therapy for her legs and muscles. 💙 Make-A-Wish Northeast New York Now more than ever, hope is essential. column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: In 1996, 10-year-old Mikey was granted a wish from Make-A-Wish Wisconsin to have a room makeover in his basement. Inspired by how his wish transformed his life, Mikey, and his mom, Susie, began to fundraise for Make-A-Wish, hoping to spread hope and joy to other wish kids. Mikey has since passed, but Susie carries on his legacy through her fundraising efforts and referring wish kids. “I have seen over and over again the significant difference a wish makes, and I will do all I can to make sure that every eligible child receives the life-changing experience of a wish come 1," says Susie. Wishes need stars like you. Help make every wish come 1: wish.org.

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: Beginning in 2005 with his first wish, Michael Phelps has granted 13 wishes to kids with critical illnesses, changing their lives forever. 🏊 Whether he’s offering coaching advice to improve their swimming or just offering encouragement, he’s given our wish kids memories to last a lifetime. His strength, kindness, and generosity are an inspiration to wish kids everywhere. Wishes need stars like you. Help us make every wish come 1 at wish.org.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Meet Janela, a sweet 3-year-old from the Philippines. When Janela's family doesn't have enough to eat, her father takes fishing jobs to provide. Unfortunately, the earnings are meager, and Janela's father and mother often do not eat, so Janela and her two sisters can get the nutrition they need. Despite the difficulty of their situation, her parents send the older girls to school daily to receive an education and food. It's because of your donations that Janela and her sisters receive shoes, meals, and school supplies. "We don't need to buy a bag and other school needs of the children, and also shoes. We can spend our money to buy food instead", says Janela's mother. You can provide school meals for a child for an entire year for only $15! Donate now, link in stories. https://bit.ly/2vk9AYm:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?2562.donation=form1&df_id=2562&mfc_pref=T&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=social-15-feeding&utm_campaign=15-int-child-feeding-program&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_content=15-feeding #International #Philippines Feed the Children-Asia

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: Diagnosed with a nervous system disorder, Andre from Make-A-Wish Metro New York and Western New York said the first 8 years of his life were some of his hardest – he spent so much time in hospitals that it became his second home. When Andre's wish to have a birthday party was granted, his whole outlook changed. It was his first real birthday party, and the first time that he truly felt the energy and strength to never give up. Now, he is a wrestling referee and continuous supporter of Make-A-Wish. “[My wish gave me] a new life and new hope and the belief that I can overcome anything," Andre says. Wishes need stars like you. Help us make every wish come 1 at wish.org.

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: 8-year-old wish kid, Jasmine, loves meeting new people, playing with her dolls and reading. She received a heart transplant in January 2011, and her journey thus far has included monthly blood draws, medications and yearly biopsies. When the Make-A-Wish Southern Nevada discovery team met with Jasmine, it was clear her greatest wish was to have a physical and digital library in her room. Make-A-Wish staff and volunteers came together in a way that ensured every detail of Jasmine's wish was perfect. We think her smile says it all!

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: "The COVID 19 pandemic has caused my husband to lose his job at the security company where he worked because jobs were cut and several people were fired. He is the main supporter, this as a family affected us because it is difficult for us to buy food for our children. Our family nucleus is 4 people: my husband and my 2 children," Cesia Hernandez, El Salvador Families in the 10 countries we serve are all feeling the effects of COVID-19. Cesia's family was not sure how they were going to survive with the layoff of her husband, but thanks to your donations and the efforts of our Feed the Children - Latin America family, Cesia's family doesn't have to worry about where their next meals will come from. You can continue to help struggling families due to the coronavirus Internationally and in the US. Donate Now: https://bit.ly/2W9wIne:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?1400.donation=form1&df_id=1400&mfc_pref=T&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=coronavirus&utm_campaign=2020-crisis&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_content=coronoavirus #International Feed the Children- Latin America & the Caribbean

Luckily, Hibo was able to stop the marriage and can now continue to follow her dream of attending university to become an engineer.

column43: "I have moved schools almost seven times in the past ten years, and my biggest fear has always been cyberbullying. The unknown is still a scary thing, but with the introduction of technology, the impact and effect of the “unknown” can become worse. I’ve seen my friends be bullied on the internet."⁣ ⁣ Gitanjali, 14, who created “Kindly”, an internet service that helps to detect and prevent cyberbullying using the latest developments in Artificial Intelligence. The internet is always evolving — and internet safety needs to evolve with it. As young people spend more time online amidst the COVID-19 pandemic, Gitanjali wants kindness to be the top priority in keeping herself and others safe. "I like to spread the message of kindness and its importance in our community. I like to use technology to solve problems in our community and hopefully inspire others to be kind."

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: The world is witnessing an alarming decline in children’s vaccinations, with more than 60 countries reporting disruptions to this life-saving service during the COVID-19 pandemic. This is a defining moment for the health of the world’s children. Will we allow this crisis to reverse decades of progress against other contagious diseases? Or will we respond to the challenge, recover lost ground and reimagine a future in which every child is protected?

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: “My wish is that one day I would wake up and hear that Coronavirus is no more and we can go back to school.” Like many kids in Zimbabwe, McClean’s life has been disrupted by the COVID-19 pandemic. She’s not going to school or able to play with her neighborhood friends. McClean and her young brother are among the 650 children that we’ve provided with hygiene kits. Their mother is very grateful and tells us the kits will assist them at home, as they had nothing to protect themselves from catching the virus.
column47: Photos from Save the Children US's post

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: We share a global goal for this baby in Mauritania and millions of other children throughout the world: to end malnutrition and hunger in all its forms by the year 2030. But the harsh reality is that we’re not on track. After steadily diminishing for decades, chronic hunger has been rising for the last five years. And now, the economic recession caused by the COVID-19 pandemic could mean 130 million more people go hungry this year. Children urgently need action to survive today and to thrive in the years to come. We must ensure every family has access to affordable and nutritious diets. It’s time to lift children up.

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: Wish kid Vicente is like any other boy his age. He loves to play outside and ride in his toy car, but unlike most other kids, Vicente has had to overcome many challenges due to his heart condition and genetic disorder. Because of his weakened immune system, Vicente is unable to go to public parks or play outside for fear of developing an infection. For his wish, he wanted a backyard makeover that would bring the joy of playing outside to his own backyard… anytime he wants! “The joy he gets from his wish every day— words just can’t describe,” his Mom said. You can bring hope to kids like Vicente by donating at wish.org. 📷: Make-A-Wish San Diego

To combat this, we're scaling up our emotional wellness program to help children stay resilient when it matters most. See how it's helping sponsored families right now: https://chldrn.org/3lpipEo:=:https://www.children.org/stories/2020/10_october/volunteer-mom-receives-vital-mental-health-support?utm_campaign=&utm_medium=social&utm_source=facebook.com&utm_content=&rs_id=196&attr=rkd_organic

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: These children are about to receive life-saving vaccines in Nigeria. But across the country, too many girls and boys are still waiting. Last year, just 57% of children in Nigeria were fully vaccinated for serious diseases like diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis. 2.5 million children received no vaccines at all - the highest number in the world. Today, this already fragile health system is facing a new threat. The COVID-19 pandemic is severely disrupting immunizations in Nigeria, leaving even more children at risk of measles and other contagious diseases. As we respond to the new threat of COVID-19, we must continue to protect children from old and persistent dangers that could surge in fresh outbreaks - unless we act now.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Drop by drop, polio vaccines are helping children in Mauritania to grow up healthy and live out their full potential. The country has made strong progress, increasing vaccination rates for common diseases by 17 percentage points over the last decade. But these life-saving gains have not been shared across West and Central Africa, where progress has stalled and vaccination rates continue to lag far behind the rest of the world. Just 66% of the region’s girls and boys are fully protected, with one in three children still vulnerable to serious diseases. We can and must do better for every child, everywhere.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Over the last four decades, global vaccination rates have jumped from 20 to 85% and saved millions of children from preventable deaths. But this incredible progress also hides deep inequalities. Last year, 96% of children were vaccinated in Eastern Europe and Central Asia, compared to just 66% in West and Central Africa. Now, the COVID-19 pandemic is widening these already unacceptable gaps. This global crisis calls for global solidarity. We’re urging the international community to do its part to help countries which are struggling to deliver life-saving vaccinations for children. Because 1 progress is shared by all.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: This was the moment Chetal received a life-saving vaccine in India. Over the last ten years, the country made impressive gains in delivering vaccinations to more children than ever before. But 1.4 million girls and boys are still not receiving any vaccines at all. Here, and throughout the world, we cannot rest until every child has equal access to this essential care.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “I came because I want to protect my baby from bad diseases like measles,” said Annet, after walking to reach a health centre in Uganda during the COVID-19 outbreak. “I didn’t mind the distance because all I wanted was to have my baby immunized. I am even willing to support mothers who can’t walk this far. I volunteered to support my neighbour, who has twins, by helping her carry one baby.” Limited public transport, fear of COVID-19 infection, lockdowns and other restrictions are making it difficult for many families to access health care right now. But parents are determined to continue their children’s vaccinations and we’re urging all governments to make that possible.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Vaccines are safe, effective and life-saving. They’re good for children - and good for us all. For every US $1 spent on immunization, we see an average return of $26 from savings on health care and lost revenues due to illness across a child’s lifetime.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: We all agree that children are worthy of care - that no girl or boy should suffer pain, disability or death from a preventable disease. This universal belief has driven health workers, humanitarians and the global community to increase vaccination rates fourfold since 1980. But over the last ten years, progress stalled. We were already off track to reach our global goal of vaccinating every child by 2030. Now, COVID-19 disruptions are threatening to throw us further off course and reverse what we have achieved together. There is only one acceptable path forward into the new decade: bold action to reimagine a healthy future for every child.

Post a video about how hunger affects people all over the world. 4. Have a (socially distant) dinner party, themed around meals under $10. 5. Volunteer at a pantry or community event and share your experience on social media. These are just some ideas. This is your opportunity to fill plates and impact lives. And thanks to the donations of corporate partners, your dollar goes 7x farther to deliver food to hungry families. #DefeatHungerMonth #CancelHunger

column43: A child's earliest years are the foundation of a good life - the building blocks that support everything that follows. These critical first years cannot be paused for COVID-19. They are a once in a lifetime chance to learn, grow and develop. The pandemic is putting this foundation at risk, with at least 40 million children worldwide missing out on early childhood education in their pre-school year because of shuttered facilities. Families need support from their governments and employers to weather this storm and safeguard their children’s development. Let's help all parents make the early moments with affordable, quality child care and early childhood education.

column43: “I can use this latrine and my knees won’t bite me.” Rajuma, 6, has a physical disability where she has pain in her knees and is unable to walk long distances. A UNICEF innovation that transforms a standard latrine into a disability-friendly solution is helping Rajuma to safely and easily use the latrines.

He got to experience every aspect of being a landscaper and ended his day with a lifetime of memories that he and his family will cherish. You can help bring hope for today—and tomorrow by donating at wish.org. 📸: Make-A-Wish Alaska and Washington

column43: “I miss my school, my teachers and my friends.” 11-year-old Dechen in Bhutan is doing her best to learn during COVID-19, but is finding it hard to study without the help of her teachers. “I understand the lessons better in school when our teachers explain; I don’t understand much when I watch it on TV. At school, the teacher explains until we understand the lessons but on television, the lessons go very fast and we can’t catch up.” To help children reach their full potential, UNICEF is calling for schools to be the first public services to re-open as communities recover from COVID-19.

column43: As COVID-19 continues to spread, so does misinformation. This helpline centre in Islamabad, Pakistan is open from 8:00 am to midnight, seven days a week. The dedicated staff provide life-saving information on how people can keep themselves and their loved ones safe from the virus, and connect them with a doctor when required. Since the outbreak, the centre has been inundated, on some days they receive up to 70,000 calls. UNICEF is on the ground in more than 190 countries, partnering with front-line responders to help provide the information and resources they need to keep families safe, informed and healthy. It's time for facts, not fear.

column43: The domino effects of COVID-19 are causing more harm to children than the disease itself. By disrupting supplies of nutritious foods, the pandemic could leave a staggering 6.7 million more young children dangerously malnourished this year. We cannot allow children like Sarah, in South Sudan, to become the overlooked victims of this crisis. It’s time to respond, recover and reimagine a future where every child thrives with nutritious food.

column43: We share a global goal for this baby in Mauritania and millions of other children throughout the world: to end malnutrition in all its forms. But the COVID-19 pandemic is disrupting food supplies and confronting us all with a harsh reality: 10,000 more children could die from malnutrition every month this year. Children urgently need action to survive today and to thrive in the years to come. We must ensure every family has access to affordable and nutritious diets. It’s time to lift children up.
