column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Lead is silently seeping into children’s bodies through unregulated lead-acid battery recycling operations, electronic waste dumps, pottery, spices, paint, toys and drinking water. We’ve known about the toxicity of lead for centuries. Yet today, 1 in 3 children are poisoned by lead globally - causing irreversible harm to their brains and bodies. To protect children’s health, UNICEF and Pure Earth are calling for urgent action - including shielding children from high-risk sites and products that contain lead, such as certain ceramics, paints, toys and spices.
column46: " Lead silently wreaks havoc on children's health and development, Henrietta H. Fore, Fore, UNICEF Executive Director unicef for every child

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: 1 in 3 children are poisoned by lead globally. Often unwittingly and with life-altering consequences, children are growing up in harm's way, inhaling dust and fumes from unregulated used lead-acid battery recycling operations and open-air smelters, eating food contaminated by lead-glazed pottery and lead-infused spices, living in homes with peeling lead paint, playing with lead-covered toys, drinking lead contaminated water and even working in lead-laced electronic waste dumps. The list goes on. Childhood lead exposure can lead to lower IQ levels, behavioural issues and increased risk of kidney damage and cardiovascular diseases in later life. UNICEF and Pure Earth are calling for urgent action including stronger environmental, health and safety legislation, and investment in health services to monitor, test and treat children’s exposure to lead.

column43: For a child fighting cancer, hope is essential. Just ask 16-year-old Matthew whose wish to give funds for childhood cancer research was granted in 2019. After undergoing challenging chemotherapy that left him paralyzed, Matthew had to learn how to walk again. “My wish is that no other child has to go through what I went through,” Matthew said. On his wish day, Matthew toured the research lab at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta, experimented with the specialists and together with Make-A-Wish Georgia, Matthew presented a check to his doctor to further cancer research. Matthew’s incredibly heartfelt wish will continue to make a difference, allowing his doctor to work towards finding a cure for childhood cancer. This Childhood Cancer Awareness Month help us make every wish come 1. Donate today at wish.org/donate:=:https://secure2.wish.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=donate_now&chid=100-000.

column43: Our hearts are with children and families affected by the horrific explosions in Lebanon, especially those who lost their loved ones. We wish a speedy recovery to the injured.⠀ ⠀ According to latest reports, the death toll could be as high as 100 with 4,000 wounded and over 300,000 people displaced. UNICEF is concerned that children are among the casualties and we are aware that those who survived are traumatized and under shock.⠀ ⠀ UNICEF’s team in Beirut has not been spared. One of our colleagues lost his spouse, seven of our staff were mildly injured and dozens of colleagues’ homes were damaged. Most of our staff - as are most people in Lebanon - are in a state of shock.⠀ ⠀ UNICEF is coordinating very closely with authorities and partners on the ground to respond to the needs including that of health and other front-line workers.⠀ ⠀ We have provided drinking water to staff at the Beirut port and are supporting the Ministry of Public Health to take out what is left of stored medicines and vaccines in a warehouse at the port.⠀ ⠀ Child protection partners are providing psycho-social support to affected children across the city. Over the coming days, we will increase our efforts to reach families in need with much needed assistance.⠀ ⠀ Yesterday’s catastrophe in Beirut adds to what has already been a terrible crisis for the people of Lebanon compounded by an economic collapse and a surge in COVID-19 cases. The pandemic already meant that hospitals are overwhelmed, and front-line workers are exhausted.⠀ ⠀ UNICEF confirms its commitment towards the people of Lebanon, the authorities and all partners on the ground. We will do everything possible to provide much needed assistance today and in the long run.

column43: How has your child kept learning during coronavirus? As schools closed because of COVID-19, parents, caregivers and educators have found new and innovative ways to help keep children learning through their laptops, phones, radios and television sets. Yet, access to the tools needed to continue children’s education is often unequal. More than half the world’s population are not online, and electricity and ownership of televisions and radios vary across countries. UNICEF is working with governments and partners to bridge the digital divide - and connect every school to the internet.

column43: Breastfeeding isn’t a one-person job. Those who breastfeed need support from someone who listens to their experience and responds to their needs with reassurance and reliable advice. But too many mothers simply don’t have that chance. This is critical - especially during COVID-19. Breastfeeding helps protect babies from many diseases, fuels brain development and sets the foundation for a good life. We’re urging governments to invest in equal access to skilled counselling for every mother, no matter who they are or where they live.

column43: For a child fighting cancer, hope is essential. Following a cancer diagnosis, the thought of having a furry companion always helped brightened 8-year-old Kaelee’s spirits in between cancer treatments. When Make-A-Wish Minnesota gave her the chance to identify her most heartfelt wish, Kaelee knew she wanted her very own Saint Bernard puppy. Kaelee was overcome with happiness the moment she met Missy, her new pup! The day Kaelee took Missy home marked the one-year anniversary of her first chemo treatment. Since then, Missy has served as a constant source of joy, hope and renewed strength for Kaelee. 🎗 This Childhood Cancer Awareness Month, help us make every wish come 1. Donate to Make-A-Wish today: wish.org/donate:=:https://secure2.wish.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=donate_now&chid=100-000.

column43: More than 1.57 billion children have been affected by COVID-19 related school closures. We don’t yet have enough evidence to measure the impact on disease transmission rates. But the risks to children’s learning, safety and wellbeing are well documented. The longer children are out of school, the greater the risk of sexual violence, child labour and child marriage. As schools make plans to reopen after COVID-19 shutdowns, it can’t be business as usual. We’re working with governments and partners to invest in better schools - and reach the most vulnerable children. This includes making clean water, nutritious meals, psychosocial support and access to the Internet available for every child.

column43: The war in Yemen has taken everything from Ahmed and his family. "We have nothing. Sometimes, my children don’t eat anything from morning till sunset except for some bread." When his daughter Hanan became malnourished last year, Ahmed made the long journey on foot to a Save the Children supported clinic so that Hanan could receive life-saving treatment. Your support can ensure Hanan and millions of children in Yemen can continue to get the care they need: http://ow.ly/jl2850BeV4r:=:https://support.savethechildren.org/site/Donation2?df_id=2521&2521.donation=form1&cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Yemen:Scus_1x_post1:090120

UNICEF is working with partners to support children and families, and equip frontline responders like Tetyana with the protective equipment and resources they need and deserve.

column43: “I grew up in this community. They helped me to learn and excel in my profession," says Kalkidan, a nurse working with UNICEF Ethiopia. "Serving them and teaching them about how to prevent COVID-19 makes me happy.” For most of her career Kalkidan has worked in the vaccination department, on infant and maternal health. She teaches pregnant women to follow up their monthly checkups, to deliver their baby in the health center with skilled attendants, to track their health and the health of their baby, and to regularly bring their baby in for immunization. With COVID-19, one of their greatest initial challenges was countering rumors that going to the health center would expose people to the virus. Mothers and pregnant women were avoiding the health center, even for delivery. #RealLifeHeroes like Kalkidan are helping change this.

column43: “I like to be with children, to show something new to them. I can even take them for a walk sometimes. And during the walk, I try to tell them something useful and educational. Maybe they remember it and will use it in their adult life.” Iryna Laposhyna is a social worker in Ukraine supporting nine families. Despite COVID-19, she makes the trek to provide the psychological help and in-kind assistance that’s more important than ever for countless families under the strain of the pandemic. Social workers like Iryna are doing everything they can to continue their work, because while other activities may slow or stop during COVID-19, the protection of children can’t be paused.

column43: More than 1.57 billion children have been affected by COVID-19 related school closures. We don’t yet have enough evidence to measure the impact on disease transmission rates. But the risks to children’s learning, safety and wellbeing are well documented. The longer children are out of school, the greater the risk of sexual violence, child labour and child marriage. As schools make plans to reopen after COVID-19 shutdowns, it can’t be business as usual. We’re working with governments and partners to invest in better schools - and reach the most vulnerable children. This includes making clean water, nutritious meals, psychosocial support and access to the Internet available for every child.

column43: In the face of relentless challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic, these social workers are committed to protecting vulnerable children. Lockdowns and school closures have left many out of sight and separated from their support systems. Governments must step up to protect and invest in social workers and the children that depend on them.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: "Having access to those hygiene products and things that they need… I think it helps boost their self-esteem. It helps them just have more confidence. We see that if they have those items that they need, that we have a higher attendance rate and less of the social ramifications and arguing and bickering and fighting and being made fun of. So I think that's important. Social-emotional health right now is just as important as the education we're providing them." Kerri Griggs, a teacher in Union City, Oklahoma. Food and essentials are important for children going to school. When bellies are full and hygiene-needs are taken care of, kids will attend class more often, have higher self-esteem, and have better attitudes. That's one of the reasons our Teacher Stores are so important! They give teachers the tools they need to grow our future leaders.

Then the door blew off its hinges. I remember that I just started screaming. My mother ran to me, pressed hard on my wound and gave me a drink of water so I wouldn’t faint.” UNICEF is on the ground, working with partners to provide children like Mira with medical, psychological and education support. The needs are staggering - overshadowed by the constant threat of COVID-19. To scale up our response for families, we urgently need your support. column43: Ubah, 33, lost all her livestock from the drought in Somalia. ⁠ ⁠ To feed her family, Ubah would go to the local market to find casual jobs. But the pandemic has left Ubah jobless and her family on the brink of hunger. ⁠ ⁠ In Somalia, we are supporting families like Ubah with cash to improve their income and purchase food. ⁠ ⁠ “Prior to receiving this support, we were eating once a day and that was in the morning only. I have seen my children sleeping hungry. As a mother the best feeling is to know that your children are well fed and are healthy. The worse feeling for a mother is when you fail to feed your children. It can be really painful.” ⁠ ⁠ Here's how you can help families like Ubah's get the support they need to survive: http://ow.ly/SbVm50Bot9H:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/what-we-do/emergency-response/helping-starving-african-children?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_HungerRelief:Scus_Lp_Post1:091120

column43: Faten, a single mother of three, embraces her children at their home in Beirut, Lebanon. “I was away from home, away from my children. My first and only thought was that my children must have been killed," says Faten, who works in shifts as a cleaner across the city. “I ran home as fast as I could. I felt my feet moving, but it was as if I was going nowhere. When I finally got home and saw my children were unhurt, I couldn’t take my eyes off them. My eldest daughter was pale and silent, my son wept, and my youngest daughter clung to me for the next three hours”. Faten and her family are being assisted by Himaya, which provides psychological care and protection with UNICEF's support. The explosion has made a bad situation worse for families in Lebanon who are already facing a lack of safe drinking water, daily power cuts and the threat of COVID-19. The challenges are staggering and profound stress will take time to heal, but Fatma feels supported. “They [Himaya] were the first people to call us after the blast. The only people to call and check on my children and to ask if we needed any assistance. Since that day, they have been here for us, making my hope for a return to normal life a little more achievable”. Help families rebuild their lives by donating today → .https://uni.cf/beirut_expl_f:=:https://www.unicefusa.org/?form=LebanonEmergency

This year, doctors have implemented telehealth services to support youth like Wilfred and other families in need so they don't go without critical services during this health crisis.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Welcome to the world, Daisy Dove Bloom! We are honoured to introduce Goodwill Ambassadors Katy Perry and Orlando Bloom's new bundle of joy. “We are floating with love and wonder from the safe and healthy arrival of our daughter,” Katy and Orlando told us. “But we know we’re the lucky ones and not everyone can have a birthing experience as peaceful as ours was. Communities around the world are still experiencing a shortage of healthcare workers and every eleven seconds a pregnant woman or newborn dies, mostly from preventable causes. Since COVID-19 many more newborn lives are at risk because of the increased lack of access to water, soap, vaccines and medicines that prevent diseases. As parents to a newborn, this breaks our hearts, as we empathize with struggling parents now more than ever. “As UNICEF Goodwill Ambassadors, we know UNICEF is there, on the ground, doing whatever it takes to make sure every expecting mother has access to a trained health worker and access to quality healthcare. In celebration of the heart we know our daughter already has, we have set up a donation page to celebrate DDB’s arrival. By supporting them, you are supporting a safe start to life and reimagining a healthier world for every child. We hope your ♥️ can bloom with generosity. Gratefully- Katy & Orlando.” http://uni.cf/PreciousGift:=:https://www.unicef.org/reimagine/precious-gift?utm_campaign=covid-baby&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=organic-post-1

UNICEF is calling for urgent investment to bridge the digital divide, reach every child with quality education and, most critically, prioritize the reopening of schools.

column43: At the height of COVID-19 lockdowns, around 1.5 billion schoolchildren were affected by school closures. UNICEF is calling on governments to prioritise reopening schools and to take all possible measures to reopen safely. When reopening is not possible, UNICEF urges governments to make sure the most marginalized students have access to catch-up lessons and remote learning.

column43: "The endless stream of cars kept coming, over eight hundred. Your endless stream of boxes were right there waiting for them…Mostly it was mothers with their children. Sometimes with one child, sometimes with two or three in the back seat…When they thanked us, we thanked them for the privilege of serving and for their life-giving work in raising children. Some mothers cried…Please let your team know that their hard work…made something magical, special, priceless and BIG happen in that parking lot…" Tom, volunteer in Woonsocket, RI. As we rally for the holidays to help provide food and joy for struggling families, we wanted to share the passionate words of a wonderful volunteer. Tom is a retired gentleman who recently helped load boxes of supplies into families’ cars at a distribution event in Woonsocket, Rhode Island. Thank you to Tom and all our donors who make this possible!

Tahsin Uddin, a 22-year-old content creator and advocate from Bangladesh, will be one of the mentors supporting the selected participants, who will learn storytelling skills from top content creators and have their work published on Voices of Youth. ⠀ At the age of 12, Tahsin started publishing a monthly newspaper to promote children’s creativity as well as write on the impact of climate change on children in his community. He’s still working to spread mobile journalism among the teenagers of Bangladesh… and the world! column43: “My daughter fell ill. We came to know it as measles. She breathed heavily and gasped a lot like an adult. The disease increasingly made my daughter suffer. I stopped working altogether because I couldn’t focus. I lost my appetite and kept worrying. I decided to take our daughter to the health centre right away. She stayed at the hospital for 10 days. Her condition gradually improved and she recovered. I was extremely happy. If I hadn’t taken her there, she could have died." Daniel, proud father of one-year-old Mekdes in Ethiopia. In recent months, UNICEF helped health workers in Ethiopia to overcome the challenges of COVID-19 and safely vaccinate more than 14 million children against measles.

Social workers are essential. Social workers are a lifeline. Social workers are hope.

column43: UNICEF is set to lead the global supply of COVID-19 vaccines in what may be the world's largest and fastest ever operation of its kind. With several vaccine candidates currently showing promise, we're preparing to procure doses for 92 countries which will be supported by the international community, along with 80 wealthier countries that will fund their own supplies. In a global crisis, the only way forward is global solidarity. That's why we're working together with partners like Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance, to ensure a COVID-19 vaccine is affordable and accessible for all. This must truly be a people's vaccine.

column43: We are ready for an immense new challenge: to lead the global supply of COVID-19 vaccines and help end the worst stage of this pandemic. UNICEF is already the world's largest single buyer of vaccines for other diseases like measles and polio, procuring more than 2 billion doses on behalf of nearly 100 countries every year. It's thanks to you - generous UNICEF donors and partners - that we now have the experience and expertise to meet this moment.

column43: One of the main ways that COVID-19 spreads is through respiratory droplets that people expel when they talk, sing, cough or sneeze. While research is ongoing, we now know that the virus can be spread by people not showing symptoms, meaning some people can be contagious and not even realize it. That is one of the reasons why physical distancing is so important in places where the virus is widespread. But it’s not always possible to keep a distance from others in crowded public places, which is why the use of a fabric mask is recommended to protect each other. But remember, a mask alone won’t prevent the spread of COVID-19 – we all need to continue practicing physical distancing and washing our hands frequently.

column43: “I can’t remember when I last went to school, and now that my school is destroyed I have no idea when I will be able to go again.” Ten-year-old Abdulkarim is able to play games and learn at a makeshift UNICEF child friendly space but it’s not the same as school. His teacher was injured in the Beirut blasts but he remains hopeful. “Maybe when my teacher gets better, we will study together again.” Amid the challenges caused by the explosions and COVID-19, UNICEF is urgently working to repair and rebuild schools, support remote learning and distribute education supplies. Help us get children like Abdulkarim learning again by donating today → https://uni.cf/beirut_expl_f:=:https://www.unicefusa.org/?form=LebanonEmergency

column43: Jean and Sandrine are holding their twins close in Rwanda, practising ‘kangaroo care’ to help their newborns grow up healthy. The first month of a child’s life is both precious and fraught with risks. In these first 28 days, babies face a higher risk of dying than at any other stage of their childhood. A staggering 7,000 newborns died every day of the past year, almost all from preventable causes. Now, the COVID-19 pandemic could make things worse. Some women are afraid of giving birth in a hospital for fear of infection, while many newborns are being denied access to quality care because health services are overrun. Ensuring every family has access to trained health workers is the key to keeping mothers and newborns alive and healthy.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Dhiraj is in good hands. Support from a trained health worker and care from a loving mother will give her a strong chance of growing up healthy in India. That’s our goal for every child, everywhere. Yet, if global trends continue, an astounding 48 million children under the age of five will die from mostly preventable causes within the next ten years. That’s more than the entire population of Spain. And if the COVID-19 pandemic continues to disrupt life-saving health services for children, that number will only rise. We take heart in the fact that child deaths have almost halved in the last ten years, proving that progress is possible. And we find hope in the knowledge that the future is ours to determine together. Let’s choose a world where every child survives with quality care.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: There were no trending stories. No breaking headlines. No climbing death toll on the nightly news. But before the world had ever heard of COVID-19, some 14,000 young children around the world were already dying every day - mostly from preventable and treatable causes. Now, the pandemic is disrupting children’s health care and threatening to push that tragic toll even higher. As governments rightly invest to protect communities from COVID-19 infection, we cannot neglect the millions of children at risk of dying from birth complications, pneumonia, diarrhoea and vaccine-preventable diseases. They may not make the front page but we refuse to let them live and die out of sight and out of mind. Every one of these children shares an equal right to survive with quality health care. It’s up to all of us to make it possible.

column43: “If they start shooting when I'm returning back from school, I immediately call my mother to come,” says 16-year-old Aliona in eastern Ukraine. “We have no lessons specifically dedicated to how to behave during the shelling. But everyone already knows.” Aliona has been studying at a local newspaper office since her school was burnt down during shelling. “I like this school, although it is very upsetting that our old school was never renovated." Attacks on schools are attacks on children’s right to an education. Today on International Day to Protect Education from Attack, UNICEF is calling on governments to sign the Safe School Declaration, a commitment to protect every child’s right to an education during armed conflict. 📸 UNICEF Ukraine

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: We have come so far. Since 1990, the number of children who die before their fifth birthday has fallen by almost 60%. But this year, the COVID-19 pandemic has caused alarming disruptions to health checkups, vaccinations and other critical services that save children’s lives. We are standing at the precipice of a new crisis, facing the very real possibility that child deaths could rise for the first time in three decades. It’s time for urgent action to resume essential health care and keep every child alive.

This is a moment for global solidarity - for the international community to support life-saving immunizations and trained health workers for every child.

column43: Five-year-old wish kid Ben is always eager to give everyone he meets a friendly fist bump, a high five or a wave. His positive attitude has not only helped him make fast friends with his cardiologists, nurses and physical therapists, but it’s also helped him persevere, despite his congenital heart condition. One of Ben’s favorite hobbies is playing and watching basketball, and thanks to our friends at Isagenix® & ISA Foundation, his wish for a sport court came 1! Ben’s sports court is now his favorite place to be, especially because it’s painted in his favorite basketball teams’ colors! Thank you to Isagenix for providing ongoing support to Make-A-Wish that makes wishes like Ben’s possible! Make-A-Wish Greater Virginia

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: In 2019, the world’s children had a better chance of surviving to age five than ever before. Immense progress is possible - but it can also be lost. Our recent survey of 77 countries revealed that more than two-thirds are struggling with disruptions to health checks and immunizations for children because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Only swift and determined action from the global community will save children’s lives and protect decades of progress.

"I hope the whole country can fight the pandemic well so that we can see our teachers and friends again." As children, teachers and parents do their best under exceptional circumstances, UNICEF is calling for urgent investment in education - particularly for girls, children with disabilities and those affected by poverty. 📸 UNICEF Viet Nam - Quỹ Nhi Đồng Liên Hợp Quốc

column46: DINNER GAMES 20 QUESTIONS: FAMILY MEMORY One person thinks of family memory. Then everyone has to ask questions to try to figure it out: Did it happen during holiday? A meal? Was it funny memory? Were there any friends involved And so on, until you either guess the memory, or reach total of 20 questions. This game also helps preserve memorable experiences by remembering and talking about them together! THE FAMILY DINNER PROJECT ORG

column43: We all agree that a child’s chances in life should not depend on where she is born. But the risk of a child dying before she reaches the age of five is 56 times higher in Somalia than in Slovenia. This is not a world we need to accept. Decades of hard work and investment in health care have proven that progress is possible. We know what works to save children’s lives. So let’s get it done.

column43: Alla has been doing her dream job, teaching children, for over 30 years. But the last few years have been harder than she could have ever imagined. “Our team never stopped teaching children, even under shelling,” says Alla, who works at a school near the ‘contact line’ in eastern Ukraine. “When they started firing, my students and I ran to hide. When it became safe, we sat down at desks again.” During heavy fighting and the COVID-19 lockdown, Alla has used every opportunity to stay in touch with her students. “When the COVID-19 pandemic started, we transferred all the classes to Zoom,” she says. “For me, one of the most important effects of the lockdown was that I was able to master the computer. But in addition to online lessons, I always tried to explain any difficult questions by phone, meet with parents and help with the installation of education software.” Although Alla has risen to the challenge, mathematics has been particularly difficult to teach online. She hopes the new school year will be easier. “I advise colleagues to always hope for the better and convey their optimism to children. You need to put on a mask, measure your temperature, use an antiseptic and come to students in a good mood. This year it is especially apparent how the children missed school, each another and their teachers during the lockdown. We missed them too."

column43: With help from our friends at Subaru of America, Inc. and Make-A-Wish New Jersey Antonio's wish to have a virtual shopping spree was granted as part of the annual Subaru #ShareTheLove Event. Antonio was diagnosed with cancer in April, but has remained positive throughout treatment. For Antonio and his family, a wish-come-1 has brought joy during a difficult time. 💙 You can help bring joy to a child, like Antonio, by purchasing or leasing a new Subaru through January 4th. $250 will be donated to your choice of participating charities, including Make-A-Wish. Learn more: wish.org/subaru:=:https://wish.org/subaru
column48:
Earlier today, our friends at Subaru of America, Inc. escorted by Camden County Police Department safely delivered the wish of eight-year-old Antonio from Camden, New Jersey. Antonio’s heartfelt wish came as a complete surprise today – a fleet of over a dozen Subaru vehicles from Subaru of America, Lester Glenn Subaru of Toms River and Subaru of Cherry Hill, led by the Camden County Police Department escort, drove past his home, each car carrying gifts that Antonio wished for during his virtual shopping spree just a few weeks prior. 
 
Antonio has struggled with his cancer diagnosis, news that devastated him and his family in April. He doesn’t fully understand his illness, but he has faced his challenges with a positive attitude and a smile, even when he must stay overnight at the hospital. For Antonio and his family, a wish-come-1 brings joy during a difficult time.
 
Antonio’s wish was granted thanks to the support of Subaru and the annual Share The Love Event. Since becoming a national charity partner beneficiary in 2011, Make-A-Wish America has received a total of more than $23 million in donations through the Subaru Share the Love Event. These funds have allowed more than 2,500 children nationwide to experience the power of a wish. Today, one more child was added to that number, as Antonio joined the Make-A-Wish family.
 
Check back soon for more on Antonio’s wish! 🌟 #WishGranted

column43: “COVID-19 was beyond my imagination. Our world tour was canceled, all our plans went awry, and I became alone. I looked up but couldn’t see the stars at night.” RM⁣ ⁣ Last week, BTS returned to the UN General assembly. In their message to young people, they shared the personal struggles they have faced during the pandemic and what has helped them overcome feelings of hopelessness, sadness and frustration. ⁣ If you are struggling right now, know that processing feelings looks different for everyone. Some people express it through art or acts of kindness, while others talk to friends and family. What’s important is that you do what feels right for you. Head over to our website for more tips on taking care of your wellbeing during COVID-19.⁣

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: We are safer and stronger when we act together. This year, the COVID-19 pandemic has revealed our deepest vulnerabilities and our greatest strengths. In an interconnected world, we have seen how an infectious disease can spread across borders, cities and streets with devastating speed. And we have discovered that our connections are also a powerful force for good - that everyday acts like washing our hands, wearing a mask and keeping distance can save our neighbours' lives and ultimately shape the course of this crisis. We share one world, and our health depends on each other. This simple truth must guide our work to ensure COVID-19 vaccines are accessible and affordable to every country. That's why UNICEF is working in solidarity with partners, governments and health workers on a historic new plan: to supply more than 2 billion doses of COVID vaccines in the next year. Success will depend on all of us.

column43: No matter what happens over the next few months, doctors and hospitals will likely be busy this winter caring for COVID-19 patients. Getting a flu shot is an easy and inexpensive way to help protect their valuable time and resources, from PPE to testing supplies. And it can help keep your family and community healthy! The CDC estimates that 46,000 children were hospitalized with the flu during the 2018-2019 flu season. We can make sure that number is much lower this year. 💪 💉

column43: "We are poor among the poorest that is how I feel and describe our current life. My father works as a construction worker but on the basis of no work no pay. That is why my mother helps to find ways by doing laundry work to have food to eat. I go to school with an empty stomach and just eat my lunch in school since there are school meals to be served." Nicole Homecillo Nicole is a 12-year-old from Cebu City in the Philippines. She often goes to school hungry because her family does not have enough to eat in their home. Still, thanks to donors like you, she receives lunch meals at school through our school feeding program. For only $15, you can make food possible for vulnerable children like Nicole and provide them with lunch for an entire school year. column43: At the very heart of who we are and all we do for children is this essential truth expressed so fervently by our founder, Eglantyne Jebb: humanity owes the child the best it has to give. That’s why we’re passionately committed to giving the world’s children what every child deserves— a healthy start in life, the opportunity to learn and protection from harm.

column43: "We've exercised, we've played...we've practiced handwashing." David Moreno, a UNICEF Education Officer has just delivered education and hygiene supplies to a rural school in Mérida State, Venezuela. As the country grapples with COVID-19, safety is a big part of school reopening. In addition to notebooks and footballs, David has brought students soap and other handwashing equipment. "Now over 100 children will be ready to start their school year," he says proudly.

column43: Loneliness affects us all from time to time but it’s something we rarely want to talk about. The COVID-19 pandemic has brought with it huge amounts of uncertainty and stress, and will affect people in different ways and at different times. In these unusual times, try to go easy on yourself and take time to look after your mental health – more than you might have previously. Intentionally engage in activities that make you feel calm and relaxed, and try to stay away from sources of anxiety, for example you could consider limiting your screen time if you think this is making you feel more stressed or isolated.

column43: "I'm happy for two reasons. First of all we have a new school. It's so nice! It's big and clean. When it's hot outside, we don't feel the heat, and when it rains we stay dry." Nine-year-old Marie in Côte d'Ivoire, like many, is incredibly happy to be back at school - and what a school she has! Her school is made out of recycled plastic bricks. "Before in the bamboo classes we couldn't even see the billboard because of the dust. I like to come to school more than before. We even have electricity and light inside. I felt very sad when they closed schools [due to COVID-19]. That's why I feel so happy again we could come back this week. I feel good here. Later I want to become a teacher. Teach in a school like this!"

column43: It is so important that we work together to provide hope for families struggling during these strange days. We are proud to partner with organizations like OPERATION COMPASSION-A Ministry of Blessings to help those affected by Hurricane Laura this week.
column48:
Operation Compassion: Before the Storm . . . You are Not Alone

Hurricane Laura was upgraded to a cat 1 storm with the potential to intensify further to cat 3 prior to landfall early Thursday morning. The weather forecast is expecting Hurricane Laura to hit somewhere between Cameron, LA and Port Author, TX given its current track. Evacuations are taking place along a large swath of the Gulf Coast and low lying areas just inland.

Operation Compassion is currently contacting our disaster relief partners getting resources in place in response to this hurricane. Feed the Children, God’s Pit Crew, Mercy Chefs and others are involved in the planning and preparations. Several semi-trucks of bottled water, food, cleaning supplies, hygiene products and many other products necessary to help sustain survivors are staged and ready to be shipped.

We are also contacting disaster relief sites in the area to be prepared to help immediately after Hurricane Laura moves further inland. Operation Compassion will stay with the track of the storm providing relief help until the hurricane is no longer a threat.

Operation Compassion will need your help to meet the requests for assistance. Financial partners are vital for our continued relief efforts. It is easy to give online, by phone (debit/credit card), or through the mail. Become a financial partner with Operation Compassion! Before the storm, YOU are not alone!

Online Donations:
www.operationcompassion.org:=:http://www.operationcompassion.org (givedirect button)

Call your donations to:
423.728.3932

Mail your donations to: 
Operation Compassion
114 Stuart Road, NE PMB 370
Cleveland, TN 37312

column43: Have you felt lonely or isolated during COVID-19? You're not the only one. Months of physical distancing and seemingly endless lockdown measures, school closures and other sustained pressures have taken a toll on our mental health.⁣ ⁣ Reflect on exactly when you are feeling lonely and what seems to exacerbate it - like social media, grief, lack of sleep or stressful relationships. Lonely doesn’t just have to mean being alone – you can experience feelings of isolation even when surrounded by friends and family.⁣ ⁣ Take time to process your feelings. Set some time aside to disconnect from your phone or laptop, set-up a regular time for exercise, talk through your feelings with a friend or close family member, or try clear your mind with meditation. Loneliness is something that affects all of us from time to time but it’s something we rarely want to talk about. Seek additional support if you think your loneliness might be being caused or intensified by other conditions, such as depression or anxiety. Together, we can support each other through this.⁣ ⁣

column43: Find ways to stay connected with others during the COVID-19 pandemic, either online or IRL. Set up a video call with friends and family or if restrictions in your country allow, organize a physically distanced activity. If there is something troubling you so much that you feel you can’t tell anyone, consider reaching out to a trusted adult like a teacher or someone else in your community, or a helpline who might be able to offer support or refer you to other services. Managing your mental health can be a battle, but it doesn't need to be one you face alone.

column43: If the COVID-19 pandemic or post election day results are anxiety-inducing for grownups, it can be downright scary and stressful for children. We’re sharing these drama-based relaxation exercises to help kids (and adults) de-stress. 👇
column46: Stress Buster: Turtle This exercise releases muscle tension. Pretend you are a turtle going for a slow, relaxed turtle walk. Oh no, it's started to rain! Curl up tight under your shell for about ten seconds. The sun's out again, so come out of your shell and return to your relaxing walk. Repeat a few times, making sure to finish with a walk so that your body is relaxed. Repeat, making sure to finish with a walk. Save the Children.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: "Dear girls around the world, My whole life, I've been led by women through storms. To me, they've always been a symbol of undying grace and resilience, and I know I'm not the only one that has had the pleasure of witnessing this. You deserve the same grace from the world. You deserve to dream. You deserve to run free with no limitations. We deserve the world to show us kindness. We deserve the world to show us what it means to feel safe. To show us the love that it has been shown by women. International Day of the Girl not only celebrates girls around the world, but recognizes the struggles we face on a daily basis. The future I dream about is one where no girl is left behind. Your dreams deserve devotion. Your dreams deserve to become 1. It’s not impossible, we just don’t want it enough. Basic human rights should never be a debate, and often, girls find themselves in positions where theirs are arguments. A future I dream of is one where girls aren’t only told that they are incredible, they are given the opportunities and resources to become just that. A future where girls step up to the podium to introduce themselves as presidents, lawyers, engineers, professors, artists, and award winning actresses and models. We are more than capable. The world just needs to want equality bad enough! Kamogelo." YES! All around the world, girls like Kamogelo are demanding their rights. The world is listening. Voices of Youth
column46: "YOU DESERVE TO DREAM. YOU DESERVE TO RUN FREE WITH NO LIMITATIONS." KAMOGELO, 18, SOUTH AFRICA VOICES OF YOUTH

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “To my 14-year-old self, You just turned 24 and wow, where has the time gone. Soon you’ll be 30, 50, then 75. What will you achieve? Your plans will change. Do not get frustrated with your failures, as they are an opportunity to learn. Do not feel discouraged since there is no established path for you to walk on. You are creating it yourself. The way a person evolves is amazing. And how a girl grows into a woman is outstanding. Let your passions change as you learn. Your goals will be shaped by your passions and trust me, they will only get better. Your actions, your emotions, your courage, your passions, your thoughts, and the opportunities you seize will guide you to become the role model you will be. There is still a long way ahead of you, even ahead of me. As a girl and as a young woman, it is scary to think about it. But if your dreams don’t scare you, are they even worth pursuing? Yes, you are a girl. One girl turning into a woman. Feel honored to be one. Women are the epitome of “man”-kind. We are strong, we are smart, we can make our voices be heard, our actions be seen. Do not let anyone tell you otherwise. You represent humankind and every exceptional aspect of it. Be proud of the girl you are and the woman you are going to be. I believe in you, so believe in yourself. Sincerely, Alexandra, your 24-year-old self.” This Day of the Girl join Alexandra in writing a letter or giving a shout out to a girl who inspires you: a young leader, a family member, an influencer, your best friend or even yourself as a teen! @voicesofyouth
column46: "BE PROUD OF THE GIRL YOU ARE AND THE WOMAN YOU ARE GOING TO BE." ALEXANDRA, 24, UNITED STATES VOICES OF YOUTH

column43: "It was very cold and lots of snow, but we didn’t quit until we were finished. People were calling to see if due to the weather if we were going to cancel. Our response was we are a veteran’s organization and our soldiers don’t get the day off. Neither did we! [It] was not only a 1 blessing to our community, but to all our volunteers. We went home wet/cold, very happy hearts." Nancy Everett-Salsman, VFW Post 382 - El Reno Another incredible event we were honored to be part of. The VFW Post 382 - El Reno served veterans within their community with food, hygiene items, and toys for their families. The event provided joy for not only our service men and women, but also the volunteers who served them. ❤️ 👏 #ThankYou #ShareYourGood #NoHungerHolidays

column43: “Our first child, Henry, was stillborn at 38 weeks. It’s almost impossible to describe the overwhelming grief caused by the unexpected death of your child, but I believe it to be the single most devastating event that any parent can experience. He was here for but a moment, yet his memory will live on in our hearts forever. I want the world to know that talking to bereaved parents about their babies that have died doesn’t remind us that they died – we haven’t forgotten. It reminds us that they lived, and that you remember them – and that is a precious gift.” Chris, UK.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “As a health worker, providing support to mothers and families who experience stillbirth is not an easy task. I really feel deep sadness from the mother and her family, but as a health worker I try to give positive encouragement that makes the mother able to get through her mourning period.” Istiyani, midwife in Indonesia.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “My son Caleb was stillborn when I was 37 weeks pregnant. I want the world to know that he existed. He was and is my son. Prevention must start with raising awareness and educating women about the risks of stillbirth. Simple things like educating women on the importance of monitoring fetal movement can help prevent stillbirth. Awareness can also help… women feel comfortable sharing their stories if they desire so.” Jill, USA.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “After losing my baby, I was faced with so much psychological trauma. Stillbirth could be prevented if only we know the cause. In my own case it was caused by hypertension which could be well managed if detected earlier. There must be good antenatal care, and support for women who have experienced stillbirth. Mothers should not be blamed for their situation.” Oyele, Nigeria

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “Witnessing all kinds of parental love, both in life and death, is a position that no midwife should take for granted. Holding space for parents during this time of grief and loss is a part of midwifery that creates a lifelong impact on parents and families experiencing stillbirth and loss. I do not take it lightly, and I implore other midwives to lean in to this difficult portion of the role. Parents will thank you for it.” Katrina, Australia

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “The death of a baby shakes the very foundations of one's world. You mourn the beautiful baby you love and were so excited to welcome into the world; you juggle the enormity of grief and sadness with the everyday tasks of living; you try to make those around you understand the significance of this massive loss. Communities around the world need to provide compassionate and sustainable information and support to parents who experience this profound and unimaginable loss.” Vicki, New Zealand.

From an 18-year-old filmmaker sharing stories of violence in Senegal, to a 17-year-old robotics champion in Afghanistan, teen girls are leading the way.

column43: “I want people in rural areas to have the same opportunities as people in cities.” 16-year-old Belen is a councilwoman in Ecuador advocating for indigenous rights. “I imagine a world with respect for different cultures, with respect for men and women…I dream of equity."

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: When 19-year-old Sebabatso suspected she had COVID-19 in South Africa, she walked to the local clinic, where she found a pregnant woman waiting alone in the punishing heat. The woman had come for a prenatal visit. “But the nurse told her it happened in the morning and she had to come back tomorrow. Imagine the time she wasted. What if she lives far and has no money for taxi fare?” This experience is what inspired Sebabatso to create an app that allows hospitals to directly communicate with patients, giving them critical information about their health care without forcing them to wait hours or even days in line.

column43: World Food Day has arrived in unprecedented times. After decades of progress, COVID-19 is threatening to unravel life-saving gains in children's nutrition. Physical distancing, school closures, transport restrictions and lockdowns are all taking a toll — not only on children’s daily lives, but on their access to healthy food. To stop this pandemic from spiralling deeper into a children's crisis, we must support them with the nutrition they need survive today and to thrive in years to come. This is our moment to reimagine the future of food - to build systems where healthy diets are affordable and accessible to every child, without exception.

column43: We are losing too many babies before they take their first breath. Globally, almost 2 million are stillborn every year - each a profound loss for an expecting mother. The trauma of giving birth to a stillborn baby is enormous, yet the death of an unborn baby remains a taboo in many cultures. Too often, women and families endure this tragedy in silence. We must break the stigma and give bereaved parents the full support they deserve. By talking more openly, we can help families cope and build the awareness we so urgently need to help save lives.

column43: “As usual, she tried to find the heartbeat – she couldn’t find it. I went blank. All this was a dream, right? The doctor confirmed that our son was no more. We broke down, we were confused – nothing made sense. We went to our car and sat there, blank – not talking, sweating and feeling cold at the same time; we were devastated! He will always be a part of us and we definitely miss him a lot.” “First time mothers should be educated on the danger signs of most common conditions and how to respond to them. We should have honest and open discussion surrounding pregnancy. Let there be a medium to tell our stories so that other people never go through this.” Lonce, Kenya.

column43: A COVID-19 vaccine should be universal - a people’s vaccine that is accessible to every country. But there is a very real risk that ‘vaccine nationalism’ will deprive this critical tool from the poorest communities with the weakest health systems. Let’s be clear: protecting wealthy countries alone will not allow life to return to normal. As long as the coronavirus continues to spread anywhere in the world, it is a threat to us all. We must act together, as nations united.

column43: When Mohammad was 14 years old, he picked up a strange object near his school in Afghanistan. It changed his life forever. The object he found was an explosive. When Mohammad tried to open it, the item exploded, wounding him and his cousin. After days in a clinic, he learned he lost his hand. "When I realized my hand was amputated, I got upset," Mohammad told us. "I became sad, wishing I hadn’t picked up that round [object] and brought it home so that my hand would not have been amputated." Mohammad wants peace in Afghanistan, and to study to become a doctor when he grows up. He is currently enrolled our “Education Cannot Wait” program where children can catch up on their schooling. "There should be peace and security and the lives of thousands of children should not be ruined." #StopTheWarOnChildren

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Any vaccines that are approved for use by the World Health Organization (WHO) must go through rigorous tests and clinical trials to prove they are safe and effective in controlling disease. COVID-19 is no exception. Right now, the global community is accelerating the search for coronavirus vaccines with an unprecedented investment of funds and scientific expertise. UNICEF is preparing to rapidly deliver supplies as soon as they are approved by WHO. We will never lose sight of the first priority that drives this whole endeavour: your health and safety.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: A vaccine has to arrive at the right temperature to remain effective and save lives. That’s why UNICEF has spent years investing in a ‘cold chain’ - a network of temperature-controlled transport that spans the globe. As the world’s largest distributor of vaccines, we are now preparing to meet one of the world’s greatest challenges: to safely deliver 2 billion COVID-19 vaccines within the next year and help end the worst of this pandemic.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: The world is waiting for safe, effective and life-saving vaccines for COVID-19. As UNICEF prepares to supply some 2 billion doses to essential workers and vulnerable groups over the next year, we must also be clear about the reality ahead: vaccines alone will not end this pandemic. It will take time to produce and distribute enough doses for widespread protection throughout the world. We will still need testing, tracing and treatments. We will each need to continue the safe habits that have so quickly become a fact of life: physical distancing, handwashing and wearing a mask. Vaccines work. But to control this pandemic, we must use all of these life-saving tools together.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Children’s survival and wellbeing depends on dedicated health workers being able to work safely in the community day after day. That’s why the first doses of COVID-19 vaccines should be prioritized for nurses, doctors and other essential workers. Our health depends on their health.

column43: Ayan was sent to be cared for by her aunt Saynab, but when she arrived, she was malnourished. “She was really very weak, I thought she might die,” said Saynab. Thanks to our mobile health clinic, she's getting the medical attention she needs to survive. Children like Ayan deserve to grow up healthy and strong. Donate now to help us fight child hunger around the world. http://ow.ly/ntXm50CpBJ2:=:https://support.savethechildren.org/site/Donation2?idb=697093211&df_id=1620&mfc_pref=T&1620.donation=form1&cid=Social_Network:Facebook:1X_GAF:Scus_1x_Post1:112120

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: UNICEF is set to lead the global supply of COVID-19 vaccines in what may be the world's largest and fastest ever operation of its kind. With several vaccine candidates currently showing promise, we're preparing to procure doses for over 180 countries on behalf of the COVAX Facility.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: A vaccine doesn’t deliver itself. It relies on dedicated health workers crossing mountains, rivers and deserts. It takes innovative tech and sheer grit. And we’re proud to make it possible every step of the way, supporting over 100 countries to keep vaccines safe and effective along a ‘cold chain’. This unbroken line of fridges and coolers allows vaccines to stay at the right temperature, even in the planet’s hottest and toughest places. Soon, the cold chain will become more important than ever. We’re strengthening this network to ensure COVID-19 vaccines can be delivered quickly and safely throughout the world.

column43: This girl is proudly showing her purple finger in Nepal - a sign she has just been vaccinated for polio. We can all be proud too. Vaccines are one of the greatest achievements in modern medicine. They have reduced the scourge of polio by 99% since 1988. They have eradicated smallpox from the face of the planet. And soon, they could be a critical tool for helping to control the worst phase of the COVID-19 pandemic. History shows that vaccines work. Our future can show it once more.

Children in low-and lower-middle-income countries have lost nearly four months of schooling since the start of the pandemic. In high income countries, it's just six-weeks. Being out of school has far reaching consequences for children's education, safety, health and wellbeing. We're calling on governments to reopen schools with all possible safety measures, invest in remote learning and catch-up classes, and protect education funding.

column43: Behind every healthy community, there is a protective shield of vaccines that keeps children safe from disease. When enough of our neighbours, friends and colleagues are vaccinated, we build up our collective immunity and stop infections from spreading. The same will be 1 for COVID-19 when vaccines become widely available in years to come. We’ll each need to vaccinate for ourselves, our families and our communities, because our health depends on each other.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: We are safer and stronger when we act together. This year, the COVID-19 pandemic has revealed our deepest vulnerabilities and our greatest strengths. In an interconnected world, we have seen how an infectious disease can spread across borders, cities and streets with devastating speed. And we have discovered that our connections are also a powerful force for good - that everyday acts like washing our hands, wearing a mask and keeping distance can save our neighbours' lives and ultimately shape the course of this crisis. We share one world, and our health depends on each other. This simple truth must guide our work to ensure COVID-19 vaccines are accessible and affordable to every country. That's why UNICEF is working in solidarity with partners, governments and health workers on a historic new plan: to supply more than 2 billion doses of COVID vaccines in the next year. Success will depend on all of us.

column43: No mother should have to watch her child starve. But Maria did. In the midst of a food crisis in Niger, Maria and her husband, a farmer and water merchant, were working long hours to put food on the table. But when there wasn’t any water to sell at the market and their crops were withering to dust, life was a daily struggle. With food and water shortages worsening, Maria’s 14-month-old daughter Fatchima grew frail and started getting sick after she began drinking water from the village well. As the weeks went on and Fatchima’s health worsened, Maria knew that her daughter’s survival was in jeopardy, so she took a brave step. She used a full day of her husband’s meager pay to hire a man with a motorcycle to drive them over treacherous dirt roads to reach the nearest Save the Children malnutrition unit. It was a decision that saved Fatchima’s life. Fatchima weighed just 11 pounds when she reached the malnutrition unit. Children 7 to 18 months old in Niger and other developing countries are most susceptible to acute malnutrition and waterborne illness, which makes them most vulnerable to rapid dehydration, infections and death. Thankfully, Fatchima’s story has a happy ending. She spent eight days at the malnutrition unit, growing stronger every day. When we checked in with Fatchima and Maria a year and a half later, Fatchima was strong and Maria was looking to the future. “We will send her to school, so that after her studies she can become a nurse or a teacher.” Today, 10 children around the world die from preventable causes like malnutrition every single minute. But you can help us create more happy endings like Fatchima’s. Please, donate if you can. To celebrate the giving season, your gift will be matched 3x to help three times as many children in need. Thank you. ❤️

CORONAVIRUS INTERNATIONAL – APPEAL FOR DONATIONS
Installing 60 handwashing stations, raising awareness among more than 20,000 families on what to do in case of contamination, distributing hygiene kits to 5,560 households—this is the work currently being carried out by our partner NGO Terre des hommes in Myanmar’s Yangon slums. 🇲🇲😷
🗣 Here, where people who are already susceptible are at the greatest risk and the recommended social distances are impossible to comply with—this is where we need your support the most. Thanks to your donations, our partner NGOs are providing concrete help to the most vulnerable. 

The coronavirus is having the worst impact on the most vulnerable.
Let’s make a difference together.

column43: Meet 17-year-old Volodymyr Charushyn, from Ukraine, an athlete and amateur chef. Volodymyr lost his hearing ability due to an early childhood trauma. He felt isolated, unable to communicate freely with children and adults outside of his specialized educational institution. So together with his friends, he developed a unique technology that teaches children how to use a dactyl [manual] alphabet to talk to non-hearing people. “My friends and I have long dreamed of breaking this barrier, this wall of misunderstanding and alienation between the society and the people who cannot hear,” he says. Their invention, a set of wooden cubes where each letter is represented by a hand gesture and objects that have the letter in their name, was installed in his hometown’s public spaces.

column43: Ahmed and his family live in a one-room house, made of rocks, wood, and pieces of worn clothes in a middle of an almost-abandoned mountain in Yemen. The way to their house is bumpy and hard-to-reach, at least an hour's walk from the nearest market or health facility. Five years of relentless war has had a devastating impact on families like Ahmed's. "Prior to the war, we had jobs, there was source of income, but now we don’t," he said. Often, his children only have a piece of bread to eat throughout the day. When his daughter Hanan became malnourished, Ahmed made the difficult, hour-long journey to a health center supported by Save the Children. Our staff provided her with immediate treatment and followed up with a regular supply of nutritious food. In the midst of raging conflicts, a changing climate, and a global pandemic, levels of child hunger are rising. Millions of hungry and malnourished children need urgent support. This #GivingTuesday, you can help children like Hanan survive, so they can grow up healthy, educated and safe. Your gift will be matched 3x to help three times as many children in need.

column43: "I love reading and I read every day." 📚❤️✨ In honor of International Day of Persons with Disabilities we're celebrating the exceptional children we serve — like 7-year-old Sophia! Sophia's parents attended inclusion and literacy workshops organized by Save the Children's Mureke Dusome program in Rwanda which teaches parents how to best support their children with disability to learn and read at home. With the literacy skills she developed, Sophia exceeded her goal of reading one book per month, now reading one every day! “I am urging parents of children with disabilities to cut out any discrimination against these children because they are capable," Sophia's dad said. "We have to listen to them and this can only lead them to achieve so much more." We couldn't agree more. ❤️

column43: Meet Juliette! 👋 Juliette is a Youth Volunteer with Disability supporting Save the Children's Mureke Dusome program in Rwanda. She conducts workshops with parents to help change harmful practices and attitudes toward children with disabilities. Juliette told us that in the past she didn’t feel valued in her community because of her disability. But thanks to the active role she is playing in society to change negative attitudes towards people with disabilities, all that has changed! "If I can lead a dialogue of 30-40 parents who are attentively participating in my awareness sessions and I influence them to later put the tips I shared into practices that makes me proud!" An amazing example of the power of youth to effect change in their communities! 💪❤️

column43: There are three things that make Anab happiest: seeing that her children are well nourished, able to go to school and have a chance at the bright future they deserve.⁠ ⁠ The family lived a nomadic pastoralist life before they were displaced because of a drought In Somalia. Daily life in their village now is tough. Getting food or water is very expensive and there are no schools or health facilities nearby.⁠ ⁠ Save the Children was able to provide the family with a sack of rice, beans, wheat flour and cooking oil. Before, they were only able to have two meals per day. Now, since Save the Children has helped them, they have three meals a day.⁠ ⁠ Although hardships remain, Anab is hopeful for a brighter future for her kids.⁠ ⁠ You can help. If you can, please consider a donation to help make change for children this holiday season. ❤️

column43: Nine-year-old Abdul has been surrounded by conflict for most of his life. In his short nine years, he's already had to come to terms with seeing his grandmother, brother and sister all injured in the fighting in Afghanistan. Abdul and his family had to flee their home because of the conflict. Although life is safer in their new town, work is scarce and there is very little food to go around. But more than anything else, Abdul misses school. Currently, he is enrolled in Save the Children’s ”Education Cannot wait” program, that helps children who have been displaced by the conflict catch up on the schooling they have missed. Abdul hopes to continue his education so that he can fulfill his dream of becoming a doctor.

column43: Severe cases of COVID-19 have left tragic numbers of people fighting for breath as pneumonia takes hold of their lungs. But pneumonia is not a new emergency. It already kills more children than any other infection, claiming around 800,000 young lives every year. For these children, medical oxygen can be the difference between life and death. We have seen what the world can do when it rallies to help people with COVID-19. Now, we must do the same for children facing the forgotten epidemic of pneumonia.

column43: At six months old, Randy is battling pneumonia - an infection that leaves children fighting for breath as their lungs fill with fluid. Every year, 4.2 million children like Randy need urgent access to medical oxygen to survive. Now, the global need for oxygen supplies has become more critical than ever, as the COVID-19 pandemic sweeps the world. We are determined to rise to both of these challenges. So far this year, UNICEF has delivered life-saving sources of oxygen to over 90 countries.

column43: This device is a life-saver for people with severe cases of COVID-19 and for children battling pneumonia. It’s an oxygen concentrator - a portable unit that takes in air from the environment, removes nitrogen and produces a continuous source of oxygen for patients who are struggling to breathe. We’re proud to supply solutions like this to over 90 countries.

column43: Last year, measles cases surged to their highest level in 23 years. Now, COVID-19 has disrupted immunization campaigns in 26 countries and left more than 94 million children at risk of missing their measles vaccines. As we respond to one disease, we cannot turn our backs on another. It’s time for urgent action to safely resume measles vaccinations and protect children from the looming threat of new outbreaks.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Musbashir is about to receive a measles vaccine in Afghanistan, and it couldn’t come at a more important time. Last year, measles claimed the lives of more than 207,000 people - most of them children. That’s an alarming 50% jump from 2016. Now, COVID-19 has interrupted vaccination services throughout the world and we’re deeply concerned about what that means for millions of children who will be left unprotected. We won’t let one crisis lead to another. UNICEF is calling on country leaders to restart immunizations and prevent major epidemics of measles from taking young lives.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Before the world had ever heard of COVID-19, we were facing the spread of another infectious disease. Last year, cases of measles leapt to the highest levels since 1996. Thankfully, for this virus, we already have a safe and effective vaccine that has proven its life-saving power for generations of children. We simply need to use it. UNICEF is encouraging the global community to safely restart immunizations, and we are inviting parents to continue regular visits to your health worker. Don’t wait - vaccinate today.

column43: It has never been more clear that our health rises and falls together. This year, we have endured terrible losses and been inspired by the strength of our communities. We have each done our part to wash our hands, wear a mask and keep our distance because we know that stopping COVID-19 will take all of us. The same is 1 of other infectious diseases that remain a serious threat to children. Last year, global cases of measles reached their highest level in 23 years. We know what works to stop the virus: the proven power of vaccines. But to build up our collective immunity and prevent deadly outbreaks, we need 95% of our community to receive the measles vaccine. Our health relies on each other.

column43: Every day, nine year-old Michelle carries her one year-old sister Gloria on her back to a health center in the Democratic Republic of Congo to receive food supplements. Gloria suffers from malnutrition. "My sister has become really skinny because we do not eat well," Michelle told us. "We only eat once in the morning and in the evening, we go hungry." "I carry my sister on my back [to the health center]. I just wanted to do it for her to get healthy again. I would like to eat twice a day, in the morning and at night." The COVID-19 pandemic has put the world on the brink of a hunger crisis. Even before the pandemic hit, many communities struggled to provide children like Michelle and Gloria with enough healthy food, with one in three children under five suffering from malnutrition. Without action, millions more children will be at risk of suffering irreversible health damage due to a lack of nutritious foods. You can help. If you can, please consider donating to help children like Michelle and Gloria get the nutritious food they need to survive and thrive.

column43: "The day of the hurricane, I was afraid."⁠ ⁠ Twelve-year-old Mirna is one of the hundreds of thousands of children impacted by Hurricanes Eta and Iota in Nicaragua. ⁠ ⁠ “The saddest thing is that [the storms] destroyed my house and left us with no place to sleep,” Mirna explained. “Although my house is very small and in poor condition, at least I had a house to live in.”⁠ ⁠ The hurricanes not only partially destroyed Mirna’s home. They also severely damaged or destroyed her family’s crops, leaving the family wondering how they will earn an income. ⁠ ⁠ Save the Children is supporting children and their families impacted by the hurricanes by delivering food, safe drinking water, blankets, supplies so families can protect themselves from COVID-19, and providing children in shelters with items like crayons and coloring books, so they can play and process their feelings.⁠ ⁠ "With this package that Save the Children gave me, I feel very happy," said Mirna. "We had no food and now, with this package, we will be able to eat."

column43: Salma was just 20 months old when she became very ill. ⁠ ⁠ “Her eyes had no strength, she couldn’t even open her eyes,” her mother, Barey, said. ⁠ ⁠ With difficulty breathing Barey rushed to⁠ her local Outpatient Therapeutic Program where she was referred to the Stabilization Center supported⁠ by Save the Children, in the Somali Region of Ethiopia. ⁠ ⁠ Struggling for breath, Salma was given a feeding tube in her nose and was put on medication. Just two days⁠ later, she was showing signs of improvement, and after eight days Salma was sitting up by herself and eating. ⁠ ⁠ When we met her again five months later, she was a very different Salma. ⁠ ⁠ “She is recovering so well!” Barey told us. “When I brought her in, she was very sick. But now she is eating again.”⁠ ⁠ Looking toward the future, Barey has big dreams for her baby girl. “I hope my daughter will become a doctor, to treat other little children just like her.” ❤️❤️❤️

column43: The pandemic has forced us to stay on top of various numbers. But what about the number of children who've had their education disrupted by COVID-19? At their peak, COVID-19 school closures affected almost 1.6 billion students - hitting vulnerable children hardest. To prevent a lost generation, governments must reimagine education for every child. This means reopening schools with all possible safety measures - and keeping them open. Governments must also focus on supporting children most likely to have lost out on education because of the pandemic, including girls, children affected by conflict, children with disabilities, and children living in rural communities or without access to the internet.

column43: Five years of relentless war has had a devastating impact on families like Ahmed's. "Prior to the war, we had jobs, there was source of income, but now we don’t," he said. Often, his children only have a piece of bread to eat throughout the day.⁠ ⁠ When his daughter Hanan became malnourished, Ahmed made the difficult, hour-long journey to a health center supported by Save the Children. Our staff provided her with immediate treatment and followed up with a regular supply of nutritious food.⁠ ⁠ In the midst of raging conflicts, a changing climate, and a global pandemic, levels of child hunger are rising. Millions of hungry and malnourished children need urgent support.⁠ ⁠ This holiday season you can help children like Hanan survive, so they can grow up healthy, educated and safe. Tap the donate button below to make change for children.❤️

column43: Exhausted, confused and a long way from home. This girl has fled with thousands of others from brutal violence in Tigray, Ethiopia to a refugee camp in Sudan. On arrival, families face overcrowded camps amidst a COVID-19 pandemic. UNICEF is on the ground, working to reach refugee children with safe water, nutrition and psychological support. More than anything, the children of Tigray need peace. We are calling on all parties to the conflict to adhere to international humanitarian law and to protect children from harm.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: This young girl is recovering from her injuries on a makeshift stretcher after an attack on her compound in #Tigray, Ethiopia. UNICEF is deeply concerned about the safety and wellbeing of children affected by ongoing military operations, particularly against the backdrop of poverty, COVID-19 and rising malnutrition rates. As we scale up our response for children in Sudan and Tigray, we’re calling on all parties in the conflict to protect children from harm and urgently grant unconditional access to humanitarian organisations.

We’re calling on governments to increase and maintain funding for emergencies. We must pull together as a global community and reimagine a safer world for every child.

column43: “My name is Gabriel Heredia, I’m 17 and I’m an activist for people with disabilities and inclusive development, from Trelew, Argentina. The [COVID-19] pandemic has been a time of a lot of personal and collective learning. I personally went through a lot of negative states of mind: loneliness, boredom, anguish, fear, lack of motivation; but as time went by, I discovered that meeting and talking to others in the same state motivates me. Listening to other people’s experiences makes me realize that we are always surrounded by people; that I am not alone, that we are not alone.” From Voices of Youth - our community for youth, by youth.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: This little boy’s family has fled brutal violence in Tigray, Ethiopia to a refugee camp in Sudan. As the conflict enters its third week, UN Agencies are warning of a full-scale displacement emergency – with around 4,000-5,000 refugees arriving in Sudan every day. In addition to the threat of COVID-19 in crowded camps, we are particularly alarmed by malnutrition rates, with acute malnutrition in Tigray increasing by one third between 2019 and 2020. UNICEF is on the ground, working to reach children with safe water, medical supplies, nutrition and psychological support. While we protect children, we’re calling for all parties to the conflict to abide by their obligations under international law to protect children and humanitarian workers too.

column43: ⁣Meet 18-year-old Somaya, the captain of the ‘Afghan Dreamers’ robotics team, a group of 25 girls who built a robot for detecting landmines. She was recently included in the BBC 100 Women list of 2020 and she'd like to become a role model for young Afghan girls who wish to pursue careers in science and technology.⁣ When Afghanistan’s first case of COVID-19 was reported in her province of Herat, Somaya and her all-female robotics team set to work on a low-cost ventilator to treat coronavirus patients. "Our focus shifted since the outbreak of COVID-19, [we] decided to build devices that can help the health system in the country fight the COVID-19 virus." Somaya's message to girls around the world? “As girls, we must continue to share our success stories with other girls, families and governments through different communication channels. This is empowering to many other girls out there.”⁣ Congratulations, Somaya!⁣ From Voices of Youth - our community for youth, by youth.
