column43: The world is waiting for safe, effective and life-saving vaccines for COVID-19. As UNICEF prepares to supply some 2 billion doses to essential workers and vulnerable groups over the next year, we must also be clear about the reality ahead: vaccines alone will not end this pandemic. It will take time to produce and distribute enough doses for widespread protection throughout the world. We will still need testing, tracing and treatments. We will each need to continue the safe habits that have so quickly become a fact of life: physical distancing, handwashing and wearing a mask. Vaccines work. But to control this pandemic, we must use all of these life-saving tools together.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: To help support your teen’s mental health during COVID-19, work together to set up new routines and achievable daily goals. You could fit in home chores around school work or set a target like getting homework done before dinner. Adolescence means independence! Try to give your child the appropriate time and space to be on their own. Needing space is a normal part of growing up. Find a few ways you can support and encourage your teen to take breaks (from schoolwork, housework, or other activities they may be working on) to do things they enjoy. If your teen feels frustrated, work with them to brainstorm some solutions to problems. Try not to take over and tell them what to do.

Together, we can provide a healthier future for every child.

column43: Jenty, 11-months-old, is smiling and playing again after treatment for malnutrition in Yambio, South Sudan. “It started with her having diarrhoea for several days. She couldn’t keep down what we were giving her,” says her mother, Margret. She took Jenty to the UNICEF-supported nutrition centre where she was diagnosed with severe acute malnutrition. “Jenty didn’t have much energy back then. She was given ready-to-use therapeutic food, and very quickly she got her energy back. You can see how much she likes it.” We can’t let COVID-19 roll back decades of progress in child nutrition. Thanks to your generous support, UNICEF aims to treat 6.3 million children like Jenty for severe acute malnutrition next year.

column43: “Children here have already been through so much and they still lack basic services. The last thing they needed was to be forced away from school and friends.” 22-year-old Osama is part of a team of UNICEF-supported volunteers providing education for young people affected by conflict and COVID-19 school closures in Homs, Syria. His team writes stories, composes songs and creates fun activities, all centered around child rights, COVID-19 prevention and mine risk education. “I’m overwhelmed to see how happy children and parents are with what we are doing. We’ve succeeded in helping ease some of the pressure they’re under.” With the help of dedicated staff, volunteers and partners, UNICEF aims to reach 93.3 million children in emergencies with education next year.

column43: Today marks the beginning of Black History Month, an annual celebration of the achievements, influences and legacies of Black Americans. At Make-A-Wish, it is only through our mosaic of different cultures, perspectives and experiences that we can grant life-changing wishes to every eligible child –including wish kid Zayden. Zayden, who was fascinated with outer space, wished to blast off to Saturn in a red rocket ship. Through virtual reality, his wish came 1 in 2017. For Zayden and many children like him, his wish was made possible by Make-A-Wish and the belief that nothing is impossible. Thanks to Black pioneers who have shaped U.S. history, including Guion “Guy” Bluford, the first Black American in space (1983) and Mae Jamison, the first Black woman in space (1992), wish kids like Zayden are empowered to dream big. This month, we are proud to celebrate the contributions that Black Americans have made to the success of our nation and our mission. 🚀 Learn more about Zayden’s wish at wish.org/zayden:=:https://wish.org/zayden. Make-A-Wish Georgia

Knit or crochet hats for newborns in your local NICU 9. Provide masks to first responders, grocery store workers, and other essential workers 10. Volunteer at an animal shelter 11. Offer to pick up your elderly neighbor's groceries 12. Help someone who has a flat tire 13. Bring coloring books and supplies to a children's hospital 14. Bring in someone's trash cans or paper 15. Thank or give a gift to your mail carrier

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: When Razan was eight years old, she was seriously injured when a piece of shrapnel hit her eye as she was fleeing violence in Hodeidah, Yemen. ⁠ ⁠ As the heavy shelling continued, her father Samir was forced to continue their journey for safety, and only had time to wrap a shawl around Razan's head. ⁠ ⁠ When they made it to safety, Samir rushed his daughter to the hospital where they were met by a member of Save the Children's team. Razan was referred for emergency surgery and later for specialist treatment. ⁠ ⁠ After two long surgeries, Razan's eyesight was saved. ⁠ ⁠ "I'm happy I'm not going back to the hospital and I'm happy that I'm alive," Razan told us. "I wish the war stops, so I can get back to Hodeidah, our home."⁠ ⁠ Learn more about what it's like for children living in Yemen: http://ow.ly/F5xm50D3Iu2:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/charity-stories/life-for-children-growing-up-conflict-yemen?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Yemen:Scus_Lp_Post1:011021

column43: It’s Lincoln’s birthday, and we couldn’t help but think of one of anti-hunger’s biggest advocates. His name is Larry, and he’s an Abraham Lincoln impersonator. Larry visits about a hundred schools a year, teaching the history of Lincoln’s era and the Civil War, while also delighting schoolchildren with his stovepipe hat, frock coat and historical speeches. After a successful 30-year career in the insurance industry, Larry loves being able to give back to his local community, and he’s a big advocate of Feed the Children. How can you and Larry continue to better the world for children? Give today and #LoveYourNeighbor this February: https://bit.ly/394hMNl:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?2081.donation=form1&df_id=2081&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=love-your-neighbor&utm_campaign=love-your-neighbor&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_content=love-your-neighbor #FeedtheChildren #ZeroHunger

column43: “Despite all the security challenges we face, we continue.” Niciima, a 20-year-old social worker, goes door-to-door in Mogadishu, Somalia to raise awareness about COVID-19. “During the first week, I was a bit worried, but I am not afraid to do the right thing. We all dream of the wellbeing of our society and that’s what really matters.” As humanitarian workers like Niciima selflessly work to support families in emergencies, they are increasingly coming under fire. UNICEF is calling for humanitarian workers to be protected at all costs. They must feel safe and supported as they reach some of the world’s most vulnerable children.

column43: By the time Brandon was 5, he had been through several surgeries, long hospital stays and hundreds of doctors’ visits because of his heart condition. But it’s his wish to have his bedroom turned into a fire station that stays with him to this day. “My wish gave me memories I will treasure for the rest of my life. It’s something that all wish kids get to hang onto for a lifetime,” Brandon, now 23, said. February is American Heart Month, and a wish can give kids facing critical heart conditions the emotional and physical strength to keep fighting against their illness –and to instill hope for the future. Donate today at wish.org/donate:=:https://secure2.wish.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=donate_now&chid=100-000 to help grant more life-changing wishes like Brandon’s. Make-A-Wish Arizona

column43: Feeling uneasy or worried? Anxiety can be overwhelming - especially during COVID-19 - but there are things we can all do to keep it from taking over. Go back to the basics.⁣ ⁣ When basic needs like sleeping and eating well aren't met, we can easily feel out of sorts. People sometimes consume caffeine or self-medicate with substances like tobacco and alcohol to help ease strong feelings of anxiousness, but these will only make you feel more anxious in the long run.⁣ Look after your physical health this week by focusing on getting a good night's sleep, eating well and doing some kind of physical activity - and see what a difference it can make.

It’s not just about wearing a mask, it’s about taking good care and working on it every day.”⁣⁣⁣ Yana is a 22-year-old HIV activist from Ukraine, founder and Chair of Board of Teenergizer, a youth-led organization. “Sometimes it is enough to talk about painful things to people close to us, but this is not always the case, and not everyone has such an opportunity.”⁣⁣⁣ Mental health affects how we think, feel and act. But it’s still stigmatized and support is underfunded in almost every country.⁣⁣⁣ To give children and young people the care they need and deserve, governments must increase investment in mental health services.⁣⁣⁣

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Béhé, 17, left his hometown of Bangolo in western Côte d’Ivoire about six years ago. After living on the streets of the capital, Abidjan, he travelled earlier this year to the town of San-Pedro. COVID-19 cases were just being reported in the country, and the resulting curfews made it even harder for those living on the streets to find enough food or money to survive. “At first, I wasn’t afraid of the disease itself, but I knew it would have an impact on us,” Béhé says. “During the curfew, I was often chased by armed men in the streets.” Béhé says it was a relief when he was approached by a social worker, who invited him to a UNICEF-supported child protection centre. “They gave me everything I needed to be able to protect myself against COVID-19,” he says. “I’m also getting counselling, and food and other support. The strict routine and numeracy classes at the centre have taken a bit of getting used to, but I feel like I have hope here. And I’m happy that I’m able to learn things that can help me in the future.” Interested in mechanics, Béhé wants to open his own garage one day. “I dream of my parents seeing me happy and being proud of me.”

column43: Binef, 18, originally from Mali, moved to Abidjan to start a new life, selling items like water and paper tissues to make ends meet. But when the pandemic hit, the man for whom Binef worked could no longer afford to pay him. With no income and no place to go, Binef was forced to sleep under a bridge. He began to notice more people around town wearing masks because of COVID-19, which scared him. So when an adult introduced him to a UNICEF-supported child protection centre, Binef jumped at the chance. At the centre, Binef was given face masks and a hygiene kit. Just as important, he received much-needed comfort and support. “I was happy when I arrived here. I’ve received so many words of encouragement,” he says. Binef says the centre has taught him some important lessons about respect and discipline, and that he has also been learning to read and write. “Things are going well, and I feel confident.” Binef wants to learn about auto mechanics. “I want to become a great mechanic,” he says, “and to one day go back to Mali and open my own garage.”

column43: This Valentine's Day, we’re spreading love by sharing the remarkable bond between wish kid Shanya and her Make-A-Wish Central and Western North Carolina volunteer, Barbara. From the moment she met Shanya in 2019, Barbara sensed they had a special bond. Although she suffers from a nervous system disorder and is nonverbal, Shanya is an expressive teenager with the “most beautiful eyes,” according to Barbara. Upon discussing different ideas for her wish, the idea of a wish to have a puppy instantly lit up Shanya’s face with a huge smile. It was clear that having a Maltipoo puppy named Fluffy was her heartfelt wish. "It was just one of those moments where I said, 'This is why I love this organization... [and] give Make-A-Wish my time. It is worth every minute that I spend here to get to see this,'" Barbara said. You can spread love (and puppy kisses!) and help grant life-changing wishes like Shanya’s this Valentine’s Day by giving at wish.org/donate:=:https://secure2.wish.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=donate_now&chid=100-000.

column43: Our plan to deliver vaccines for COVID-19 will be the largest operation of its kind in history. In 2021, we’re aiming to provide up to 2 billion doses to 92 lower-income countries - that’s up to 850 tonnes of supplies every month. It’s an unprecedented challenge and only bold, collective action will make it a success. That’s why we’re working hand in hand with shipping, airline and logistics leaders. Together, we can deliver these life-changing vaccines quickly, safely and fairly.

column43: Eight-month-old Suha was suffering from acute malnutrition when we met her in a health center in Taiz, Yemen. ⁠ ⁠ Suha's mother Mariam has two children and due to the conflict in Yemen, getting enough food for her family is a daily struggle. ⁠ ⁠ "The situation in this country is not good," Mariam told us. "Because of the war there are no jobs. My husband used to have a job but now he is unemployed."⁠ ⁠ Mariam brought Suha to a health center supported by Save the Children in a district in Taiz governorate. There, the health workers examined her, taking her measurements and weighing her to check for malnutrition. ⁠ ⁠ Once diagnosed, Mariam was provided with nutritional supplies for Suha, and she was also given advice on how to best feed her.⁠ ⁠ "My hope for the future is to have our own house and for my husband to get employed, my kids to be comfortable and food to be at their reach," Mariam said. ⁠ ⁠ Sadly, Suha and Mariam's story is not unique. We estimate more than 10 million children in Yemen will require life saving assistance in 2021. Learn more: http://ow.ly/D4bi50DhEal:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/about-us/media-and-news/2021-press-releases/60-million-children-across-eight-of-the-biggest-humanitarian-crises-need-help-to-survive?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:SCUS_Lp_Post1:012621

"The pandemic affected us very much, economically and otherwise. Our son looks very different today compared to when he was malnourished," says Erick's father, Floro. In Guatemala, 1 in 2 children suffer from chronic malnutrition. With families seeing less money coming in, and major disruptions to health services, COVID-19 threatens to make a bad situation worse. UNICEF is working with governments to invest in nutrition and healthcare, particularly to improve the chances of the world’s most vulnerable families.

column43: “The aftermath of that severe February storm is still very real,” said Michelle Faist, Head of Corporate Affairs, StarKist Co. “It’s an honor to provide much-needed food for families in Texas who are still recovering. We appreciate our strong partnership with Feed the Children to make it happen, and will continue to work together to help families in need across the country.” The winter storms in February are still wreaking havoc on communities in Central and South Texas. Families are still living without water, electricity, and food. Seeing the desperate need communities are still facing, our amazing partners at StarKist have stepped up and donated over $25,000 worth of product, which is a whopping 20 pallets! Thanks to their generosity, our partners at Vision Inspired Church and Belknap Ministries will be able to provide nearly 2100 families with the supplies they need. #ThankYou #Partners #FeedtheChildren

column43: Breakfast, it's the most important meal of the day. According to the Food Research & Action Center, more than 12.6 million low-income children participated in the School Breakfast Program on an average school day during the 2019-2020 school year. Proper nutrition throughout the day is important for children so they can have the ability to have better grades, higher self-esteem, more positive social interactions, and decreased risk of behavioral problems. You can provide hungry kids with the nutrition they need to have better days in the classroom, and right now, your gift goes 8x farther to provide the food and essentials necessary. Donate now and provide hope for a brighter future: https://bit.ly/3rjQVUl:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?1400.donation=form1&df_id=1400&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=nationalnutritionmonth&utm_campaign=national-nutrition-month&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_content= #NationalNutritionMonth #NationalSchoolBreakfastWeek #FeedtheChildren

column43: The conflict in Afghanistan changed Shogofa's life forever. Her family used to have "everything," she told us. They had a home and Shogofa enjoyed playing with her friends. But the conflict took it all away. Her brothers were killed and her school was forced to close after an attack. So, the family decided to leave. Now they live in a tent in a small dusty plain, sleeping and living in one tent with her mother, father, sisters and remaining brothers. Shogofa attends Save the Children’s Child Friendly Space in the camp, a safe place where children can play and receive psychosocial support. She dreams of becoming a doctor so she can treat sick people and hopes she and her family can one day return home. 9.7M children in Afghanistan will need life-saving support in 2021. Learn how you help 👉 http://ow.ly/Omo650DmjrB:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/afghanistan?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:013121

column43: “This is where my house was. You can see all our belongings still lying here." 12-year-old Vaseva, after a category five cyclone hit her island home in Fiji just before Christmas. "I am sad that I lost so much but I’m happy that everyone on my island is safe. We will be working together to build everything.” Her grandfather, Napolioni has lived on the island for fifty years and has never seen a cyclone so devastating. “We [the villagers] had dug up a well after the cyclone to collect rainwater as our source of drinking water was destroyed in the cyclone. We don’t even boil the rainwater. That’s how thirsty we all are. Even all the coconuts are finished now," he says. “I am so happy to see UNICEF and the government giving us water and other important things. We really needed this for our daily living, especially the water.” UNICEF is on the ground, working with the government and local partners to provide safe water, medical equipment and education supplies as communities rebuild and recover.

column43: “I know how it is when you don’t got nobody to help you.” - Danicia A single mom struggling at the edge of poverty with limited means, Danicia has few options. There are no grocery stores in her neighborhood. The dollar store is the only place within walking distance to buy food for her four-year-old daughter Amelia, and it doesn’t carry fresh produce. Danicia and parents like her were facing impossible choices even before COVID-19 struck. The struggle to keep food on the table has only gotten worse in the face of new economic hardships. You can help single parents just like Danicia. Right now, your donation goes 8x farther to provide food and essentials to struggling parents working to make ends meet and put food on their children's plates. Donate now: https://bit.ly/3bryGXy:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?1400.donation=form1&df_id=1400&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=multiplier&utm_campaign=multiplier&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social Learn more about Danicia's story: https://bit.ly/3p0tKgZ:=:https://www.feedthechildren.org/our-work/stories/danicia-and-amelia/ #SingleParentsDay #FeedtheChildren #DefeatHunger

But in our pop-up child friendly space, she was excited to play and her father was relieved to see her smile again. Six months later, Hala is playing again at home, and starting to rebuild her childhood. ❤️

column43: Barbara Wax, a senior midwife, was one of the first to receive a COVID-19 vaccine at Brockton Neighborhood Health Center in Massachusetts, USA. “I have been very concerned about contracting COVID given my age,” said Barbara, who has been a midwife at the centre for 18 years, “and the fact that I lost my husband to COVID. My adult children do not want to lose a second parent in a short period of time!” For Barbara, a vaccine means peace of mind, and the ability to see family. “I am looking forward to... worrying a little less about contracting COVID, and seeing my children and grandchildren, hopefully in the spring.” Midwives like Barbara have risked their own health to deliver babies throughout the pandemic. To safe-guard them as they care for mothers and newborns, we must prioritize vaccines for health workers.

UNICEF calls for urgent action to bridge the digital divide and prioritise the reopening of schools.

column43: Ummay tragically lost her first baby to pneumonia. She believes her lack of maternal health care contributed to her baby’s death. When she became pregnant again, Ummay attended Save the Children’s health facilities in Cox's Bazar regularly for check ups and now has a healthy 18-month-old daughter called Jakia. “After giving birth to my daughter, she received all the vaccinations at the right time," Ummay told us. "Because of the vaccinations, she has not had any severe diseases since her birth. She is perfectly well and healthy." We have eight health posts offering primary health care services in the Rohingya refugee camps, including maternal, newborn, and child health to ensure every child survives and thrives. #VaccinesWork💉

column43: Asia is a high school student in Tanzania and a member of the children's council where she campaigns for children's rights and advocates for positive change in her community. She has visited schools to educate children about their rights and uses her voice to urge the government to strengthen policies and laws to punish those who have been abusing children. According to Asia, being in the children's council has made her very strong and confident, giving her the knowledge and skills to achieve her dreams. "My dream is to become a child rights lawyer," Asia told us. "I am looking forward to my bright future as well as a bright future for many other girls in my community."

Bit by bit, vaccines will become available to more people and start to build a protective shield for whole communities. When we choose to vaccinate, we’re not just protecting ourselves and our families - we’re doing our part to build a safer, healthier future for all.

column43: The COVID-19 pandemic brings with it feelings of anxiety, stress and uncertainty — and they are felt especially strongly by children of all ages. Though all children deal with such emotions in different ways, if your child has been faced with school closures, cancelled events or separation from friends, they are going to need to feel loved and supported now more than ever. Take a moment today to ask: 'How are you, really?' ⁣

column43: This radio has been keeping 14-year-old Angures Buba learning during COVID-19. Accelerating access to the internet and providing every child with the necessary learning tools and technology is critical. This is a once-in-a-generation opportunity to reimagine education.

While the circumstances differ from patient to patient, Laura refers each eligible child to Make-A-Wish. “I think a wish is so important for the child’s sake,” Laura said. Thank you, social workers, for helping give children a piece of their childhood back! Make-A-Wish Arizona

column43: We are so thankful for our new partnership with College Fresh for helping to fuel our mission of Feeding Minds and Bodies. College Fresh’s dedication to providing our Feed the Children Teachers Stores with school supplies from their Drives and monetary donations helps ensure teachers receive the resources they need. Teachers spend an average of $750 of their own paychecks on providing resources to students in their classrooms each year. Because of this added expense that teachers take on, we offer our Teachers Store, giving free supplies to help them and their kids have a successful school year. Our Teachers Store requires help from partners who are committed to education and nutrition, just like us. Thank you College Fresh! #FeedtheChildren #Education #ThankYou

We must bridge the digital divide.

column43: Our history proves the power of vaccines. Smallpox killed 300 million people in the 20th century alone but it was eradicated in 1980 thanks to vaccinations like this one in India. As UNICEF prepares to supply 2 billion doses of safe and effective COVID-19 vaccines to people at high risk and essential workers across the world, decades of experience and science are on our side.

column43: 8-year-old Andrea smiles while she colors. 😀🖍️✨ As part of our child-protection activities in Peru, we delivered kits with coloring books, stickers, crayons, and an address book of local and national health and protection services. The coloring book aims to help girls and boys understand, in a friendly way, how to recognize possible dangers of sexual assault, and encourage them to seek support from their trusted adults in the event of any danger or doubt.

column43: Last week, Make-A-Wish Southern Florida granted 5-year-old Chloe's wish to have a Cavapoo puppy. Chloe's new pal Cooper became her new best friend instantly! 🐶

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Severe storms have battered families displaced by conflict in northwestern Syria. As harsh winter weather sets in, more than 2 million people have fled violence, sheltering in flimsy tents and destroyed or unfinished buildings. Just this week, a six-year-old boy reportedly died when a wall built around his tent collapsed on top of him amid flooding and snowfall. UNICEF is working tirelessly through COVID-19 to provide life-saving support to children, but we cannot do it alone. We need funding. We need better access. Most importantly, the violence must end.

Rian and her community is just one example of how your donations help create brighter futures for children in the U.S. and the 9 countries we serve in. #FeedtheChildren #DefeatHunger Feed the Children-Asia

column43: “I want to be a teacher when I grow up. I want to help people who can’t read and write, because the ability to read is the best feeling in the world.” 11-year-old Mohammed and his family have been displaced from their home in Yemen due to intensified conflict and as a result, he has been unable to attend school. His mother heard about education classes that Save the Children runs in their neighborhood and decided to enroll Mohammed—within a few months he was able to read and write which helped him get accepted into a formal school. His parents are very proud and believe education will provide him with a better future.

column43: After frigid temperatures and winter weather battered Texas, children and families along the U.S. southern border are in need of urgent assistance. For newly arrived families living in transit shelters, the situation is life-threatening. Shelters have limited or no power. Some are without water. Hundreds of families, many with young children, are struggling to keep warm and stay healthy. Our team is responding to meet the urgent needs of kids and their families. Learn more about our response below and please consider donating if you can: http://ow.ly/xYWx50DFSHd:=:https://support.savethechildren.org/site/Donation2?4890.donation=form1&df_id=4890&mfc_pref=T&cid=Social_Network:Facebook:1X_USP:Scus_1x_Post1:022121

column43: Feed the Children is dedicated to ending childhood hunger both at home and abroad. In 2020, thanks to donors' kindness, we were able to provide 36 million meals internationally. In the U.S., we distributed more than 79.2 million pounds of food and essential items to children and families who needed them. Learn more about us and the countries we serve in! https://www.feedthechildren.org/our-work/ #FeedtheChildren #DefeatHunger

column43: This little girl has fled conflict in Ethiopia's Tigray region, seeking safety in Sudan. Thousands of new arrivals, many weak and exhausted, are arriving each day. UNICEF is caring for children through psychosocial support, safe water and malnutrition screening. As more refugees stream into crowded camps, the spread of COVID-19 and other diseases remains a major concern. For those children trapped in Tigray, the impact of violence is deeply troubling. To reach all children with life-saving support, we need access, now.

Kathy is a single mom and she would do absolutely anything to make sure her son gets enough to eat. Together they have a small garden to supplement the nutrition they need and she takes on as many work shifts as she can to provide Eddy with the food and school supplies he needs. Learn more about Kathy and Eddy's journey here: https://bit.ly/3fbFURQ:=:https://www.feedthechildren.org/partners/wf/n-three/kathy-and-eddys-story/index.html #SundayStories #FeedtheChildren

column43: Growing up is tough. Growing up in poverty, without resources & support, is even tougher. That's why our social & financial literacy program serves to empower youth by boosting their self-confidence & independence. "Being part of the program has really helped me to boost my self-esteem. I know that I mean a lot, I know that I can make a difference in the world." - Aaron, 18, Zambia Thanks to Aflatoun International's program curriculum, youth like Aaron are learning financial & social skills that will help them for the rest of their lives.

column43: "I was fortunate and grateful to get the first dose of my COVID-19 vaccine today," UN Secretary-General António Guterres said on Thursday after getting his shot in New York City. "We must get to work to make sure the vaccine is available to everyone, everywhere. Our world can only get ahead of this virus one way — in solidarity. None of us are safe until all of us are safe. My thanks to all the essential and frontline workers who have risked their own health to protect and support their communities. Solidarity is crucial in our global fight against the pandemic." Are you receiving a COVID-19 vaccine - or know someone who is? Post a picture with the v-sign and tell us why it's important to you. ✌ for #Vaccinated 📷: UN Photo / Eskinder Debebe

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Emmanuel is from a small village in Uganda. He and his family live in a grass hut on a homestead surrounded by eucalyptus trees. Education is not of high importance in their village because of the distance students had to travel to school. The community he lives in has one primary water source where children and adults ran the risk of contracting water-borne diseases like typhoid and Bilharzia. And many citizens have never had access to education about proper food and nutrition. Thanks to donors' gifts, Emmanuel's community has been provided the resources needed to have more success within their lives. The programs our Feed the Children - Africa team set up, he and his family have access to clean water, education access closer to town, and a new water source set up at their Primary School. #ThankYou #International

Join us in thanking child life specialists like Allison, who has referred more than 160 patients to Make-A-Wish Illinois. column43: Asia is a high school student in Tanzania and a member of the children's council where she campaigns for children's rights and advocates for positive change in her community.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ She has visited schools to educate children about their rights and uses her voice to urge the government to strengthen policies and laws to punish those who have been abusing children.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ According to Asia, being in the children's council has made her very strong and confident, giving her the knowledge and skills to achieve her dreams.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ "My dream is to become a child rights lawyer," Asia told us. "I am looking forward to my bright future as well as a bright future for many other girls in my community."

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Meet Snayder, a sweet, energetic little boy from San Carlos in Honduras. Snayder lives with his grandparents, where his grandfather works as a farmer and day laborer and his grandmother raises chicken. Most of what they grow and raise, they keep for food for their tables since they do not make enough money to have more, but when times are more difficult they sell their extra chickens. Thanks to the kindness of donors, Snayder is able to receive meals at school at our school feeding program provided by our team in Latin America, relieving some of the stress about not having enough food. And thanks to the additional meals, he is able to have enough energy to get through a successful school day and still play with his friends afterwards. #FeedtheChildren #LatinAmerica #SchoolMeals

Black and Hispanic children have been disproportionately impacted — they are twice as likely as white children to experience hunger in America. column43: Being online can present lots of great opportunities to connect, learn and share what’s important to you especially during COVID-19, but it comes with challenges too. We all have a part to play to make online spaces feel safe and supportive. 👇⁣ ⁣ Use social media for good, by sharing positive and supportive content and messages with your friends, family and classmates. For example, you could reach out to let someone know you’re thinking of them or add a positive comment on a post they've shared. If you find yourself responding to a message or post with something negative, pause and consider whether you could frame it in another way or have an in-person conversation instead. If you see or receive messages or content you consider to be bullying or abusive, you should block and report it. Words matter, and it’s important to think carefully about what we share. Make someone's day by spreading love, not hate.

column43: Teachers all over the world have been going above and beyond to support their students and to help them continue learning by whatever means possible during COVID-19. Many have embraced new ways of teaching, including online, over radio, television or hand-delivered materials. UNICEF is calling for teachers, along with child protection and other social service workers, to be prioritised to receive the COVID-19 vaccine - after frontline health personnel and high-risk populations. Safeguarding vital services for children and young people is key to safeguarding their future.

Still, thanks to donors who have stepped and shared their kindness, she receives the nutrition she needs while her mother can attend programs to educate herself further. Thanks to parents and health workers, the vaccine is protecting children against an infectious disease, which was once the leading cause of childhood paralysis worldwide.

column43: What's your favourite thing about social media and the Internet? Here are a few of ours 👇 ⁣⁣ There are loads of great online tools and content that can help support all aspects of your mental health and wellbeing. From meditation apps to help you relax and focus, to platforms that help you develop your sense of identity, stay connected and support one another.⁣⁣ There are also online learning tools where you can try something new, like drawing or yoga, which can build new cognitive and creative skills, as well as online exercise classes to help you stay healthy and unwind.⁣⁣ Try and find positive and motivating content and creators to follow, like athletes, singers, home cooks, authors or young people speaking up about issues you care about.⁣ 🖌️: Ellie Zahedi Voices of Youth

column43: When was the last time you checked privacy settings on all your social media profiles?⁣ As we spend more time online, especially during COVID-19, it's important to stay safe online. Be careful when signing up to apps and services online, especially providing your full name, address or photo. If you are concerned about something you have seen or experienced online, you should talk to a trusted adult like a parent or teacher; report the incident on the platform in question (remember to take a screenshot as a record); and look up online safety helplines and mental health services in your country for more support.⁣

Globally, more than 750 million young people aged 15-24 years old have no internet at home. Bridging the digital divide is more urgent than ever before.

column43: Important reminder: Not everything you see online is real, even from your friends, but how it affects you is. How does social media make you feel? Do you check your phone first thing in the morning to learn about breaking news or out of pure habit? Does reading the news online make you feel informed or stressed? Does seeing photos of your friends at a party make you feel good or envious? Identifying why you are online and how it makes you feel can help you set the right personal limits on how much time you spend on social media and other apps. While it’s not always realistic to unfollow or report everyone that intentionally or unintentionally affects your emotions negatively, especially during COVID-19, you could try muting or limiting content from accounts that are not making you feel good.

column43: The lines between the online and offline worlds can feel increasingly blurred, especially during COVID-19, making it hard to live in the present moment and satisfy our innate need for human contact. Do you ever find yourself interrupting what you are doing so you can post it on social media or tapping through your friend’s stories rather than calling to see how they are doing? It’s important to try and switch off and take a break from social media every now and then and spend time with friends and family in real life too, where it’s safe to do so. Try and set yourself realistic goals. You could try not going online for the first hour of the day or just before bed. Activities such as meditation, going for a walk or calling a friend will help provide a similar stimulation but leave you feeling more focused and relaxed.

As COVID-19 continues to disrupt learning, getting students – especially the most vulnerable - back to school as quickly and as safely as possible must be a top priority.

column43: Santiago is a bright, 13-year-old from Venezuela who has a hearing impairment. ⁠ ⁠ School is one of the few places where he can communicate freely and feels understood, but due to the COVID-19 pandemic, he has not been able to attend school for almost 11 months. ⁠ ⁠ “What makes me feel sad, worried, and scared is not being able to return to school. I like school. People understand me there. When I can't go to school, I cry.”⁠ ⁠ To help children like Santiago keep up with their studies during the pandemic, we’re working with a local partner to provide school kits – which contain things like notebooks, pens and pencils, and craft supplies – and learning materials focused on literacy and numeracy.

Teachers film themselves giving lessons in the bus and send them to their students via WhatsApp. Ten-year-old Aya loves keeping up with her lessons and dreams of becoming a doctor so she can help the Syrian people.

column43: “Since our school is closed, I have been passing my days mostly studying at home and spending time with my mother. But I miss my school, my friends and playing in the school field. I want our school to open as soon as possible,” says 10-year-old Arifa from Bangladesh. Despite increasing evidence that schools are not the main drivers of the COVID-19 pandemic, and despite overwhelming evidence of the impact of school closures, many countries have opted to keep schools closed - some for nearly a year, continuing to disrupt the education of millions of children and young people worldwide. Without urgent action, the learning crisis will only deepen and the effects could be felt for generations to come. No effort should be spared to keep schools open or prioritise them in reopening plans.

column43: 8-year-old Andrea smiles while she reads with her mom.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ As part of our child-protection activities in Peru, we delivered kits with coloring books, stickers, crayons and an address book of local and national health and protection services.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ The coloring book aims to help girls and boys understand, in a friendly way, how to recognize possible dangers of sexual assault, and encourage them to seek support from their trusted adults in the event of any danger or doubt.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “I have moved schools almost seven times in the past ten years of my school life, and my biggest fear has always been cyberbullying. The unknown is still a scary thing, but with the introduction of technology, the impact and effect of the “unknown” can become worse. I’ve seen my friends be bullied on the internet, through text, and other social media.” TIME’s first-ever Kid of the Year, 15-year-old Gitanjali Rao, is using her experience and love of technology to reimagine a safer internet where children's mental health is prioritised and protected. “I like to spread the message of kindness and its importance in our community. I like to use technology to solve problems in our community and hopefully inspire others to be kind to self, community, and environment,” she says. Gitanjali is working on an internet service called Kindly that aims to help detect and prevent cyberbullying, using the latest developments in Artificial Intelligence technology. The internet is always evolving – and internet safety needs to evolve with it. From Voices of Youth – our community for youth, by youth.

During the virtual wish Morgan and the guys talked about their favorite episodes, pranks and even learning how to drive since Morgan just turned 16! Thank you for creating hope for Morgan, Impractical Jokers!

column43: 15-year-old Peter lives in a refugee settlement in Uganda. He dreams of a future in politics and tells us “I want to be a member of Parliament so that I can build a smart house.” Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and school closures, Peter’s education came to a halt but we’re doing whatever it takes to keep kids learning. With support from local government, we're providing learning materials and solar lights to help children continue studying even when it's dark. #SaveOurEducation

column43: This is Katherine, 10, from the Philippines. Katherine was enrolled in our Nutrition Program after discovering she was underweight for her age. "[The Nutrition Program] helped me to become healthy & not sickly...My favorite part of the program is the healthy food like malunggay (moringa), pechay (cabbage), tomatoes, eggplant & many others." - Katherine By focusing on key areas such as nutrition rehabilitation, oral health, hand washing & safe water, our program is helping children & youth establish & reinforce healthy behaviors early on.

column43: How can we create a gender equal world? By ensuring all girls are safe, their rights protected and their voices heard. When adolescent girls are active in decision making processes, they become drivers of positive change in their communities now and in the future. That's why we believe in investing in girls' leadership opportunities. Because empowered girls become empowered women.

column43: Seven-month-old Natan Hailay is eating a high energy biscuit to boost his nutrition levels in Ethiopia's conflict-ravaged region of Tigray. After fleeing violence, Natan and his family are currently sheltering in a school. Throughout COVID-19, UNICEF is on the ground, working with local partners to provide nutritional screening and supplies to thousands of children. ⠀ ⠀ As the crisis continues, a deeply troubling picture is emerging. To save lives, we need urgent and continued access - particularly in more rural areas.

column43: “I want to be a teacher when I grow up. For me, education is as important as my mother’s love - I cannot do without the two.” 13-year-old Ripa from Bangladesh. In 2020, 188 countries imposed countrywide school closures, affecting more than 1.6 billion children and youth. Globally, many schools lack the resources to invest in digital learning, and many children from poorer households do not have internet access. Closing schools should be a measure of last resort. To safeguard children’s futures we must safeguard their education.

column43: The senseless violence needs to stop. The racism needs to stop. Attacks against Asian Americans have been on the rise over the past year amid the COVID-19 pandemic. One in four Asian American youth report experiencing racism over the last year. Some parents fear sending their children back to in-person school due to anti-Asian sentiment. This is utterly unacceptable. Our children are watching. We must act to #StopAsianHate and end the systemic racism that is putting their futures at risk.
column46: Save the Children. Janti Soeripto @SaveCEO_US I'm horrified by the senseless murder of 8 people in Atlanta, including 6 Asian women. @StopAAPIHate reports 25% of Asian American youth have been targets of racism during the pandemic This is unacceptable. @SavetheChildren stands with the AAPI community. #StopAsianHate

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Baby Ghofran is only 4 months old, yet she's fighting for survival. "She has been suffering from the same condition since she was born, and we keep transferring her from one hospital to another," says her father, Mohammed. Ghofran is one of 2.3 million children projected to suffer from acute malnutrition in Yemen this year. While she's receiving treatment at a UNICEF-supported hospital, many cannot. "The increasing number of children going hungry in Yemen should shock us all,” says UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore. “More children will die with every day that passes without action." UNICEF and partners are on the ground supporting families grappling with the impact of conflict and COVID-19, but we urgently need more funding.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “I miss going to school because you can discuss and help each other to understand faster,” says 12-year-old Alfani from Kenya on the challenges he faced when his school was closed. The cost of closing schools – which at the peak of COVID-19 lockdowns affected 90 per cent of students globally and left more than 1/3 of schoolchildren without access to remote learning – has been devastating. We must prioritise reopening schools as safely as possible. No effort must be spared to ensure children and young people can continue their education.

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: When the shelling in #Syria started, 12-year-old Nour and her family had to flee their home – constantly moving from place to place. Due to the family's displacement, Nour was out of school for several years, and at the age of 11, she could not read or write. "If it were not for the war, I would have been much more educated. War prevented me from learning.” When Nour arrived to a camp in North East Syria, she began to attend classes at Save the Children's temporary learning space. Now, she knows how to read and write, and she has made new friends. “I wish that all of Syria’s children remain in their houses with their parents, studying well, and living happily to achieve their dreams.”

So, let’s work side by side as partners and friends to emerge from this pandemic stronger than before.” UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore in an open letter on how we can reimagine a better future for every child.

column43: “Mental health is just as important as physical health. Sadly, far too many children and young people do not seek help because of stigma and discrimination. Countries need to give this issue the investment it deserves, dramatically expand mental health services and support for young people in communities and schools, and build on parenting programmes to ensure that children from vulnerable families get the support and protection they need at home.” UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore in an open letter on how we can reimagine a better post-COVID-19 world for every child.
column46: "COVID-19 HAS TURNED LIVES UPSIDE DOWN." Henrietta Fore, UNICEF Executive Director unicef for every child 75

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “The coronavirus pandemic has affected almost everyone on the planet, but it is not affecting us all equally. In too many countries, your ethnicity, your colour or your wealth, may make you more likely to suffer the consequences. We need a renewed commitment to address inequality and discrimination and invest in social services. Rich or poor, if your neighbour is sick, you can get sick. This crisis will not end for anyone until we end it for everyone.” UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore in an open letter on how we can reimagine a better post-COVID-19 world for every child.
column46: "COVID-19 DOES NOT DISCRIMINATE, BUT OUR SOCIETIES DO." Henrietta Fore, UNICEF Executive Director unicef for foreverychild every child 75

column43: “During the peak of school closures in early 2020, about 30 per cent of the world’s schoolchildren were unable to access remote learning. We now face a ‘once-in-a-generation’ opportunity to connect every child and school to the internet, and provide new, digitally driven tools to help them develop the skills to realize their potential – through and beyond COVID-19. Bridging the digital divide can help bring quality education for all.” UNICEF Executive Director Henrietta Fore in an open letter on how we can reimagine a better post-pandemic world for every child.

column43: Five-year-old Havugimana is being screened for malnutrition at a UNICEF-supported health clinic in Kizimba, DR Congo. She’s one of more than 3 million children displaced by brutal violence in one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises. As the country grapples with measles, cholera and COVID-19, UNICEF is calling for conflict to stop now.

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: 13-year-old Muna loves school and wants to be a teacher when she’s older. However, due to severe water shortages, her school has been closed since August 2020 when the majority of people in her community were forced to move away in search of pasture and water for their livestock. Muna continues to study at home every day because she doesn’t want to forget what she has learned and often asks her father when the school will reopen. Children are bearing the brunt of a growing climate crisis in Somalia and if urgent action is not taken, an alarming number will face hunger, school closures and displacement. Learn more: http://ow.ly/yaWJ50E6AT8:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/about-us/media-and-news/2021-press-releases/severe-water-shortages-somalia-leave-70-percent-without-safe-drinking-water?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:032321

column43: “We have power cuts and TV is too expensive,” says 17-year-old Stacey from Kenya on her struggle to continue learning remotely during COVID-19 school closures. Not being able to attend classes online, she spent most of her day sitting outside in the alleyway - often in the dark - studying her textbooks in the hope of not falling behind and soon being able to return to school. Remote learning used to be a nice-to-have. Now, it’s a must-have. Yet, in 2020, 463 million children were unable to access remote learning. Significantly expanding access to the internet and digital devices is vital for ensuring that all children and young people are learning and acquiring the knowledge and skills they need to reach their full potential.

His neighbors, like Ruby who lost her job during the pandemic, have been particularly grateful during this difficult time, and she says the events are “helpful to make ends meet. "With the first shipment of doses to Ghana, we can begin to make good on the promise of the COVAX Facility to ensure people from less wealthy countries are not left behind in the race for life-saving vaccines."

column43: 16-year-old Jeison moved to the U.S. at the age of ten as an unaccompanied minor, traveling from his home country of Honduras. He walked for much of the journey and recalls seeing people hungry and dying. “It’s nothing I hadn't seen before,” he explains. Back in Honduras, Jeison witnessed his father’s murder when he was only three. After a difficult journey in search of a better life, he is now in New York pouring his energy into his creativity – he loves rapping and writing screenplays and music. Jeison also volunteers helping with beach clean-ups and coaching soccer. He wants everyone to know that if he can make it, so can they.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Your donations have such an amazing impact on struggling families. Check out how you've helped Clara and how that inspires her to help others. Growing up, Clara lived in a trailer home and shared a bed with five other children. Though she remembers often going to bed hungry, she also remembers the distributions of food, clothing and other items from Feed the Children that let her family stabilize their sometimes desperate situation. Now, as an adult, she credits the support she received with eventually helping her break the cycle of poverty, become self-sustaining and provide for her own children. Still grateful, Clara volunteers with Feed the Children once a month, hoping to help others do the same. #YourImpact #FeedtheChildren #DefeatHunger #BreakTheCycle

However, I really missed school – my friends, my teachers, even our classroom.” After months of remote learning due to COVID-19, 11-year-old Sesili from Georgia is happy to be back in class. Schools are central to children’s development, safety and well-being. Yet, more than 888 million children worldwide continue to face disruptions to their education as a result of full or partial school closures. Governments must invest in children’s education and prioritise reopening schools.

column43: Join us this #MonthOfMoms as we honor all the incredible wish moms, like Linda, the original wish mom, whose son Chris’ wish to be a police officer was granted 41 years ago. Chris’ wish not only gave him an escape from his fight against leukemia, but also sparked a legacy of hope for more than 340,000 children in the U.S. since. 🌟 "It's been more than [40] years since my son Chris received his wish, and I am still amazed and inspired how one little boy's dream to be a policeman has touched the lives of so many thousands of people." – Linda, mother of Chris, the boy whose wish inspired the founding of Make-A-Wish. 💙

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: 168 empty desks. 168 unused backpacks. 168 million futures hanging in the balance. This pandemic classroom installation at the United Nations in New York is a powerful reminder of the global education crisis. The desks and backpacks represent the 168 million children whose schools have been completely closed for nearly a year due to COVID-19. Our message to world leaders is clear: no effort should be spared to reopen schools.

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: 15-year-old Peter lives in a refugee settlement in Uganda. He dreams of a future in politics and tells us “I want to be a member of Parliament so that I can build a smart house.” Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and school closures, Peter’s education came to a halt but we’re doing whatever it takes to keep kids learning. With support from local government, we're providing learning materials and solar lights to help children continue studying even when it's dark.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: 13-year-old Nawil is happy to return to school in Somalia. COVID-19 has disrupted schooling for children all over the world, threatening to unravel decades of progress. Schools for 168 million students have been closed for almost a year due to the pandemic. Helping children get their education back on track is critical to protect their futures.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “This classroom represents the millions of centres of learning that have sat empty—many for almost the entire year. Behind each empty chair hangs an empty UNICEF backpack—a placeholder for a child’s deferred potential.” Executive Director Henrietta Fore. As we enter the second year of the COVID-19 pandemic, we urge governments to prioritize the reopening of schools.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: "A tragedy for the future of humankind.” UN Secretary-General António Guterres on a visit to our pandemic classroom installation highlighting the 168 million students out of school for almost a year due to COVID-19. As he has warned before, we’re facing a “generational catastrophe.” Reopening schools - and reopening better - is more urgent than ever. Children cannot afford another year of school closures.

We've also set up child-friendly space supported by Save the Children staff and volunteer leaders from the displaced community, where children can play safely and recover. Our humanitarian response spans across the Tigray region and in Sudan, where we are supporting refugees displaced by the conflict.

column43: “I can’t believe that schools are going to be opened. I miss my friends and I can’t wait to see them again. I love school so much. It made me sad when they were closed,” says 12-year-old Salam who lives in Za’atari refugee camp, Jordan. For many children, school is so much more than a place of learning – it is a lifeline to safety, health services and nutrition. Yet, millions have already missed almost an entire year of schooling, causing immeasurable disruption to their lives, learning and wellbeing. Now is the time to increase investments in education and prioritize reopening schools as quickly as possible.

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: This #WorldHealthDay, we're celebrating incredible community health workers like Lucky. After her three-year-old son was diagnosed with malnutrition, Lucky joined Save the Children's mother-led malnutrition program in Somalia. "I was shocked he was malnourished because I thought he looked healthy," Lucky said. "And that’s why I joined the program so I could keep an eye on my other children and make sure they also didn’t become malnourished." The program provides training for women in the community on how to assess children for malnutrition and information on the importance of breastfeeding and vaccines. Once trained, the women go door-to-door in their communities assessing children and referring those with malnutrition to Save the Children’s Maternal and Child Health clinic where they can receive treatment. Community health workers like Lucky are the backbone of health systems around the world. We're so grateful for everything they do to ensure kids are healthy!

column43: Mariana, 20, left Guatemala with her two younger sisters to reunite with their mother in the U.S after being separated for five years. She was eight months pregnant when they crossed the border and gave birth to her daughter inside a detention centre in Texas. We need a new approach to ensure unaccompanied migrant and asylum-seeking children in the U.S. receive proper care and support.

column43: “I am very happy the vaccine is finally here." Shiprah, a social worker, is one of the first to be vaccinated against COVID-19 in Kenya. "We are exposed to many people at work but now I feel safer because I have had the COVID-19 vaccine.” Shiprah received her vaccination thanks to COVAX - a global initiative to ensure the fair distribution of COVID-19 vaccines co-led by UNICEF, Gavi, the Vaccine Alliance World Health Organization (WHO) and CEPI.

column43: “When I came back to school, everything seemed so different: while in class we all wear masks, desks are one metre apart and you cannot come up to the blackboard to talk about your homework, you need to do it from your desk. Also, we cannot hug each other,” says 10-year-old Rezi from Georgia on some of the precautions his school has taken to help prevent the spread of COVID-19. Despite the changes, children like Rezi are adapting and glad to be back in school. “There were a lot of technical problems with distance learning. Many of my classmates could not really participate in class. So, of course, I prefer learning at school.” What are you looking forward to most about returning to school?

Diagnosed with the same cancer, at the same age, her nurse became her motivation to fight and to come out a survivor. Thank you, nurses and nurse practitioners for your compassion and dedication to your patients -including wish kids! #NationalNursesWeek

column43: Jennifer, 15, colours with her 8-month-old daughter Scarlett at their home in New York. Originally from Guatemala, Jennifer crossed the border into the U.S. when she was 13 years old with her sisters to reunite with their mother after being apart for five years. "I would like my daughter to know how to cherish the opportunities that life has given her." She tells us as she recalls the difficulties along their migration journey and how important finding support systems and being reunited with their mother was.

column43: When teenagers embrace a cause, you can bet they’ll jump into it with zeal and get the job done. Feed the Children has teamed up with multiple partners across the U.S. for distribution events. Teenagers are almost always among our most enthusiastic volunteers at these events, jumping right in. Why? Because they know what it means to “love thy neighbor.” 💕 🤗 “ᴍᴀɴʏ ᴘᴇᴏᴘʟᴇ ᴡʜᴏ ᴅᴏɴ’ᴛ ʜᴀᴠᴇ ᴇɴᴏᴜɢʜ ꜰᴏᴏᴅ ꜰᴇᴇʟ ʜᴏᴘᴇʟᴇꜱꜱ ᴀɴᴅ ᴜɴʟᴏᴠᴇᴅ,” ꜱᴀʏꜱ ᴛᴏᴍᴍʏ, 15. “ᴀɴʏᴏɴᴇ ʟᴏᴏᴋɪɴɢ ᴛᴏ ꜱʜᴏᴡ ʟᴏᴠᴇ ᴛᴏ ᴛʜᴇɪʀ ɴᴇɪɢʜʙᴏʀꜱ ᴄᴀɴ ᴅᴏ ɪᴛ ʙʏ ʜᴇʟᴘɪɴɢ ᴍᴇᴇᴛ ᴛʜᴇɪʀ ᴘʜʏꜱɪᴄᴀʟ ɴᴇᴇᴅꜱ ᴀɴᴅ ᴘʀᴀʏɪɴɢ ꜰᴏʀ ᴛʜᴇᴍ.” Thank you, teens, for your service! 👏 #Volunteer #ThankYou #Compassion #FeedtheChildren

column43: “I am thrilled that they are opening schools again because I will be able to see my classroom, teachers and friends,” says 10-year-old Ayman who lives in Za'atari refugee camp, Jordan. “I wasn’t learning very well when learning was online, at least not as good as when I was in school. There were some technical problems… and the internet coverage here is so bad.” As students like Ayman return to their classrooms after nearly a year of school closures due to COVID-19, it is critical that they are given the support they need to readjust and catch up on their learning.

column43: One of the comments we often receive around migrant children at the U.S. southern border is "why don’t they stay in their home country?” We wanted to answer this question. ⁠ ⁠ Many kids attempting to cross the U.S. southern border are asylum seekers left with no choice but to flee their homes. Seeking asylum is not a crime and every child has the right to safety and protection. Swipe below to learn about the reality for kids at the border and why they’re forced to make this life-threatening journey.⁠ Share this post to raise awareness of the situation and follow the link to learn how you can help: http://ow.ly/zfBb50Ek2Ea:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/charity-stories/unaccompanied-minors-border-crisis?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Border_Crisis:SCUS_Lp_Post1:040921
column46: THE CLIMATE CRISIS HAS WORSENED ALREADY DIFFICULT CONDITIONS In November 2020, Hurricane Eta and Hurricane lota tore through the region. Families who were already struggling due to COVID-19 then faced the devastating loss of their belongings, houses and crops. Extreme weather has left many families living in poverty with less food, less clean water, lower incomes and worsening health. The U.N. warns that many will have to choose between starvation and migration.

column43: ✌ for #Vaccinated! As health workers, teachers and loved ones are vaccinated against COVID-19, a whole network of people that children rely on are being protected. More healthy midwives to care for babies and pregnant mothers, more healthy teachers to educate our children, and more healthy parents, aunties, uncles and grandparents to support with childcare. Are you being vaccinated or know someone who will be? Share a picture, tell us what the vaccine means to you, and tag UNICEF for the chance to be featured.

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: Saynab, 14, and her family have been hit by repeated droughts in Somalia. Last year they were forced to leave the rural area where they lived because all their livestock died due to severe water shortages. The drought also meant Saynab's mother Amina had to close her business. Because of this, Amina can only afford to send three of her children – including Saynab – to school. "My biggest challenge is that I’m worried my family won’t be able to afford my school fees and that I won’t be able to go to school," Saynab told us. "I’d be worried that I wouldn’t be able to catch up once I went back and that I would miss my friends and my studies." It's clear: the climate crisis is a children's rights crisis. We need climate action to help protect every child's right to education, so kids like Saynab can continue to learn and follow their dreams.

column43: After months of enduring intensive chemotherapy treatments, Quiana from Make-A-Wish Greater Bay Area, celebrated the end of her cancer journey with her wish for a trailer for her show pigs. Now, Quiana can pursue her passion and compete at any competition she wants with her show pigs and brand-new trailer in tow. “It closed that door [of cancer] and she can look to the future with her wish.” – Ellen, Quiana’s mom You can help bring hope to wish kids like Quiana by donating today at wish.org/donate:=:https://secure2.wish.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=donate_now&chid=100-000.

column43: Hasseniya was a child when she was married in Mauritania. By 16, she'd had her first child. 10M additional girls are at risk of child marriage due to COVID-19, threatening years of progress. School closures, economic stress, service disruptions, pregnancy, and parental deaths due to the pandemic are putting the most vulnerable girls at increased risk of child marriage. One year into the pandemic, we must do more to reduce a girl’s risk of having her childhood stolen.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: When Hasmik moved to a new high school in Armenia, it was the chemistry lab that caught her eye. That’s when the 16-year-old knew she wanted to help make science accessible to students of all backgrounds. She and her co-founders created VR Labs, a virtual lab that simulates science experiments with virtual reality headsets. “It’s one thing to watch an experiment being done by your teacher,” Hasmik says. “It’s another thing to do it yourself.” Education in STEM (science, technology, engineering and math) is critical for success in today’s rapidly changing world. But compared to boys, many girls don’t have the same opportunities to study STEM subjects and develop the high-level skills needed, as adults, to compete in the workforce. Hasmik hopes VR Labs will inspire more students - especially girls - to pursue studies and careers in science. Soon, she and her team plan to secure a meeting with Armenia’s Ministry of Education and Science to present their prototype.

column43: All 10-year-old Ferhana wants is to go to bed without hunger. Her family lives in a tent settlement in Balkh, Afghanistan after they were displaced by conflict. Her parents are unable to work due to COVID-19 shutdowns and are struggling to afford food. This means Ferhana, her four siblings and her parents survive off just tea and bread. "I want the war to end," Ferhana said. "And I want us to have something to eat." The decades-long conflict in Afghanistan has brought daily suffering to countless children. And COVID-19 continues to have a disastrous impact on millions of families like Ferhana's. Learn more about the situation and how you can help: http://ow.ly/4lUc50El1Ts:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/afghanistan?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:SCUS_Lp_Post1:041121

column43: “Despite everything that happened to me, I could not stand still, I kept helping people in need.” 25 year-old Mubarak is a psychosocial support volunteer in Yemen. Before volunteering, he constantly tried to protect his neighbors and friends—often putting him in harm's way. Mubarak tragically lost two of his brothers in conflict and was seriously injured on two separate occasions resulting in the loss of one of his eyes and his left leg. Despite all this great personal loss, he continues to work with Yemeni children and strives to create a better world for them. #MondayMotivation

Their mother works hard to keep a job and food on the table, but sometimes she needs just a little extra to make it through the month. Help families like Addison and May's. column43: Wish kid Cherish, from Make-A-Wish Michigan, wished to have a Michigan family vacation where she and her family could play in the sun experience a new place. “Every sick child and family deserves to experience a wish. It is a big escape from reality, doctors, hospitals, school and work. For her wish, we just wanted to spend time together as a family and enjoy good food, good fun and good vibes. We were all together without a worry and just having fun.” -Brittany, Cherish’s Mom Wish Moms like Brittany know firsthand the impact of a wish for their families. You can help grant more wishes for kids like Cherish by giving today at wish.org/donate:=:https://secure2.wish.org/site/SPageServer?pagename=donate_now&chid=100-000. #MonthOfMoms

column43: When the situation in Venezuela became impossible, 8-year-old Monica and her family left the country to settle in Colombia. Monica’s mother Anastonia has been struggling to find work since arriving in Colombia, and due to the family’s financial struggles, they sometimes have to go two to three days without food. Monica’s youngest sister, Luz, suffers from malnutrition and at one years old, she is still unable to walk. Thanks to support from Save the Children, Monica’s mother has been able to buy essentials like food and medicine and take Luz to see a doctor. When we met Monica, she was looking forward to celebrate her birthday with cake, a piñata and toys! ❤️ 🎉

column43: V for #Vaccinated! ✌️ Over the past few weeks there were scenes of joy, relief and hope as health workers in Ethiopia, Fiji, Nigeria, Sudan and Philippines were vaccinated against COVID-19. They received their vaccines through COVAX, a global initiative led by UNICEF, WHO, Gavi and CEPI to ensure the fair distribution of COVID-19 vaccines. column43: Ummay tragically lost her first baby to pneumonia. She believes her lack of maternal health care contributed to her baby’s death. ⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ When she became pregnant again, Ummay attended Save the Children’s health facilities in Cox's Bazar regularly for check-ups and now has a healthy 18-month-old daughter named Jakia. ⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ “After giving birth to my daughter, she received all the vaccinations at the right time," Ummay told us. "Because of the vaccinations, she has not had any severe diseases since her birth. She is perfectly well and healthy."⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ #VaccinesBringUsCloser to a world free of diseases like polio, pneumonia, measles and, help eradicate childhood diseases—saving millions of children’s lives each year. #VaccinesWork

Many are traveling alone and have experienced severe trauma en route to the border. ⁠ ⁠ In Mexico, our team operates child-friendly spaces where migrant children can draw, sing, play and just be kids during a very difficult time. ⁠ Learn more about our border response: http://ow.ly/UH5Z50Ez88E:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/what-we-do/emergency-response/us-border-crisis?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Border_Crisis:SCUS_Lp_Post1:042721

column43: A devastating fire has displaced 50,000 Rohingya refugees in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh. Behind the clouds of smoke and beneath the ashes are homes, education centres and cherished belongings. UNICEF is working shoulder-to-shoulder with partners to support children and their families with shelter and water, and to reunify those who have been separated in the turmoil. Almost 1 million people live in the crowded camp after fleeing brutal violence in Myanmar. Half are children. With heavy monsoon rains rapidly approaching and the ever-present threat of COVID-19, funds are urgently needed to help families rebuild and recover.

column43: Maddie, born with a rare heart condition, endured three open heart surgeries, all before her 2nd birthday. This fighter was also born with Down syndrome - but she doesn't let her diagnoses dull her spirit. Maddie wanted her wish to capture the many dreams she has for herself, and her wish for a permanent basketball hoop did just that. She joked that her doctor would be happy with her choice as it encourages her to exercise, and that one day she might even go pro! Until then, Maddie will use her new court to improve her skills and impress her Special Olympics teammates. 📷: Take Heart Studios, Make-A-Wish Western New York

When I grow up I want to be a doctor and then help the patients in my community." 16-year-old Meskele attends the Maru Sombo school in her community in Ethiopia that was built by Save the Children. Thanks to partners like PVH we’re providing early childhood and youth training resources to kids in some of the world’s most underserved communities. You can support our work for children like Meskele by donating at Tommy Hilfiger and Calvin Klein U.S. stores now through May 30th. https://bit.ly/3xkmIYA:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/about-us/become-a-partner/corporations/5-million-and-above-lifetime-giving#pvh

We’ll only beat this pandemic if we work together and make vaccines available to people in all countries. #OnlyTogether #VaccinesWork #Vaccinated ✌

column43: During COVID-19 lockdowns in Venezuela, Maria has been finding ways to keep busy—playing the flute and learning to cook. At home, she is able to keep up with her studies by using our school kits which are equipped with notebooks, pens and pencils, craft supplies and learning materials focused on literacy and numeracy! The force is strong with Maria! #MayThe4thBeWithYou
column46: Photo: an Andres into Save the Children

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Teachers are largely being left out of COVID-19 vaccine priority groups in lower income countries. Vaccinating teachers protects them in the community so that they can continue to teach in person and schools remain open. It is a critical step towards putting children's education back on track. We must do everything in our power to safeguard the future of the next generation. And this begins by safeguarding those responsible for opening that future up for them.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Children like Danisa deserve to thrive. For only $15, you can provide food to children just like her in the 8 countries we serve in. Donate today: bit.ly/3vhmcIM:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?2562.donation=form1&df_id=2562&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=15-int-child-feeding-program&utm_campaign=15-int-child-feeding-program&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_content= Danisa is 12 years old and lives in Bohol, a small coastal community in the Philippines. Her father is a fisherman who relies on his daily catch, which can earn him roughly five dollars a day, but Danisa’s mother is currently unemployed due to the pandemic. Because of their financial hardship, they’ve had to choose between buying school supplies or putting food on the table. Danisa’s parents know that, without an education, it will be hard for her to earn a decent living when she gets older, but they can’t afford to buy the school supplies she needs to succeed if they also have to buy food. When help came from Feed the Children, it changed their lives. Thanks to people like you and our partners, Danisa and her family no longer have to make the heartbreaking choice between food for today or education for Danisa’s future. #International Feed the Children-Asia #Philippines #FeedtheChildren #ChildhoodHunger #DefeatHunger

Aesha, a 62-year-old Syrian refugee flashes a 'V for #Vaccinated' sign with her granddaughter, after receiving a COVID-19 vaccine in Jordan. “At first, I was nervous because I heard rumors about the vaccine but, me? I know better. The vaccine is protection for us all and I'm a woman of faith." Countries must follow Jordan's lead and make sure everyone has access to the vaccine, no matter where they are from. In addition to supporting the delivery of vaccines through COVAX, UNICEF is also providing syringes, training and cold chain equipment.
