column43: Aida* and her two-year-old daughter Zala* were forced to flee their home when conflict erupted in the Tigray region of Ethiopia. Aida and Zala slept in caves and suffered from hunger during the journey. They now live in an informal camp for children and adults who have been displaced by the conflict. Aida told us that the conflict has heavily impacted on the healthcare system in Tigray. Many health workers have fled, and facilities are not operating and do not have equipment and medicine. Save the Children’s Emergency Health Unit runs a mobile clinic in the informal camp where Aida and Zala live. Thanks to the clinic, Zala received a Vitamin A supplement, which is essential to boost the immune system and protects against life-threatening infection. Learn how you can help children and families like Aida and Zala get the urgent care they need to stay healthy and protected ⤵️ http://ow.ly/nW3X50EEOtJ:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/ethiopia?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Tigray:SCUS_LP_Post1:050521 *name changed for protection.

We’re thrilled the pair reunited in 2019 and are happy to share their story today on National Best Friends Day! 😍 📷: Make-A-Wish Oregon

It was truly magical.” – Randi, Sasha’s mom Learn more about how Disney and Make-A-Wish continue to grant wishes together at wish.org/Disney:=:https://wish.org/disney. #DisneyWishes

column43: It's simply not fair that people in high income countries have more access to COVID-19 vaccines than lower income ones. It’s dangerous too. If the virus is left unchecked by vaccines in one place, it can easily spread to another. That’s why countries which have more vaccine doses than they need MUST share them. Without global cooperation, we only prolong the pandemic and its impact on children. #OnlyTogether #VaccinEquity #WorldHealthDay #Vaccinated ✌️

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: See your donations at work. 😀🤗 Meet Axel.👋 Axel is your typical 5-year-old. He loves to play with his brothers, color, and play soccer.⚽🖍️🦕 And, like many kids, he'd prefer to have a diet of churros rather than fruits and vegetables. When he was younger, he suffered from malnutrition and being underweight, affecting his growth and development. As a result, he didn't care to play with the other children, didn't want to go to school, and didn't look healthy. Thanks to you, Axel now receives three meals a day🍽️ plus vitamins. Providing him with the nutrition and energy⚡ he needs to succeed in school, grow big and strong, and get excited about playing with the other children in his class and village. "I am very happy that my son turned 5 years old no longer has weight problems, they gave me vitamins, I received nutritional counseling, today he eats vegetables, takes his vitamins and likes to play with his friends." Axel's mother. #ChildhoodHunger #Malnutrition #Nutrition #FeedtheChildren #DefeatHunger
column47: Photos from Feed the Children's post

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: If your child is having difficulty coping with feelings of anxiety, anger and sadness, it can help to acknowledge how challenging and different life is during COVID-19. Support them to figure out ways to regulate their emotions – going for a walk, running, deep breathing, drawing, painting or safely seeing friends. Remember, not everyone parents in the same way, so do not compare yourself to other parents or your children to other children. We’re all doing the best we can to get through this.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Schools provide more than learning. They give students access to other essential services such as meals, mental health support, protection, water and sanitation. For many children, school meals are a reliable source of nutrition - and sometimes the only meal they get in a day. Getting them back into the classroom is critical. Schools should be the last to close - and the first to reopen.
column46: School meals are a critical source of nutrition for many children -40% of school meals missed 370 million children globally missed an average of out of 10 school meals in 2020 due to COVID-19 school closures. Prioritise Reopening Schools unicef for every child

column43: Wish kid Arya lives with a rare genetic disorder that causes an inability to sweat, which can be a challenge during hot Arizona summers. Her wish to have a backyard splash pad, complete with LED lights, gives her the opportunity to play outside all summer long! "This is the best wish ever! I'm going to play on my splash pad every day!" -Arya 💦 📸: Make-A-Wish Arizona

column43: According to the USDA, up to 12 million children live in food-insecure households, frequently having nothing or not enough food to eat. This astonishing stat is why our amazing partners at Bentgo have decided to help put a lid on summer hunger. Thank you, Bentgo, for sharing our passions to help end childhood hunger! And this summer, for every purchase made on Bentgo.com, they will donate $1 toward creating a world where no child goes to bed hungry. *promo valid 6/24 – 7/31, 2021

On average, a teacher spends over $700 on school supplies for their classroom. Our Teachers Stores provide FREE classroom materials for teachers to use in their classes. Books, snacks, pencils, notebooks, they have access to the things they need for their students without having to spend money out of their own pockets, giving their students access to the prospect of having a more successful school year. Learn more: https://bit.ly/2TVA12y:=:https://www.feedthechildren.org/resources/distribution-centers/arizona/ #FeedtheChildren #DefeatHunger #Education #Teachers

column43: Everyone is at risk of catching COVID-19, but not everyone has equal access to vaccines. As variants emerge across the world, governments and businesses must urgently simplify barriers to intellectual property rights, eliminate restrictions on exports of COVID-19 vaccines and donate excess vaccine doses as quickly as possible. We’ll only end this pandemic by working together.

Hanadi, a nurse, is helping roll out COVID-19 vaccines at Za’atari refugee camp in Jordan. COVID-19 doesn't discriminate. UNICEF is calling for everyone to have access to vaccines regardless of who they are, where they live, where they come from or where they are going.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: "We can get the extra help that we need, and it helps a lot. Especially during the summertime, when the kids are out of school, they play more and eat at home more. "- Martina Martina and her husband are the proud parents of 3 children. Their children are some of the 39 million kids who rely on free and reduced-price school meals that are offered throughout the school year. But once summer begins and the schools let out, they find themselves struggling to keep food on the table. "Some schools, they'll give some lunch during the summertime. Some don't. But it's just for a short time. And then it's just it's a little harder to get food more consistently." You can help end summer hunger for families like Martina's. When you donate today, your gift goes 8x further to provide food and essentials for children and families. Helping moms like Martina keep food more consistently on their table. Donate now: https://bit.ly/3iUNe5Y:=:https://secure.feedthechildren.org/site/Donation2?df_id=4521&4521.donation=form1&s_src=facebook&s_subsrc=summer-hunger-fy21q4-202106&utm_campaign=summer-hunger&utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_content=fy21q4-202106 #SummerHunger #DefeatHunger #FeedtheChildren #Summer

column43: Children and families are arriving to the U.S.-Mexico border, having fled unimaginable violence and disasters in their home countries. ⁠ ⁠ Through our network of partners in the U.S., we're supporting the immediate humanitarian needs of newly-arrived families at the southern border with necessities, including hygiene kits, diapers, wipes, books, clothes, backpacks. ⁠ ⁠ We also provide children with toys and games, so they can have fun and just be kids amid extremely difficult circumstances.⁠ ⁠ Learn more about our work at the U.S. southern border and how you can help: https://bit.ly/2RONasQ:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/charity-stories/help-migrant-children-at-the-border?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Border_Crisis:SCUS_Lp_Post1:051121

column43: As schools reopen, we must ensure all students return to the classroom and are given an equal opportunity to learn. This means reaching the most vulnerable, including the 1-in-5 children globally who were already out of school before COVID-19. For every child, an education.

column43: Eshe just received her measles vaccine at our clinic in Tigray, Ethiopia. Across the Tigray region, more than 1.7 million children and adults are displaced as a result of the conflict and need urgent support with access to food, shelter, healthcare, mental health support, clean water and sanitation services. We're continuing to scale up our response to meet the growing needs of kids and their families. Our Emergency Health Unit is running mobile clinics providing critical primary health services such as vaccinations, treatment for diseases and malnutrition, care for pregnant and breastfeeding women and mental health services. Click the link to learn more about the situation and how you can help us to keep children like Eshe healthy and safe: https://bit.ly/3uFA8wA:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/charity-stories/ethiopia-tigray-region-conflict-facts-faqs-how-to-help:emer_tigray:scus_lp_post1:051221

column46: Savethe the Children. Save Children. Save the Children US @SavetheChildren We are horrified by the violence in Gaza and Israel that has killed more than 120 people, including 33 children. That’s why we work around the clock to ensure vulnerable children and their families are supported. Through sponsorship, we’re providing families In Zimbabwe with hygiene kits. Now, 10-year-old McClean and her siblings are among the 650 children in their rural community who have received kits. Their mother is grateful and tells us it will assist them at home, as they had nothing to use to protect themselves from catching the virus.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: "People need encouragement and support. We keep forgetting how important it is to just listen... Sometimes, people just really need to tell you everything that’s going on," says mental health advocate Renata, 24, from Belize who has been helping to support her community during COVID-19. "On average, countries invest just 2% of health budgets in mental health. It’s worth investing in mental health services because your people are the foundation. Having teachers, parents, stakeholders, policy makers all understand what mental health is and not just hearing about it but really learning about it is really going to help provide the proper support."

column43: School closures can have devastating effects, especially on girls who are more likely to drop out and never return. The chance to learn can change a child’s life and reduce the risk of child labour, child marriage, early pregnancy, violence and abuse. Governments must reopen schools and prioritise education for all children.

column43: Wish kid Rylen suffers from a nervous system disorder that has taken much of his eyesight and mobility. Rylen and his dad love spending time together outdoors, but his condition makes it hard to get to their favorite fishing spots. Rylen’s wish for a tandem fishing kayak makes him feel free, calm and in control. And it means he and his dad will be able to make happy memories together. 🎣 Join us in honoring all amazing dads, like Rylen’s, this Father’s Day! 📸: Make-A-Wish Tri-Counties

UNICEF works with partners across the world to prevent and treat malnutrition - a condition that robs children of their futures and threatens their lives. Yet, the strain on families’ livelihoods and health services due to COVID-19 has devastated children’s access to regular, healthy meals. Through the pandemic, we’re determined to end hunger for every child. Thank you for your support.

As we acknowledge our past, we also must continue to focus on our future and each do our part in creating a world where systemic racism can finally be defeated. The Make-A-Wish office is closed today to allow employees to celebrate, learn and reflect on this monumental day in history. #Juneteenth

column43: 13-year-old Yousif was injured by shelling in November of 2020 outside of his home in Yemen. ⁠ ⁠ He had been bravely helping people struck by an earlier attack when he was hit —badly injuring his arm, leg and foot. Yousif has had operations to remove the shrapnel, but he cannot move his arm. ⁠ ⁠ Save the Children supported his family by paying for the surgery costs, as well as providing food baskets, toys and other supplies to keep him comfortable while in recovery.⁠ ⁠ When we spoke to Yousif, he said: "I hope I can have my arm back as it was, so I can write and play again."⁠ ⁠ Children in Yemen are paying for the price of this brutal, relentless war with their lives. Learn how you can help keep children like Yousif healthy and protected: https://bit.ly/3bsj99o:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/yemen?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_Yemen:SCUS_Lp_Post1:051721

column43: How it started ➡️ How it's going In November 2013, staff at the maternity ward in Gardo General Hospital in Puntland, Somalia, held their breath as they waited for baby Zakaria to take his first. Zakaria's mother was terrified when her baby boy came into the world without breathing. But she was in the right place and the midwife had the right training and tools to know what to do. Working quickly with ventilation, oxygen and suction, she treated Zakaria until finally, he began to cry. Zakaria was one of the first babies to be born in this Save the Children supported hospital. Six years later, we caught up with Zakaria who is now a thriving young boy and amazing older brother to three siblings!

column43: 9-year-old Daniel and 13-year-old Nafissa receive new backpacks on their first day back to school in Cameroon. They're excited to be learning with their classmates and teachers again after months of COVID-19 closures. “I was bored when the school was closed, and I missed my friends. I realize how much I like school." Daniel dreams of becoming a police officer. "I’m so happy I can come back to school. I wasn’t happy when the school was closed. I like to learn," says Nafissa who hopes to one day become a nurse. Every child deserves to have their dreams fulfilled. Yet, millions continue to be denied the chance to go to school and learn. Governments must spare no effort to get them back into classrooms. Their futures depend on it.

column43: Should you breastfeed during the COVID-19 pandemic? Absolutely. Breastmilk is rich in nutrients and antibodies - helping protect babies from infections, diarrhoea and pneumonia. Breastfeeding, starting within the first hour of birth, provided exclusively for six months, and continued for up to two years or beyond is one of the most powerful ways to give children the healthiest start to life.

column43: Mishy from the Maldives is studying at home and staying connected with her friends online. COVID-19 school closures forced hundreds of millions of students all over the world to rely on virtual learning. But for those with poor or no connectivity at home, this was almost impossible - causing them to lose out on education and costing them a real shot at a better future. UNICEF is working with partners to expand access to the internet and to digital devices. This is vital for ensuring that all children are learning and acquiring the knowledge and skills they need - and deserve. Together, we can deliver quality learning opportunities to anyone, anywhere, at any time.

column43: "They are saying that the next floods will be even worse than the one that made us leave our home.” 13-year-old Ajok and her family lost everything to floods in June last year. They were forced to live in a school classroom for 10 months. While they were there, Ajok contracted Malaria and her baby sister Achol, suffered from malnutrition. Flooding in South Sudan has caused displacement for thousands of people across the region, and another rainy season is due to start any day. Families are doing the best they can, but unsanitary conditions in temporary accommodation is affecting children’s health and wellbeing. Learn how we’re providing support to families in South Sudan and how you can help: https://bit.ly/3bGYG0Q:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/south-sudan?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:052121

So we provide food every week. – Cyndi Tercero, Family & Community Engagement Manager, Phoenix Union High School District Despite the American Rescue Plan's increase in SNAP benefits, a gap still exists for most households between what they can pay for and their food needs. Thanks to our incredible partners at Frito-Lay, we can provide food and essentials to hungry children and families, even during the hungriest time of the year. Thank you, Frito-Lay, for helping us defeat summer hunger.

column43: Somalia is one of the hardest places on earth to be a child. Decades of conflict, an increasing number of climate-related disasters and severe drought have left many families facing extreme poverty.⁠ ⁠ Twelve-year-old Fawzia lives with her grandmother Mariam, her mother and siblings in a camp for displaced people in Somalia.⁠ ⁠⁠ Mariam supports her extended family with the income she generates from a shop she runs in the camp. ⁠ ⁠ Last year, she received a grant from Save the Children through our income generation program and used the money to expand the shop. ⁠ ⁠ Now, Mariam says the shop produces a larger income, and she has been able to use the money from the business to pay for medical treatment for Fawzia’s mother who is very ill. ⁠ ⁠ We are helping families like Fawzia’s to find alternative sources of income so they can support themselves and survive the multiple crises they face. Learn more about our work in Somalia 👉 https://bit.ly/2QJVAlc:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/somalia?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:052421

column43: Thanks to vaccines, many of us have been fortunate to grow up without seeing family or friends fall sick with measles or polio. In a sense, vaccines have become a victim of their own success - they have eliminated transmission of these diseases in many countries but also the visible and shocking impacts that make us fear infection. As we wait for COVID-19 vaccines to roll out more widely, let’s remember to vaccinate our children against other highly contagious diseases which remain a serious threat. #VaccinesWork

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Five-month-old Soro Issuf is waiting for a polio and measles vaccination with his mother at a UNICEF-supported hospital in Côte d'Ivoire. We must not let COVID-19 disrupt children’s access to life-saving childhood vaccines. Don’t delay. Find out what vaccines your child needs today. #VaccinesWork

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Emily, 12 months, is waiting with her mother for her routine vaccinations in Uganda. Vaccines have helped generations of children grow up in good health, safe from infectious and dangerous diseases like polio and measles. As COVID-19 vaccines become available, they too will offer life-saving protection to our communities. #VaccinesWork

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: The COVID-19 pandemic reveals what is at stake when we don't have the protective shield of immunization. In the past year, children have been locked out of classrooms, denied life-saving health care and prevented from being close to loved ones. Today, vaccines are our best hope of ending this pandemic - and rebuilding a better world. Governments must work together to ensure COVID-19 vaccines are affordable and accessible to all countries. #VaccinesWork

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: “Despite everything that happened to me, I could not stand still, I kept helping people in need.” 25 year-old Mubarak is a psychosocial support volunteer in Yemen. Before volunteering, he constantly tried to protect his neighbors and friends—often putting him in harm's way. Mubarak tragically lost two of his brothers in conflict and was seriously injured on two separate occasions resulting in the loss of one of his eyes and his left leg. Despite all this great personal loss, he continues to work with Yemeni children and strives to create a better world for them.

column18: Together, we create life-changing wishes for children with critical illnesses.
column43: As a kid, Eldy stole her mother’s camera whenever she got the chance. But when she was 14, she was diagnosed with cancer. When she was asked what her one 1 wish would be, she knew right away, she wanted a camera to call her own to capture the memories her close-knit family. The camera, the lenses, and the editing software were more than she could have imagined on the day her wish came 1. “My wish made me realize that I overcame huge challenges, and with photography, I can continue to create more memories,” she said. 📸: Make-A-Wish Greater Los Angeles

column43: 12-year-old Hassan and his family lost everything due to the climate crisis. We've been helping Hassan's family through our cash fund program, but he really wants to go to school. Hassan loves to play football and dreams of becoming a doctor. “I want to be a doctor, because we don't have any health place here in the camp.” Sadly, Hassan's mother Bakari cannot afford to enroll him into a daily school program. Climate change is having a profound impact on children and their futures are at risk. We must act now. Learn more: https://bit.ly/34m1fRO:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/what-we-do/emergency-response/climate-change?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Climate_Evergreen:Scus_Lp_Post1:052721

column43: Many of us are waiting for the day when we can see loved ones again, but are our children prepared? The COVID-19 pandemic has disrupted immunization against dangerous childhood diseases, leaving children vulnerable once more social interactions resume. We can’t let this happen. UNICEF is calling on governments to urgently prioritize investment in health services and vaccination programmes to reach every child - particularly the most vulnerable. #VaccinesWork

column43: Tens of thousands of families have been forced to flee their homes following the eruption of Mount Nyiragongo near Goma in the Democratic Republic of Congo. Eleven-year-old Bakari was at the market selling cabbage when the volcano erupted. His father wasn’t with him and when the eruption occurred, they fled separately. “I heard shouts and started running with other people without returning home," Bakari said. Our team has been working to reunite children like Bakari who were separated from their families in the aftermath of the eruption. “I was walking without knowing where I was going. Now that I am home I feel good.” Click the link to learn more about the situation in the DRC and how you can help: https://bit.ly/3oY2Czq:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/charity-stories/drc-volcano-eruption-goma?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:052921

Liam was able to demonstrate his bravery, integrity, focus and patriotism, as he became an honorary member of the 56th Squadron at Luke Air Force Base, the “Top Dogs” of Arizona, officially granting his wish to be a fighter pilot. 🇺🇸 📸: Make-A-Wish Arizona

They have prevented lifelong disabilities and almost eliminated the scourge of diseases such as measles and polio - saving millions of lives. Now, COVID-19 vaccines will also act as a protective shield for whole families and communities. #VaccinesWork

column43: "Because of the coronavirus, we were not going to go back to school. This news saddened me." 11-year-old Harira was scared when she learned about COVID-19 and that her school would be closing in her village in Niger. Harira dreams of becoming a teacher and knows that the only way to achieve her dream is to continue her education. The pandemic has created a global education emergency, and girls are particularly impacted. That's why we're calling on world leaders to help ensure all girls have access to the quality education they deserve and the chance at a brighter future.

It’s time for the 17th annual Eat-A-Dish for Make-A-Wish campaign where you can indulge in your favorite Italian dishes for a good cause. Through August 11 you can help Make-A-Wish grant life-changing wishes for children like Forrest when you dine at Maggiano's or order online. Come dinnertime, you know what to do. 🍝 Find a location near you at locations.maggianos.com.

column43: The second wave of COVID-19 has overwhelmed health systems in Nepal. Vaccination supplies are limited, and with oxygen in short supply, the situation is critical. And the longer this crisis goes on, the greater the disruption to vital health services, putting children and their families at risk. With your support, we are providing oxygen and other essential medical supplies to health facilities. We are educating kids on COVID-19 safety and providing mental health support during lockdown. Learn more about our response: https://bit.ly/3ci3tpB:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/nepal?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:060421

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: Fourteen-year-old Samira was born with one lung and infantile paralysis in her left hand. Though she loves school, Samira’s disability made it difficult for her to thrive in a crowded classroom in North West Syria for a full day. Breathing difficulties made it near-impossible for her to spend a long time in class and her paralysis caused her to feel self-conscious at times. She would often leave early and miss out on learning. As schools closed due to COVID-19, our partners in Syria began providing students with distance learning instead. This allowed Samira to resume her education without facing any difficulties regarding her breathing. She regained her confidence and is at the top of her class! "Thank goodness now we are studying at home," Samira told us. As we build back better from the pandemic, we must ensure that all children with disabilities can access and benefit from quality education so that they can reach their full potential. #SaveOurEducation

UNICEF Nepal

column43: "I want to become a teacher when I grow up because teachers are the best, they help children to overcome their fears and shyness.” 10-year-old Jannat could not read or write, and the high number of students in her class made it difficult for her to learn. Jannat's teacher noticed her struggling and referred her for Save the Children's summer remedial classes –within months, Jannat's reading and writing improved. Jannat's father believes that the support that she has received has saved her from dropping out of school. The war in Yemen has had a devastating impact on the lives of children. With access to a quality education, there's hope for a better future.

column43: Washing your hands with soap and water like this school girl in Cameroon is one of the most effective ways to prevent COVID-19. UNICEF is working to provide every child with a local source of safe water no matter who or where they are.

column43: 11-year-old Leslie reads a book titled "The most frightening fear of all." The story helps children and their parents recognize fear as a normal reaction to a situation like the pandemic, raises the importance of talking about fear to help kids process it and encourages families to seek emotional support and tools to cope. As part of our child-protection activities in Peru, we also delivered kits with coloring books, stickers, crayons and an address book of local and national health and protection services.⁠⁠⁠

column43: During COVID-19, millions of children and young people have been unable to learn from home due to a lack of access to the internet and to digital devices. In Jordan, UNICEF has been providing tablets and data packages to help the most vulnerable students living in remote areas access quality online education and ensure continuity of learning.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: This week, the Democratic Republic of Congo declared the end of an Ebola outbreak in North Kivu. The swift action from a whole network of people helped stop the spread of Ebola, save lives and protect children. Health workers delivered lifesaving medical care and vaccines. Volunteers helped track and trace efforts and spread lifesaving information. Nursery workers cared for children while their parents received treatment. Our work is not over. Through COVID-19, UNICEF and partners continue to expand access to handwashing stations, run awareness campaigns and provide psychological and nutritional support to people affected by Ebola, including children. UNICEF en RDC

column43: “When I grow up, I want to be a nurse. I want to help and treat people,” says 9-year-old Nalee from Lao PDR. Every child has the right to a quality education and should be given the chance to fulfil their dreams. It is up to us to reimagine a world in which they can.

column43: 13-month-old Terry lives with her mother Ikaal and extended family in one of the poorest and rockiest areas of Turkana, Kenya. ⁠ ⁠ Save the Children, in partnership with Kenyan Ministry of Health, introduced a family nutrition screening program in Terry’s area. Mothers like Ikaal were trained on how to screen for malnutrition and given advice on nutrition.⁠ ⁠ Thanks to the program, they were able to identify when Terry became severely malnourished and get her treatment.⁠ ⁠ Terry is now recovering, and Ikaal is grateful to have the skills to feed her children healthy food and monitor them for malnutrition. 👏

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: Six-year-old Yasmeen was on her way home from school in Taiz, Yemen when the shell hit. Yasmeen was badly injured, along with one of her sisters and her brother, Rashad. Yasmeen had shrapnel lodged in her body and head from the explosion. She was admitted to the ICU for urgent surgery provided by Save the Children and had an operation on her skull to remove the pieces of the shell. Tragically while Yasmeen was fighting for her life, her 11-year-old brother Rashad died from his injuries. Yasmeen is now recovering well and enjoys playing with her younger sister Safa’a who is two years old. When she is well enough, she will need a second operation to replace sections of her skull. We're providing ongoing medical support so Yasmeen can have her surgery.

column43: "I'm very happy to be back in school. I haven't forgotten we're still fighting COVID-19, so I comply with prevention measures such as physical distancing, handwashing and mask wearing," says Mariza from Mozambique. As schools reopen, it’s important that precautions are taken both inside and outside the classroom to prevent the spread of the virus and help protect students, staff, teachers and their families. How are you staying safe?

Each student was able to select their very own free books thanks to the generosity of Scholastic, as part of the #ScholasticSummerReading program. column43: “School is important for girls. When you're educated, you have knowledge. I want to be a doctor to take care of my people and the people of my village." Fourteen-year-old Kadidia and her parents were determined that the violence sweeping Africa’s Sahel region – including her homeland of Mali – wasn’t going to end her chances of completing her education. She knows the value staying in school to prevent early marriage so that she can take control of her own future. We're working around the world to get girls like Kadidia back in the classroom and the chance to achieve their dreams.

column43: More than ever before, the COVID-19 pandemic has revealed the importance of digital connectivity. Connecting every school and home to the internet is a critical first step towards providing every child with access to quality digital learning and opportunities online. Together, we can bridge the digital divide and leverage technology to reimagine education.

column18: Save the Children is an international humanitarian organization that has been protecting children around the world for more than 100 years. Sign up for our newsletter: http://ow.ly/zLnb30lBtl8
column43: 28-year-old Zainab and her family have been impacted by continuous droughts in Somalia. Although they have tried to adapt, the severity and frequency of droughts is making it almost impossible for them to cope. Lack of food and clean water has caused Zainab’s 7-month-old baby, Mohamed, to become malnourished. “I didn't have enough milk and water to feed my child... my village doesn't have a health facility, that's why I came here.” Zainab travelled to a Save the Children-supported health center where baby Mohamed was treated for severe acute malnutrition. Right now, Somalia is facing yet another drought, which is pushing the number of children and adults who need critical support to 5.9 million. Learn how we’re reaching families with support and how you can help ➡️ https://bit.ly/2RLeLM1
column47: Photos from Save the Children US's post

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “Why do we treat mental health as if it’s not a big deal? Why do we say to a person in grief that ‘you are just overthinking’? Why do we stereotype people having mental illness [as] being crazy?... It is time that we set aside these stereotypes and accept that mental health is as important as our physical health.” Tulika, 18, India. COVID-19 has turned children’s lives upside down, disrupting comforting and familiar patterns like going to school and seeing friends. Young people like Tulika are calling out for help. We need to listen and provide the support they need. Voices of Youth

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Khem Rithy is one of the first teachers in Cambodia to receive both shots of the COVID-19 vaccine. “I admit I was nervous about the side effects at first, but after I felt as good as usual.” After health workers and people most at risk, UNICEF is calling for teachers to be prioritized in COVID-19 vaccine roll-outs. In addition to physical distancing, handwashing and mask wearing, vaccines are a powerful way to protect teachers from the virus while helping children back into the classroom.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: “Even though we attend online classes, there are many issues with our studies – where it is difficult to get the teachers’ help and resolve it online. I wish to go back to school soon and enjoy our regular classes,” says 9-year-old Jannatun from Bangladesh. She misses her school, teachers and classmates very much. While many students are back in the classroom, millions worldwide are still facing disruptions to their education due to full or partial school closures. It is imperative that governments continue their efforts to reopen schools and get children's learning back on track.

column18: UNICEF saves children’s lives, defends their rights, and helps them fulfill their potential. We never give up.
column43: Cello, 3, and her mother Selly stand in front of an overflowing river that inundated their home in Indonesia after days of heavy rain. Climate change has and will continue to lead to higher temperatures, more dramatic weather events, more crop failures, increased water scarcity, the damage and destruction of key services for children, as well as injury and death. Inaction is not an option, we need climate action now.

column43: “I would do anything to be like the children at my school. Anything to be like them, because I was told that I wasn’t good enough. I would never be good enough. Now, I look back at those times of my life, and I truly feel sorrow for myself, and unfortunately, this is a very similar reality for many Indian and South Asian children in the United States. Thankfully over the years, I have learned to love my vibrant and traditional culture again, and I have been able to come in closer touch with my South Asian roots, as well as cherish the little things about my Indian heritage that used to make the child in me smile.” Nandana, 16, from the USA, talks about appreciating her heritage and the struggles she has faced throughout the years. From Voices of Youth - our community for young people, by young people.

column43: 12-year-old Nafeesa and 13-year-old Umama are two sisters who were living happily with their mother Marium. But everything changed when Marium became seriously ill with COVID-19. Due to the scale of the pandemic in India, hospitals and ambulance services were overcrowded, and the family could not afford private medical treatment. When Marium's health worsened, Umama ran to Save the Children Youth Champion Obaidullah for help. Thanks to Obaidullah, we were able to support the family, ensuring the mother got the treatment she needed and that the children were safe. “I must thank Save the Children team, which has been very support and were always in touch with us, Umama said. “We could sail through this situation because there were good people around us.” Marium’s condition has stabilized and she continues to recover. Learn how we're keeping children and families healthy and safe in India, including how to help: https://bit.ly/2TmkFDM:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/india?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:061421

column43: All children have the right to proper nutrition. In Zambia, more than 2.3 million people are facing food insecurity due to severe drought. Many families have lost their source of livelihoods including livestock and their farms have yielded less than expected due to the failed rains. With support from our sponsorship programs, children like Kabukabu are now receiving nutritious food packs at school so that they have the fuel they need while learning.

Breaking down the barriers to accessing quality education and skills development has never been more urgent.

"Some of them cannot access the online platform because they do not have access to internet mobile data or have Wi-Fi at home," she told us. The pandemic has created a global education emergency. We're working around the world to ensure all children have access to the quality education they deserve. Drop a 📚 in the comments if you think world leaders should act to #SaveOurEducation.

column43: 23-year-old Amina and her children live in Somalia and have been displaced for over three years by drought after losing their livestock. When we first met her youngest daughter, Fatima, she was very tired and sick with diarrhea and vomiting—lack of nutritional food and clean water caused her to become malnourished. Fatima and her mother were referred to our health center where she received therapeutic food and medicine. Four months after her treatment, Fatima is doing much better! Her mother tells us she is very happy and grateful for the service she received!

column43: Two-year-old Rajiya was born at a Save the Children primary health care center in Cox’s Bazaar, the world’s largest refugee camp. Her mother says they wouldn’t have survived without it. But in the camp, their future is uncertain. “I can't stay here forever and Rajiya future is uncertain here. I plead to you to do everything you could to improve the situation of our country (Myanmar).” Rajiya is one of at least 700,000 Rohingya children in Asia who face discrimination and are denied safety, citizenship and an education. The Rohingya community in Myanmar has experienced decades of state-sponsored persecution and violence. This must stop. Learn more about the situation for Rohingya refugees 👉 https://bit.ly/3vDtRB8:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/about-us/media-and-news/2021-press-releases/rohingya-children-denied-basic-rights?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:061721

column43: “When schools were closed, it was bad news for me and my siblings because when learning moved online, we all had to share one mobile phone to study. There was a lot of pressure and I felt like I was missing out on some lessons," says 15-year-old Rania who lives in Za’atari refugee camp, Jordan. She hopes to become a journalist. "I care about my education and I want to show everyone that I can make it. By doing so, I can inspire many girls to follow my lead and never give up hope." Now, in our second year of the COVID-19 pandemic, ensuring children - especially the most vulnerable - return to school and catch-up is critical to protect their futures.

column43: The ongoing violence in Cabo Delgado, Mozambique has forced more than 800,000 people to flee their homes, including 350,000 children. Like six-year-old Clara whose father was killed when her village was attacked by armed men. Clara and the rest of her family hid in a bush for four days — their home was destroyed and all their belongings burnt. When Clara found out her father had been killed, she was very upset, barely ate and didn’t play with her friends for a long time. Thankfully, the family escaped to a transit site for families who have been displaced by the conflict. Save the Children is supporting Clara’s family with accessing services they need to survive. We also provided Clara with a Happy Kid Kit —books, paper and colored pencils when she first arrived to the transit site. “The conflict is the hardest thing in my life. I like to draw because it makes me feel good and safe,” said Clara. In conflict settings, children are the most vulnerable. Learn how we’re responding to the urgent needs of families in Cabo Delgado, and how to help: https://bit.ly/3iRQsXO:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/mozambique?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:Scus_Lp_Post1:061821

UNICEF is on the ground providing water, health and psychological support but more than anything, the children of Palestine and Israel need peace.

It's time for children to return to the classroom - including those who were already out of school before the COVID-19 pandemic.

column43: Last year, one-year-old Hanan became dangerously malnourished when her father could not find work and struggled to afford even the most essential items for his family. Her father traveled by foot to a health center supported by Save the Children where she received immediate treatment. Combined with a regular supply of nutritious food, after six months, Hanan's weight had increased to nearly 20 pounds. Unfortunately, Hanan's story is not uncommon enough. In Yemen, more than two million children under five do not have enough food to eat. This is a catastrophe that should set off alarms around the world. Learn more about the hunger crisis and take action 👉 https://bit.ly/3vPdJwC:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/charity-stories/children-under-five-years-old-dying-of-hunger-in-yemen?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:Emer_HungerRelief:Scus_LP_Post1:062321

I was inspired to teach and pass on what I learnt to the younger generation," she adds. As COVID-19 continues to disrupt schooling, we must do everything we can to ensure children can develop the skills they need to succeed in school, at work and in life.

column43: “I have strength, I am brave."⁠ ⁠ Strength and courage are two words that perfectly describe 11-year-old Ousmane — a boy who has been through so much but continues to work hard, always with a big smile!⁠ ⁠ Ousmane's father was killed during the violence sweeping Mali, and neighboring Burkina Faso and Niger. ⁠ ⁠ With his mother struggling to cope with her loss and with raising other children alone, Ousmane's aunt offered to take him in.⁠ ⁠ Now he attends a Save the Children-supported school, where he has thrown himself into his studies.⁠ ⁠ "No one works harder than me,” Ousmane says. “No one gets ahead of me at school."⁠ ⁠ Give Ousmane a 👏👏👏 and stand with us in fighting to ensure ALL children have access to a quality education.

column43: How it started ➡️ How it's going⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ In November 2013, staff at the maternity ward in Gardo General Hospital in Puntland, Somalia, held their breath as they waited for baby Zakaria to take his first.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ Zakaria's mother was terrified when her baby boy came into the world without breathing. ⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ But she was in the right place and the midwife had the right training and tools to know what to do. Working quickly with ventilation, oxygen and suction, she treated Zakaria until finally, he began to cry.⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ Zakaria was one of the first babies to be born in this Save the Children supported hospital. ⁠⁠ ⁠⁠ Six years later, we caught up with Zakaria who is now a thriving young boy and amazing older brother to three siblings!

column43: Children in lower income countries rely on healthy parents, healthy health workers, healthy teachers and healthy social workers as much as children in higher income countries. Yet unequal access to COVID-19 vaccines puts everyone at risk. UNICEF is calling on G7 governments and other wealthy countries that have adequate or excess supplies to donate available doses to COVAX now. Sharing doses over the next few weeks will allow COVAX to distribute vaccines to the world’s lower income countries as quickly as possible.

column43: The COVID-19 pandemic shows just how urgent access to safe water and sanitation is. In conflict, where this is already under threat, children and their communities are even more vulnerable to disease. We must end attacks on children and water NOW.

column43: Without access to safe water, children fall ill, schools and hospitals don’t work, and disease and malnutrition spread. Around the world, millions of vulnerable children are growing up in war and their water and sanitation services are under attack. An attack on water, is an attack on children.

column43: It’s not just a moral outrage that COVID-19 vaccines are unequally available. It’s dangerous too. The longer health workers, teachers and social workers remain unprotected against COVID-19, the greater the risk to their health, and the health, safety and opportunities for children. Wealthy countries must share available vaccines through COVAX, a global initiative which ensures fair access to vaccines for all.

Now Samia and her friends are back in the classroom — because child's right to education doesn't stop in times of emergency.

I couldn't ask questions when I didn't understand something but above all I missed the school and my classmates," she adds. Nothing beats learning in a classroom. With measures to help mitigate the spread of COVID-19 and protect students, staff, teachers and their families, governments must do everything they can to resume in-person learning. "I have peace of mind thanks to all the measures taken at school. The washing of hands, the mask, the respect for preventive protocols, all that reassures me."

Six months later, Noor is happy and loves to hear her mother sing. This little survivor is now thriving! But the conflict in Yemen, extreme poverty and rising foods costs are pushing children to the brink of starvation. We must not accept children suffering and dying from hunger, disease and war. column43: "Where we are, we are starving, we are both suffering because we have nothing to eat." Mary is the mother of one year old Aluel, a girl who was born with a cleft lip which she did not receive treatment for at birth. Mary’s village in Akobo county in South Sudan has faced hunger, flooding and cattle raiding in the recent years. Many in her community have lost everything and are experiencing an acute hunger crisis. Due to the hunger crisis, Aluel has been sick and malnourished her whole life, and Mary feared her baby girl wouldn't survive. Fortunately, Aluel is currently receiving treatment at a government hospital, while Mary is receiving psychosocial support from Save the Children. Although Aluel still needs further treatment, both she and Mary are improving. As South Sudan marks its ten year anniversary, millions of kids like Aluel are at risk of famine. Learn more about the crisis and how you can help: https://bit.ly/3xudSHu:=:https://www.savethechildren.org/us/where-we-work/south-sudan?cid=Social_Network:Facebook:LP_Longtail:SCUS_Lp_Post1:070921

Up to 33,000 children remain trapped in inaccessible parts of Tigray, severely malnourished and facing imminent death without immediate help. In a conflict-response made even more complex by the pandemic, UNICEF is calling for an urgent cessation of hostilities so families can receive lifesaving support and begin to rebuild their lives.

column43: Even before the assassination of Haiti's president, 1 in 3 children were at risk due to violence, hurricanes and COVID-19. We are deeply concerned that further insecurity could pose serious challenges to our delivery of vaccines, medicine and medical supplies. "When gangs are fighting in the street and bullets are flying, it's hard to reach the most vulnerable families with these lifesaving supplies." says Bruno Maes, UNICEF representative in Haiti. "Unless humanitarian organizations are granted safe passage, thousands of affected children will continue to be left with little to no assistance.” To reach vulnerable children and families, UNICEF and partners urgently need access and an end to gang violence.

column43: What are the costs of continued COVID-19 school closures? The longer students are out of the classroom, the less likely they are to return - and the higher the risk of child labour, child marriage, early pregnancy, violence and abuse. Children must resume in-person learning as soon as possible.

column43: "I’m a bit scared. I go to a kickboxing club and one of my coaches sent me texts saying he is going to picture me naked every time I go kickboxing and asked me if I would “entertain” him. It’s made me feel so anxious. I can’t focus because I am dreading training tomorrow and what might happen”. It's illegal for teachers, care workers and youth justice workers to have sex with 16 or 17-year-olds in their care. But there's a loophole in the law that means other adults who hold a position of power over a young person can legally have sex with them. This is wrong and we're calling for the law to be extended to include any adult who holds a position of power over 16 or 17-year-olds. To find out more visit: https://bit.ly/2Pbw583:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/campaigns/close-the-loophole/

column43: Warning: this post contains sensitive information some might find upsetting. "Many people don’t speak out. You don’t think you can question your parents’ authority for one, and the power an adult has over a frightened child is huge. There’s also the burden of feeling like it’s your fault to contend with, or the fear of suffering embarrassment and prejudice." Emily-Victoria was sexually abused by her father throughout her childhood and we are so grateful that she shared her story with us. At the time, she was understandably scared to speak to anyone about what was happening. We want to help more young people just like Emily, which is why we've developed resources to help you #TalkPANTS with your children. It's a simple conversation that helps to teach them how to speak to a trusted adult if they're ever worried. Find out more:http://bit.ly/36PSgba

column43: Many young people are receiving their A-level results today. The pandemic has changed the way results will be given and we know this has caused young people more anxiety about their futures at an already difficult time. We understand that it can be hard to know how to support your child with their results. It's important to remind them that they're not defined by their grades, and that you're here if they ever want to discuss their results and options. What would you tell a young person who is feeling anxious or upset about their results?
column46: Supporting your child with grades Be patient and supportive until they feel ready to open up about how they feel. Encourage your child to take their time to think about what they want to do next. Help them think about their choices by writing down a list of pros and cons for each of their options. NSPCC

column43: Warning, this post contains information that some might find upsetting. "When I had children of my own, the memories of my childhood came flooding back. I chose to leave a gift to the NSPCC in my will because of my experiences as a child.” Rita was physically abused and neglected as a child by her mother. “She used to hit me all the time and for any reason. She even held a carving knife to my throat and threatened to kill me when I was 7 or 8.” When Rita was 21 she met her husband. “I hadn’t experienced love, so I was always surprised when people showed it to me. When I had children of my own, the memories of my childhood came flooding back. I was reminded of all the things my mother never did for me. The abuse affected me really badly - I feel like she took away my childhood. I might not ever see the difference that my gift is making but I know I’m doing something, and it feels great.” Rita is incredible and has left a gift in her Will to the NSPCC. To find out more about leaving a gift in your Will, download a free pack today: https://bit.ly/3gYcjsT:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/ways-to-give/leave-charity-gift-in-will/?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=AX3550*LMA21&utm_content=Legacy_Aug2020+Rita_story+Aug20&ac=210309

column46: How to ask a young person if they're ok Pick a time when there's not lots of people around to interrupt and have the conversation in a relaxed, neutral place. 2. Try and make the conversation relevant in some way. For example relating it to the TV show they' re watching. 3. Start by asking questions that aren't just a "yes" or "no" answer, and give them as long as they need to respond. NSPCC

column43: Warning, this post contains information that some might find upsetting. "During the pandemic, so much went on for children. And the effect on their mental health - anxiety, self-harm, suicidal thoughts - is just the beginning. There have been a lot of conversations with children about wanting to end it all. Those are the most difficult calls." - Omar, a Chilldine counsellor, has been here on the frontline for children during this pandemic. "Lockdown made more children vulnerable. The social aspects about not being with friends, their social groups, being out of that routine, missing school, missing the support system that they had within school, feeling deserted by schools, by teachers, missing friends." It's been a difficult year for every one of us. But, through it all, some children have been the hidden victims – experiencing abuse and neglect at home, increased risk online, and further pressures on their mental health. We need to be on the frontline to help children cope and recover from the impact the pandemic has had. We know that with the right help, at the right time, these experiences don’t have to shape their lives. "That's what Childline provides. They feel safe in the fact that no one's going to make a judgement on them. There isn't any other service where they're going to get that. I’m here for them. Childline is here for them." https://bit.ly/2YGzT6z:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/campaigns/still-here/?utm_source=generic_social&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=AY3593*&utm_content=Still_Here+OrganicSocial+Sept20&ac=211550

column43: During the pandemic, reports of domestic abuse have soared. Contacts to our helpline about domestic abuse involving children are up by nearly 50% in the five months since the UK-wide lockdown began. Over the last 10 years, our Domestic Abuse, Recovering Together (DART) service has been here to support thousands of mothers and children who have experienced domestic abuse. More recently, our work alongside other charities successfully campaigned for the Government to amend the Domestic Abuse Bill which means that children will now be recognised as victims of domestic abuse by law. This is progress - but sadly, there are still many families who need support.

column43: "It's giving a child hope. It's giving them an extra day." In 2012, Aaron set up The Liam Charity in his brother’s memory and through it has raised just over £235,000 for Childline! This will help us continue to support children and young people. Tomorrow, Aaron will be running 26.2 miles as part of the Virgin London Marathon's virtual 40th Race. It's taking place three days before the tenth anniversary of the death of his brother Liam, who tragically took his own life at 14. Aaron has carefully crafted his 26.2 mile route around locations of personal significance, including the school he and his brother attended as children, the family home they grew up in and Liam’s grave. We wish Aaron, alongside all our other incredible runners the best of luck tomorrow. Help us thank Aaron for all the work that he has done and continues to do for children, below. He truly is an inspiration. We have no doubt that Liam would be immensely proud.
column46: Aaron, Team NSPCC Running the Virtual London Marathon for his brother, Liam.

column43: Warning: this story contains information that some might find upsetting. “My partner called me to say she thought she might be pregnant. I remember a lot of mixed emotions. You hear all these stories of what can go wrong during pregnancy.” It was Graham’s first time becoming a dad, and he went along to the appointments with his partner to prepare. “I was too nervous to ask questions. I didn’t want it to seem like I didn’t know what I was doing. I felt that I was just expected to stand in the corner during appointments; there but not involved. I stopped talking about my feelings to anyone.” After Graham’s daughter Roxy was born, he continued to struggle with his mental health. “Our check-ups after Roxy arrived felt the same as before. I was never asked how I was feeling or if I had questions. You see on TV that people with mental health struggles can have their kids taken off them, so I was worried that if I did speak to our Health Visitor about it, that they might pass this on to someone who would decide I wasn’t fit to keep my child.” Not getting support made it a lot harder for him to get settled into his new role as a dad. “My partner and I separated when Roxy was six months old and it was a difficult time. My mental health really took a turn for the worse. Over time I began having suicidal thoughts.” Graham was referred to Blackpool Better Start, and did a support course called ‘Mellow Dads.’ “It's important dads speak up about their mental health. Even just talking really helps. I want to help other dads and I think it’s important to build better bonds with professionals who support parents so we can work together to change dads’ experiences." Help us fight for a #FairStart for dads like Graham this #WorldMentalHealthDay: https://bit.ly/3bVXjKs
column46: "It's important dads speak up about their mental health We can work together to change dads' experiences.' Graham & his daughter Roxy

column43: Having a new baby brings pressures and challenges for new parents. Tayah shared with us how she felt as a new mum: “When my daughter was born and they put her on my chest I was shocked by how I felt I couldn’t believe she had hair already and I remember thinking how beautiful she was. Once she arrived, things seemed fine at first, but then it began getting difficult again.” Tayah felt overwhelmed with the new challenge of being a mum: “It started to sink in that she was mine and that this was 24 hours a day, 7 days a week with no breaks.” In England, healthcare professionals check in with all parents in the first few months to spot the signs of mental health problems and support them to bond with their baby. They are crucial for mums like Tayah who’ve needed help. “That black cloud that created a storm in my life soon passed and perhaps could have passed even sooner if I had gotten the help I needed.” With added pressures of the pandemic, we’re asking the government to ensure parents continue to get the support they need. Join us and ask the government to support mums, dads, and babies. https://bit.ly/3m4BTQ9

column43: As the impact of the Covid crisis continues, the challenges families face are likely to intensify. We’re hearing from our services how worries about money, job security, social isolation and insecure housing risk pushing families into crisis. It was inspiring to see Marcus Rashford speak out about his own experiences and to see so many others coming together to protect and support children in their communities during half term. We need to focus on planning further ahead, and that’s why we’ve written to Boris Johnson with Action for Children The Children's Society Save the Children UK Barnardo's and National Children's Bureau children’s futures are not defined by this pandemic. We must all do everything we can to get children through this crisis. Find out more about what we’re asking the Government to do here: https://bit.ly/2JvmM37

column46: What to do if your child has bullied someone 1. Explain how bullying can make people feel. Childline has lots of great advice. 2. Help them realise how what they ve done will have affected the other person. You could ask them how they think the other child is feeling. 3. Explain what you're going to do next, and what you expect your child to do now. NSPCC

column43: With your help in 2020, we came together… For new mums, dads, carers and grandparents – who did an amazing job in tough circumstances. For teachers and guardians – who adapted and adapted and adapted. For our key workers, volunteers and counsellors – who kept going no matter what. For our runners and fundraisers – who found ways to keep helping us be here. We came together to ask each other for help, to look out for one another, to support each other on the bad days, to stand up for children, to celebrate our heroes and to give children a voice. But most of all, we came together for young people to let them know they did not need to face this year alone.
column46: What did we achieve in 2020? We came for new mums and dads together for key workers and volunteers for teachers and guardians to run, climb and fundraise to support each other to look out for one another to give children voice to stand up for children to speak out against child abuse. column43: Anne, our oldest volunteer, who is 106-years-old has been awarded an MBE for her charitable services after continuing to raise money for the NSPCC during the Coronavirus pandemic, also making her the oldest person to receive an MBE! “It was a great surprise and a great honour because I felt as if I didn’t deserve it at all. I love the NSPCC because they really look after families and I think that is so important especially nowadays when we are going through such difficult times. This last year the NSPCC has worked wonders and I’m really grateful to them.” Since the age of 95, Anne has hosted an annual garden party at her home with the help of friends, family and NSPCC volunteers, and guests have even included Childline Founder Dame Esther Rantzen. Each event has raised vital funds, helping us to be here for children who’ve needed us over the years. However, large gatherings out of the question last year because of the pandemic, but Anne didn’t let that stop her. Instead she set up a Just Giving Page for those who would have attended the event, and raised nearly £4,000! Anne was invited to join her local NSPCC committee over six decades ago, and has been involved in a wide range of different fundraising events and initiatives over that time. We thank Anne from the bottom of our hearts for so many decades of loyal support. Anne is an inspiration to us all, her smile lights up any room and her caring for children everywhere is appreciated. If you’re interested in fundraising for the NSPCC visit: http://bit.ly/39a0Zao:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/volunteering-nspcc-childline/

(Gender unknown, 10) Over the past ten months, our counsellors have heard first-hand the devastating impact that the coronavirus pandemic is having on young people’s mental health, including loneliness, low mood, low self-esteem, depression and anxiety. There have been 54,926 Childline counselling sessions since the start of the pandemic, helping to support children with their mental and emotional health. While the last year has been a struggle, we can do amazing things when we all join together – even if we have to keep our distance. Childline is continuing to support children despite the national lockdown, because when a child needs to talk, we need to be here to listen. column43: Throughout lockdown, it's more important than ever that we all play our part in keeping children safe. Emotional abuse is any type of abuse that involves the continual emotional mistreatment of a child. Emotional abuse can involve deliberately trying to scare, humiliate, isolate or ignore a child. Emotional abuse is often a part of other kinds of abuse, which means it can be difficult to spot the signs or tell the difference, though it can also happen on its own. Any child, from any background, can be at risk of emotional abuse so it's important to stay informed and be able to spot the signs. If you're worried about a child you know, we're here to help. Call our helpline team on 0808 800 5000 or email help@nspcc.org.uk. You can find out more about emotional abuse on our website: http://bit.ly/2EkHdgx:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-is-child-abuse/types-of-abuse/emotional-abuse/
column46: Age inappropriate behaviour Struggling to make or keep relationships Signs that a child could be experiencing emotional abuse Difficulty controlling their emotions Lack of self-confidence NSPCC

column43: Our Pregnancy In Mind service supports parents who are experiencing mental health issues, during and after pregnancy, giving them tools and strategies to help alleviate and manage their mental health difficulties. It can be difficult for men to speak out about their problems and practitioner Keith said: "I think men are less likely to speak out when they are struggling. Men tend to gloss over their own problems and focus instead on the difficulties that their partners are facing. It can be difficult for a lot of men to access services that are not specifically designed for them and are predominantly attended and run by women. It is important that men get support as they need to be well enough to support their partner, and to be able to build positive relationships with their newly born baby." We're fighting to ensure every parent, including every father, gets the support they need, so every baby can have a #FairStart: http://bit.ly/3m4BTQ9:=:https://e-activist.com/page/43747/data/1?ea.tracking.id=heicmx1i

column43: Last year was difficult for us all, and for many children, the uncertainty and worry from the pandemic has sadly taken a toll on their mental health. Now, we find ourselves in a tough situation again, more children are once again staying home, and thousands are struggling to cope. We know it’s hard, and we’re here to support families and lighten the load where we can. We want to answer every call, reach every child who needs us, and keep adapting to whatever challenges this year throws at us. Childline could be a child’s only source of support. We must be here for them. You can help by donating today http://bit.ly/2Mc7ams:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/ways-to-give/donate/?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=BC4496*&utm_content=rapid_response_2+launch+Jan21&ac=214144

column43: [Trigger warning: suicidal feelings] "After seeing my daughter suffer the way she did from low self-esteem, it was the thought of other children out there feeling the same.” As a mother, Lisa was inspired to volunteer with Childline while helping her daughter, Victoria, cope with ongoing bullying. Victoria was suffering with anxiety and depression after being bullied in primary school and it started to affect her school work. “She felt like life wasn’t worth living. It was the listening ear that was able to get Victoria to where she is now. Being able to open up to someone actually saved her.” Through volunteering, Lisa was able to gain additional knowledge and skills to help her daughter cope. “It’s the fact that Victoria has come through the other side. I just wanted to help other children.” During the pandemic, Childline has continued to adapt to ensure it can still be here for children, including developing online training so volunteers can answer emails from young people remotely. However, despite this, since last March volunteer numbers have dropped by 40%. Could you spare four hours a week to be here for children when they need us the most and volunteer with Childline? http://bit.ly/3oAvgG2:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/volunteering-nspcc-childline/volunteer-childline-helpline/#?utm_source=instagram&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=BC4449*&utm_content=vol21+childlinegeneric_eandw+Jan21&ac=
column46: "Childline don't judge, they listen and try to help."

column43: [Trigger warning: suicidal feelings and sexual abuse] This Children’s Mental Health Week and Sexual Abuse and Sexual Violence Awareness Week, we want to raise awareness of what the impact of abuse can have on a child’s mental health. Megan’s step-grandfather didn’t look after her like he should have. Instead, he sexually abused her from the age of four until 11. After enduring years of abuse, she told her parents to try to protect her younger siblings. “When I was 11-years-old, I really didn’t want to be alive. I felt I couldn’t go on anymore and I needed to tell someone. I was also getting frightened that he would potentially abuse my sisters. When he would help to bath them I would stand and watch him through the crack in the door to check they were safe. I credit my sisters with saving my life, because I wouldn’t have come forward if it wasn’t for them. There was no way I was ever going to let him abuse them. The only thing I had to hold on to after the abuse, was at least it was me and not them.” The abuse has had serious consequences on Megan’s mental health. “I started self-harming and made two suicide attempts when I was ten-years-old. I’ve suffered with panic attacks and depression for years. At the age of 27 I was diagnosed with complex PTSD and then dissociative disorder which means that I suffer from a series of PNES which are ‘psychological non epileptic seizures’ brought on by high levels of stress and anxiety. These are physical fits where I drop to the floor, they can easily last up to two hours and have at times lead me to be hospitalised. As well the physical factors of living with trauma, mentally it affects every aspect of my life and makes any type of relationship difficult. I want to share my story because seeing others share theirs, is what gave me the courage to come forward. I would like others to understand complex PTSD and other mental health disorders.” Megan had support from the NSPCC as a child and mental health support as an adult. She went back to the police to re-open her case, and sent her abuser to prison for 18 years, meaning Megan was able to begin her journey of recovery. #ItsNotOk
column46: "Abuse became my new normal" Megan

column43: There are many different types of abuse. Not every child who experiences abuse will encounter just one; different types of abuse can be experienced at the same time and more than once. If you're worried about a child, it can be hard to know what to do. It's important to educate ourselves on the different types of abuse that some children and young people may be experiencing as it can be make it easier to spot the signs and help us to understand what we can all do to help keep children safe. You can find out more about types of abuse on our website: https://bit.ly/3jHgED0:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/what-is-child-abuse/types-of-abuse/

It can be hard to recognise the signs of self-harm in children and teenagers, and understand it's difficult to know what to do if your child is struggliing with their mental and emotional health. column43: Since 2017 we’ve been campaigning for the Government to close the loophole and make it illegal for adults who hold a position of trust to have sex with 16 and 17-year-olds in their care. Today the Ministry of Justice have made a huge commitment in the new Police, Crime, Sentencing and Courts Bill that sports coaches and faith leaders in England and Wales will be held to the same standards as teachers, doctors, and social workers. Thank you to everyone who threw their weight behind our campaign. As lockdown lifts and children return to the extra-curricular activities, we hope to protect more children and young people at risk of grooming. Read more: http://bbc.in/3ciTmju:=:https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-56328874

column43: [Trigger warning: discusses mental health] "The best word to describe it was numb. It’s nothing to do with children in general, it’s how I feel about myself." Gary struggled with his mental health when he became a father, and he isn't alone. Up to 1 in 10 dads in the UK experience mental health issues during pregnancy and after birth. Access to emotional and psychological support during pregnancy and after birth is vital for all parents. Gary was put in touch with a group called the Dad’s Project, and he's found additional support through social media. "I know my father, growing up, he just wouldn’t talk. I’ve found there’s a few pages on social media where men will talk. If you can sit at home and talk to someone, it’s a lot easier than having to drive half an hour to go see somebody. It feels like a relief but we still worry that this person will now know all of our problems. Just because you have a mental health problem, doesn’t mean there’s something really bad or wrong with you. Accept help. If someone offers it to you it’s because they care. If you’re struggling, just be open and honest and say, I’m really struggling." Right now, getting the right support at the right time isn’t guaranteed. That's why our Fight for a #FairStart campaign is calling on governments across the UK to help parents, like Gary, make sure mental health support is in place at every stage throughout pregnancy and after birth – from the first check-up through to specialist help if needed. Sign the petition here: https://bit.ly/3dLPbPQ:=:https://e-activist.com/page/75431/petition/1?ea.tracking.id=Facebook
column46: "If you're struggling, be open and honest and say, I'm really struggling." Gary, Dad

column43: [Trigger warning: this post mentions suicidal feelings and post-natal mental health] "I couldn’t cope anymore. It just felt like every day was the same and it was never going to get better." After the birth of her son, Leanne struggled with her mental health. "It started as soon as he was born pretty much. I was expecting to feel this amazing love for him and it would all be great and I’d be crying in happiness about how lovely it all was, but I didn’t feel like that. I just felt quite flat." I didn’t think it would happen to someone like me. I always thought, no, I’m strong enough that I’d be able to cope with all of that." Despite struggling to ask for support, eventually, Leanne sought professional help. "I felt quite uncomfortable talking about my feelings. In the end, one day I just rang up and left a message for her to call me. And when she called me, I just said I really don’t want to be here anymore, and that’s how I feel every day. I think once I’d realised that actually they’re just there to support generally, that was when I started accepting it. And then once I’d done that I wished I’d done it so much sooner!" Leanne spoke to us about what she believes would help new parents and professionals. "Better education for parents and for healthcare professionals that are looking after those parents, so that they feel equipped to speak to parents in the right way, or they feel equipped to support parents and to pick up on it." For any parent who is struggling right now, Leanne wants you to know there's hope. "It might feel really hard now, but there is light at the end of the tunnel, no matter how hopeless it is, support is there, and it does get easier and it does get better." Right now, getting the right support at the right time isn’t guaranteed. Our Fight for a #FairStart campaign is calling on governments across the UK to help parents, like Leanne, by ensuring mental health support is in place. Sign the petition here: https://bit.ly/3dLPbPQ:=:https://e-activist.com/page/75431/petition/1?ea.tracking.id=Facebook
column46: "There's no such thing as the perfect mum. Doing your best is more than enough." Leanne, Mum

column43: You might have heard the heartbreaking stories being shared through 'Everyone’s Invited'. With at least a third of sexual offences against children being committed by other young people, it's vital this is addressed. A new NSPCC helpline with the Department for Education is available from today. It's here for both children and adults who are victims of recent or historic sexual harassment and abuse in schools or education. All children should be able to grow up in a safe community that is free from sexual violence, where their rights are respected. You can contact us on 0800 136 663 or help@nspcc.org.uk for support and advice. In an emergency, call 999.
