column43: [Trigger warning: discusses post-natal mental health] "When we took her home, I developed this fear that she was going to die. I didn’t sleep and, I was exhausted. I felt like I had to keep up this act that everything was perfect and that I was happy all the time. I wanted to be happy. And I really really loved my baby." After the birth of her daughter, Natalie began to struggle with her mental health. She found it difficult to ask for support, and believes there should be investment so health visitors are better able to spot new parents who are struggling. "When the health visitors came round, they were lovely. They’d ask if I was okay or feeling down, and I’d say no, because I wasn’t. So I didn’t tell anyone. I think they’re so rushed, the health visitors, and they don’t know you, so they don’t know if the behaviour you’re exhibiting is normal for you. It’s difficult for the mother and for the health visitor. I think consistent pre and postnatal care would be beneficial. That obviously needs investment." Eventually Natalie sought help from a doctor and wants other parents to know there's support available. "It doesn’t matter if you muddle through. Stop being so hard on yourself. And if you need help, ask for help." It takes less than a minute to sign our petition and demand better mental health support for new parents, like Natalie. Sign our petition: https://bit.ly/3dLPbPQ
column46: "I didn't want anyone to think I wasn't coping." Natalie, Mum

column43: Neglect is the ongoing failure to meet a child's basic needs. A child might be left hungry or dirty, or without proper clothing, shelter, supervision or health care. This can put children and young people in danger, and can also have long-term effects on their physical and mental wellbeing. Every child deserves to be loved, cared for and protected, but 1 in 10 children have experienced neglect. It can be difficult to spot the signs of neglect. If you're worried about a child, contact us on 0808 800 5000 or help@nspcc.org.uk Share this post to help us spread awareness.
column46: Housing & family issues Health & development problems Signs of neglect NSPCC Change in behaviour Unwashed or unsuitable clothing

column43: [Trigger warning: mentions online grooming] When Mared was 14, she was groomed on Facebook. "I was getting messages from guys in their early and mid-20s. You don’t think that’s weird at the time because these older guys have friends that you know of, or live in the same kind of area as you, so it doesn’t seem creepy. I hadn’t had any attention from boys before. Lads my age were bullying me and taking the mick out of me." "At first, I was sent messages like ‘Hey, how are you?” and “You know some of my mates” and “Are you in school?”’. As the weeks went on, they started sending messages that became more and more sexual, commenting on my figure, making sexual comments and asking me for pictures." Mared told us why she didn't feel like she could speak to an adult about it. "I thought I’d get into trouble for talking about sex with a guy. Looking back now, it’s scary to think that I sent semi-naked pictures to older guys." "We need to get the message across that not every predator looks the same. Not all predators are decades older, it wasn’t the case for me and my friends, but it was still adults grooming children. Perhaps if someone had told me at the time that what was happening to me was not right, if there had been more awareness of this, I would have questioned it sooner." By sharing her story, Mared is helping us call on the Government to end the #WildWestWeb and protect young people from abuse online. We’re looking for more people like Mared to share their story. If you have one to share, please visit: https://bit.ly/2QbfPb8:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/campaigns/wild-west-web/#share
column46: "Not every predator looks the same. realised how wrong it had been for those men to talk to me." me W Mared

column43: Do you believe children have a right to be safe from abuse online? Current plans for end-to-end encryption means many offenders would be able to use popular social media platforms and messaging apps to share child abuse images and target children without being detected. It's vital that tech companies develop new child safety solutions if they plan on rolling out end-to-end encryption on their services. Our new research found that if companies can protect children’s safety, support for the rollout of end-to-end encryption almost doubles, from 33% to 62%. Read more here: bit.ly/3sx4Jua:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/globalassets/documents/news/e2ee-pac-report-end-to-end-encryption.pdf

column43: Calls to our helpline have risen to record levels during the pandemic. And with most young people now back in schools, the harm and trauma faced by some children in the past year will become increasingly visible. We want governments across the UK to focus on prevention and protecting children from abuse and neglect both online and offline, delivering a supportive environment in the early years and ensuring services are available to help children recover from traumatic experiences. We must all come together and play our part in keeping children safe. Read more: https://bbc.in/33c3wi1:=:https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/education-56917654

column43: "When my eldest son was born, I felt very excited and blessed. At the same time, I felt lost. It was confusing; I had all the positives about having a new baby on the one hand but the stress and ongoing feeling of being dismissed as a ‘paranoid’ new mum alongside this. I’d been so anxious towards the end of my pregnancy that I often struggled to get out of bed." When Jasmine brought her son home, she noticed he was vomiting more than usual, but struggled to get medical support. "My son was finally diagnosed with severe reflux, as well as cows’ milk and soya allergies. As a result of how my concerns had been dismissed I became very protective and anxious when it came to my son. All I wanted was to be able to celebrate being a mum. I became pregnant with my second baby seven months after my first and, following my previous experiences still didn’t feel able to enjoy pregnancy the way I’d hoped to." After struggling to get medical support for her son, Jasmine met her Health Visitor Wendy, who she thanks for supporting her throughout her pregnancies. "Wendy is an amazing human being. She told me I was doing really well, reassured me and encouraged me. Her visit made me feel happy and confident. I think if I hadn’t been able to get to know her and build that bond, my anxiety would have worsened. I was able to be honest with her and that made a huge difference. When I’d struggled with my feelings before, I’d never told people. It was a hard thing to do, so it had to be with someone like Wendy who I felt comfortable with and came to know well. She helped me truly enjoy being a mum, and I’ll never forget her." Jasmine is now part of an organisation where parents share their stories to support one another. "I got involved with an organisation called Dope Black Mums, and that’s really helped show me the impact someone sharing their experiences can have on others. I’m sharing my story for the NSPCC’s Fight for a #FairStart campaign to raise awareness that welcoming a new baby isn’t always simple, but that doesn’t mean there won’t be a positive outcome when we open up and can access support when we need it." This #MaternalMentalHealthAwarenessMonth help us ensure all mums like Jasmine get the support they need, at the right time: https://bit.ly/3dLPbPQ:=:https://e-activist.com/page/75431/petition/1?ea.tracking.id=Facebook
column46: "I'd been so anxious towards the end of my pregnancy that I often struggled to get out of struggledtogetoutofbed.' bed." Jasmine

column43: Since 2017, over 46,000 supporters have joined us in campaigning for legislation to better protect children online. Today, the Government published a draft Online Safety Bill - but as it stands, it risks failing to effectively respond to the very real threat of child abuse. Unless the Government stands firm on their promise to put child safety at the front and centre of the Bill, many children will continue to be exposed to harm and sexual abuse in their everyday lives, when this could be avoided. The Government must deliver on a transformative Online Safety Bill that children and families deserve. Find out more: https://bit.ly/33AwpnV:=:https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/internet-child-safety-online-harms-b1845467.html

column43: We are looking for more people like Megan to share their stories and help us end the #WildWestWeb 👇. Trigger warning: self-harm and eating disorders. "A group of girls I was friends with turned on me overnight. It escalated to online bullying, then a boy started physically bullying me. My mum knew that I was suffering from anxiety and not eating properly. What they didn’t know was that I was self-harming. To help me cope I often visited Childline and chatted to online counsellors." Megan's parents eventually found out about her self-harming and got her professional help. "I told my parents I couldn’t deal with the bullying, so I moved schools. My first day was nerve wracking but everyone was really nice and there was a frenzy of people adding me on social media. I ended up adding a boy who was a year above me. He started messaging me on Facebook, Instagram, and Snapchat. Then one night he asked me if I would send him a picture of myself naked. I said no. For four days it was constant pressure. I was desperate to be liked so in the end I sent him an image of me naked via Snapchat. A message appeared. It was a photo of a girl in my year group with the words ‘Haha I’ve got you’. She had taken a photo of the image I had sent on her phone and had been using the boy’s social media accounts to communicate with me. I panicked and turned my phone off. The next morning I had loads of text messages. I ignored them and went to school but as soon as I arrived people started crowding round me holding up their phones with the photo of me on the screen and print outs of it." As a result, Megan began to struggle with her mental and emotional health again. "I started self-harming again, not eating properly and isolating myself. I turned to Childline to help me cope. I truly believe if it wasn’t for Childline I wouldn’t be here today." Megan is working hard to raise awareness around the pressures of sexting. "Life is good now. I give talks about my ordeal at schools, charity and government events and police training sessions to help them understand how best to handle cases similar to mine. Even if I can help just one person through everything that I do then it’s worth it." All young people, like Megan have the right to be safe online from sexual abuse. If you want to help us protect more young people through our campaigning by sharing your story, visit: https://bit.ly/2QbfPb8:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/campaigns/wild-west-web/#share
column46: NSPCC "I was suffering from anxiety, not eating properly & self-harming To help me cope I often visited Childline and chatted to online counsellors." Megan

column43: Warning – this post contains mentions of sexual harassment Since April 1st, the ‘Report Abuse in Education’ helpline - commissioned by the Department for Education for reporting child abuse and harassment in education settings - has received 353 calls. Sexual abuse, exploitation and harassment by peers is the most common issue reported to the helpline so far, ranging from incidents such as pupils looking up classmates’ skirts to sharing indecent images and rape. We know speaking out can be a very difficult decision to make. “I want all victims of abuse to be supported and feel confident to report any allegations. That is exactly why we set up this additional helpline.” - Education Secretary Gavin Williamson The helpline is available to child and adult victims of abuse in schools to make current and non-recent disclosures as well as witnesses, parents and carers with concerns or professionals looking for advice. To get in contact with the Report Abuse in Education helpline call 0800 136 663 or email help@nspcc.org.uk

column43: “From the mess of the place I hadn’t thought for one moment that there were any children in the house. When I saw her my heart just sank.” Brad was concerned when he spotted a toddler during a home visit. He acted fast and called one the NSPCC helpline. The practitioner he spoke to contacted the police who worked with children’s services to get the child to safety. She went to live with her grandmother so she could be cared for until things had changed at home, and it was safe for her to return Join us as we take a moment to recognise Brad and others who have taken action, for helping us protect every childhood. 🙌 We all have a role to play in protecting children, and together we are stronger 💪 louder🎤 and smarter 🧠 Please share Brad’s story and inspire others to stand up for every child and young person. Together, we can stop child abuse and neglect. You can also help us raise money and protect children this #ChildhoodDay https://bit.ly/3aOzQvi:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/events-fundraising/childhood-day/play?utm_source=facebook&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=BF4795*&utm_content=ChildhoodDay+SocialContent_MPT+Apr21&ac=
column46: Trigger warning: neglect Brad was working as a TV engineer when he visited a house and spotted a toddler who was being severely severely neglected. "As soon as left the house, found the number for the NSPCC's helpline and called. They asked me all the right questions and they acted straight away." Brad

column43: After the year we’ve just experienced, we could all do with a bit more play. Our latest research found that 68% of parents think play has become more important for their children since the start of the COVID-19 pandemic. During the pandemic children have done more arts, crafts and activities like reading, drawing and painting - they’ve played more online and also played more pretend-based games like dress-up and acting-out stories. We’re teaming up with Sky to encourage people to play their part this Childhood Day and give more children a great summer and a brighter future. “We hope to harness the power of Sky’s platforms to increase awareness of the NSPCC’s vital work and the importance of safeguarding children.” - Lyssa McGowan, Chief Consumer Officer at Sky However you play, play your part this #ChildhoodDay on 11th June: https://bit.ly/3vGZMSa:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/events-fundraising/childhood-day/?utm_source=SKY&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=BG4999*&utm_content=CL_May+Sky_CHD+May21&ac=

column43: Trigger warning – the following post mentions stories of suicide, emotional and mental health. “The night before I was discharged I tried to take my own life. That was the first time I called Childline. The counsellor started asking me about the things I like to do. Afterwards I was able to talk calmly about what had happened. That chat stopped me from going back to my room and trying again.” Hollie, struggled with her mental health and after she suffered a panic attack, within a matter of months she had deteriorated so much she had dropped out of school, isolated herself from her friends and been admitted to hospital. When she turned to Childline, our counsellors were there to listen and help her. “When I was back at home, I still wasn’t talking to people but whenever I was feeling low I would go to the shed and call Childline – they were the only people I would speak to. Childline gave me the confidence to write a note to my mum asking if I could see a counsellor. It was that counsellor who, after two and half years of silence, finally got me talking again. If I hadn’t called Childline there is a chance I wouldn’t be here today. In fact, all the progress I have made is thanks to other people’s support, including Childline.” Our Childline volunteers are the beating heart of what we do and without them, we couldn’t help children and young people like Hollie, who need us. Drop a heart 💚 below for the counsellors who were here for Hollie. To find out if there are any volunteering opportunities near you, visit: https://bit.ly/34qrkPw:=:https://join-us.nspcc.org.uk/volunteers/vacancy/find/results/?utm_source=linkedin&utm_medium=social&utm_campaign=BH4966*&utm_content=VolJun21+LinkedIn+Jun21&ac=

column43: We want all young people to have a safe and positive experience online. But we know that some are more at risk of having a negative experience than others. The internet can offer LGBTQ+ young people a sense of belonging and community; a space where they can explore their own identity. Sadly, it can also be a place where they are exposed to bullying or inappropriate content. This World Pride Month, read our Net Aware article for some top tips on keeping LGBTQ+ young people safe online. https://bit.ly/3prbpdD:=:https://www.net-aware.org.uk/news/helping-to-keep-all-children-safe-online-this-pride-month/

column43: “Looking back, I’d tell my 12-year-old self that you can talk to people – they will believe you. Whatever your doubts, nothing will ever defy the bond you have with certain people. I think everyone has got somebody who they can trust, who will listen to them and believe them. They just need to identify who that person is and tell them.” We’d like to thank Amber* for sharing her powerful story with us. Tomorrow, Friday June 11th, we’re asking the UK to join us in celebrating Childhood Day and to raise funds so that we can continue to support young people just like Amber*. If you’ve not yet signed up, follow this link to find out more: https://bit.ly/3aPSHWR *Names have been changed to protect identity.
column46: Trigger warning: sexual abuse Amber* was sexually abused by a close family member from the age of nine. By 12, she was so traumatised that she decided to contact Childline and tell a teacher at school. NSPCC

column43: "Childline could have helped Liam. Speaking anonymously to a trained counsellor might have made the difference for him, it could have saved his life.” In 2012, Aaron set up The Liam Charity in his brother’s memory and through that, has raised just over an incredible £250,000 for Childline through various fundraisers. On top of all the fundraising, Aaron is also now a volunteer Childline counsellor, listening to children and young people when they have nowhere else to go. All his support will help us to continue to do what we do, and we're so proud of everything Aaron has done, and we know Liam would be too. Leave a 💚 below to help us thank Aaron for his inspiring dedication.

column43: [Trigger warning: mentions mental health] "The best word to describe it was numb. I had no feelings towards anything in particular. But there was still so much of me that loved them. And always would have, and always will, but I was just numb." We spoke to Gary about about the difficulties some dads face when they struggle with their mental health after the birth of their child, and the difference speaking to someone can have. "I know my father, growing up, he just wouldn’t talk. He wouldn’t tell his problems to anybody. Just because you have a mental health problem, doesn’t mean there’s something really bad or wrong with you. Accept help. If someone offers it to you it’s because they care. Whether that be they’re at your front door, or they’re contacting you through social media. If they’re opening up to you first, they’re doing it because that’s the goodness of their heart. Just be open and honest and say, I’m really struggling." This #FathersDay we're fighting so all dads get the support they need, at the right time to improve outcomes for them and their babies. "Our reality wasn’t picture perfect. Lots of new parents need mental health support. Will you join me?" https://bit.ly/3bVXjKs:=:https://www.nspcc.org.uk/support-us/campaigns/fight-for-a-fair-start/

column48:
Last Friday, we were at it again with delivering food boxes to military family members. This time, at Whiteman Air Force Base, all thanks to our partners at Coalition to Salute America's Heroes and Feed the Children.

With the help of volunteers and key leaders in the community, we were able to deliver 150 non perishable food and hygiene boxes to military families in need. 

"I didn't know about Blue Star Families before this event. Now that I know, I definitely want to volunteer more because I feel like I am doing something that matters," expressed Airmen First Class Seguga Guerrero.

We can definitely do more together. 

If you aren't a member of Blue Star Families, here's a link to join us: www.bluestarfam.org/join:=:https://bluestarfam.org/join/

column48:
At Seekonk Speedway this morning with some amazing volunteers, Representative Steven Howitt and local officials to kick-off an event that will provide many local families with the supplies they need now more than ever. 

Feed the Children, Price Rite of Seekonk and Angels Care Closet are providing $100,000 worth of Food, Essentials, Personal Care items, Fresh Produce and Disney Children's books to 1,600 low income individuals struggling with food insecurity during the Covid-19 crisis. Additionally, they are providing 800 backpacks filled with schools supplies to help kids with the start of the school year.

Price Rite and Feed the Children have been stepping up for years to do this in locations throughout the Country. Their partnership with Angels Care Closet and Seekonk Speedway today will benefit many local families dealing with food insecurity in this pandemic and economic crisis.

Across the country, nearly 30 million children rely on free or reduced lunches. Unfortunately, not all of them are able to take advantage of feeding programs that have been set up by schools as a result of COVID-19.

Our foundation and Allen Hurns are working with the Miami Dolphins to support Feed the Children this summer. Feed the Children works with a network of community partners across the country to provide food and essentials to those who don’t have a stable source of nutrition during the summer months.

To give back to those who are facing hunger due to having their lives turned upside down this
year, please visit http://www.feedthechildren.org.:=:http://default.pub30.convio.net/

column46: Children have a right to give or refuse consent to having their picture taken. Children have a right to know no one should ever take a picture of them in their underwear, or nude. MAMA EFFECT S BEAR
column48:
I am posting this with the hope that every parent, caregiver, grandparent, babysitter, etc. understands how serious this message is for the safety of children. 

While we know that images of child sexual abuse have sky-rocketed in distribution over recent years, much of it being shared through social media, we also know something equally disturbing . 

The vast majority of people who exploit children online are parents, stepparents, and people who LIVE within the same home as the child. 

I came across a news story this evening that I will not share because it will be very triggering for many, but this epidemic is not going away, if anything, I fear it is getting worse. 

Teach children as soon as they are able to understand, that they have a right to say 'no' to being photographed. Children are photographed more than any other generation - while this is a benefit to parents who want to be able to capture every moment, children are also normalizing having every moment of their day captured and also shared on social media. 

Teach children that NO ONE should take a picture of them when they are not fully dressed. It may seem harmless to take photos of them in the bath, on the toilet or running around in underwear, but the rate we are learning children, especially young children exploited is at the point we should be considering child sexual abuse a national emergency. 

These children often have no idea that what is happening to them is wrong, and these predators are smart enough to take steps that make it very difficult to track them down. 

This has to become a movement, because we the good people of this earth have the most opportunity to protect children, with awareness and care for the people we know to educate them on this risk. This is not a "parent" issue this is an everyone issue - if you know children, make sure they know their rights - if their own parent is abusing them, it's that much harder for them to disclose and get help. But with the knowledge that they can get help to make it stop, we can help stop abuse from continuing. 

There are no guarantees, there are no fail-safe methods, but we cannot let this devastation of innocent life go on without doing what we can to stop it. 

When people sexually violate a child, they also violate the trust of the other adults who desire to protect that child, their faith and goodness is also exploited. 

People may attack us and say we're infringing on the rights of parents to take photos of their children as they see fit, but we urge you to consider the underlying message children are hearing when we don't respect their privacy and their desire to not be photographed. Imagine if we did the same to another adult? Imagine if another person took and shared pictures of us without our consent? 

Children are citizens of this world and by their innocence, they require more protections for their rights, not less. 

~Adrianne Simeone
Founder, Executive Director 

www.TheMamaBearEffect.org:=:https://themamabeareffect.org/

column48:
Happy International Women's Day 🎉
Today we're giving the mic to some of the amazing women in our team who will share words about work/life balance, challenges during the pandemic and more!

Meet our very powerful Procurement Officer, Mona Saad

"I've been working at Tdh for 19 years, it used to be very hard to balance work and life because I used to travel a lot in my early years. But now since I got married and had kids, I have a clear system to organize myself. I wake up at 6 am to prepare my children's meals, then I go to work and when I get back I have to do the same to make sure that they're fed and doing their homework. 

My job is very challenging but very rewarding at the same time, one time years ago I received a call of appreciation from the Minister's secretariat of the Ministry of Justice, this made me feel that my hard work pays off. During the pandemic, its exceptionally hard when my kids have exams because I have to make sure they're safe when they go to their lessons.

Work means a lot to me, and specially working in development, hearing the stories of people, this gives me strength and makes me feel like I'm in the right place, the smiles of children and youth I met, all this gives me purpose and drive. I remember I used to cry a lot when I heard the stories of children we worked with, but then I realized that tears won't help make anything change, hard work will. So this powers me to be able to do all this work.

I think the only way to be able to balance work and life is to choose a job that is fulfilling to us, I want to encourage people and women who are worried about working in development. I want to say that it is a very rewarding field and it will give you strength, faith and purpose that you never imagined" 

Stay tuned for more!

column48:
Για τα παιδιά που αγωνίζονται να επιβιώσουν κάθε μέρα της ζωής τους, θα μιλήσουμε σήμερα. Για τα παιδιά που ταξιδεύουν ολομόναχα. Περνάνε, βουνά, πεδιάδες και ερήμους, ρίχνονται στη θάλασσα. Για τα παιδιά που αν «σωθούν», καταλήγουν στα κέντρα κράτησης, κοιμούνται στις πλατείες, εκπορνεύονται στο δρόμο.
 Η Σοφία Κουβελάκη, γενική διευθύντρια του οργανισμού The HOME project The HOME Project  μας εξηγεί πως γίνεται  αυτά τα παιδιά στην Ελλάδα να ξεφύγουν από την κόλαση και να ζήσουν μια κανονική ζωή. Να έχουν ένα σπίτι, να πηγαίνουν σχολείο ακόμα και να σπουδάσουν. Απόψε στις 23.00, στο Πρώτο Πρόγραμμα, στους 91,6 και στους 105,8,  στην εκπομπή «Στο ντιβάνι της κρίσης». Με τις μουσικές της Σοφίας Κουβελάκη.

column48:
🚀 Inspire. Enable. Engage!

🤩 We are excited for the Global Youth Summit! 

🗓️ 23-25 April 2021

On Day 2, Saturday @ 17:15 (GMT), #CovidUnder19, Terre des hommes, London School of Economics, and the International Institute of Child Rights and Development will be facilitating a breakout session "Claim your rights in the digital world!" 

The session will focus on sharing evidence on children’s online experiences during the pandemic and present concrete resources to empower children & young people online. The session will end with a call to action, signposting participants towards concrete steps that they can take to claim their rights in the digital environment.

Learn more about the program and register for the Summit broadcast and get updates ➡️ https://globalyouthmobilization.org/global-youth-summit/

See you all then!

#youthmobilize

column48:
These past days we have been on the ground in Puri district, where we are visiting our activities under our Project titled ‘Post cyclone Fani integrated shelter response in Odisha’ which is being implemented 
by our partner Gram-Utthan TI Project with funding support from Swiss Solidarity. 
It has been remarkable to sit with community members, and the project field teams to understand all of the lessons learnt and results achieved, despite the multifaceted challenges that were posed by Covid-19, cyclone Amphan and implementing consturction activities within one of the wettest monsoons experienced in over 10 years. A huge credit and heartfelt thanks to our partner Gram Uttan and their dedicated and committed field team, and to the community members who took ownership of this project and helped the team to overcome challenges using their local knowledge and networks. 🙏🏼🙏🏼🙏🏼

column48:
🇺🇦 Young people in Eastern Ukraine are motivated to participate in their communities' life, but they often lack skills and supporters among peers and adults.

👩‍🏫 We train teachers to promote and support youth's civic engagement. Trainings include topics such as democracy, human rights, tolerance and non-discrimination, journalism and communication skills. 

🙌 Using the acquired knowledge, educators will then train at least 200 young people to be active members in their communities.

🆒 The trainings are part of the "YOUNG CITIZENS – Community engagement of young people in East Ukraine" project, implemented by Terre des hommes - Україна under the USAID Democratic Governance in Eastern Ukraine/ Демократичне врядування у Східній Україні project, funded by USAID - US Agency for International Development.

Learn more 👉 http://tdh-europe.org/our-work/young-citizens--community-engagement-of-young-people-in-east-ukraine/7146

column48:
👌 🇬🇷 Our Constr.Act Labs in Greece tackle #COVID19 in the most creative way! Terre des hommes Ηellas  - Γη των ανθρώπων set up these spaces, which are based on the FabLab model, in refugee camps and safe zones in the Attica region to support the wellbeing of refugee children and youth.

🧵 Here, children and young people learn how to use sewing machines, laser cutters and 3D printers to make masks, visors and other protective equipment that will be distributed amongst their community, as well as to the frontline workers.  

🆒 They will also create clothes, toys, fitness equipment, gardening tools and anything else they can imagine to meet the needs and desires of the people living in the camps. 

🧘 At the same time, the ConstrAct Lab participants will attend our informative and creative activities to learn how to stay safe during the pandemic, but also how to manage its effects on their mental health, which unfortunately, keeps worsening due to their particular living conditions.     

💪 The children hosted in the Schisto Safe Zone already had the opportunity to get acquainted with the sewing machines and choose the fabric they liked to create their own mask, step by step.
✅ Of course, we followed the specifications set by the World Health Organization (WHO), so our masks have 3 layers of fabric of different composition to provide the maximum possible protection from COVID-19. 

👖 During the workshop, the children could also repair their clothes using our FabLab equipment. 

🙌 Those who were already familiar with the use of sewing machines were happy to reconnect with an activity they love, and they willingly helped others and contributed to the conduct of the workshop. The ones who were new to this activity found the challenge and experience enjoyable and want to do it again!  

🤩 However, the best thing about our meetings is what we share and how this makes the children's time really count. They get to know each other better, they feel creative, they relax with music and tea and… they are looking forward to the next time! 

ℹ️ Constr.Act Lab is funded by Direct Relief and we implement it as part of our child protection services - with an emphasis on mental health and psychosocial support - for families and unaccompanied children living in refugee camps and safe zones in the Attica region. The child protection services are provided in collaboration with DRC Greece, IOM Greece and with the support of the European Commission Asylum, Immigration and Integration Fund #AMIF #DGHOME #EUHomeAffairs. The recent Constr.Act Lab activities were carried out in collaboration with ARSIS - Association for the Social Support of Youth under the supervision of which is the Safe Zone in Schisto.

column48:
🇸🇾 Today, 15 March, marks the 10th anniversary of the Syrian conflict, one of the worst humanitarian crises in recent history. #Syria10 A decade of violence that has forced more than five million people to flee their country in the hope of finding some security. 

❗️ One million Syrian children were born as refugees since 2011. 🇬🇷 Among them are the three children of Nasrin, 29, a Syrian woman who lives in the Veria refugee camp in Greece. Nasrin’s older daughter of 5 years never spoke due to trauma. 

🧡 Read the story of Nasrin and her family to learn about the difficulties they went and go through, their memories of Syria, and hopes for a peaceful and healthy future. 

🤲 In Veria, as well as in seven other mainland camps, Terre des hommes Ηellas  - Γη των ανθρώπων offers child protection services and works to ensure that families receive support and children grow up in the best possible conditions.

🗣 "My name is Nasrin, I am 29 years old and I am a recognized refugee from Syria. I have been in Greece for two years now with my three children and my husband who is also a Syrian refugee. We did not come to Greece directly from Syria, but from Kurdish Iraq where we lived in a camp with my husband and where my first daughter, who is now 5 years old, was born. My other two children are 3 years and 9 months old.

Life was very difficult in post-war Syria. There was no safety in our village – near the town of Qamishli on the borders with Turkey. It was abandoned by its residents and it was impossible to find work, everything became very expensive, we had to leave. It was a difficult journey, and the situation was aggravated by the fact that our families did not want this marriage. We had to get married against their will and hide because my brother was threatening to kill me. We had to live all alone for a long time in a forest, without electricity, to stay alive. But even after the child was born, we were left alone in the woods, surviving only on some bread. In these circumstances, I lost a pregnancy due to miscarriage. I did not even know I was pregnant.

We passed from Turkey to Lesvos island in Greece and stayed at the Moria camp in a tent with two blankets. We slept on a wooden pallet and so I got problems with my back. Then we moved to Veria, to this camp where mainly Syrians, recognized refugees, live. We are currently waiting for our travel documents to be processed, in order to leave for Germany.

I have pinned all my hopes on this journey. I wish to be in a house, so that I and my family can rest. But most of all, I am hoping for a cure for my daughter, who never spoke. She was eight months old when we left the forest and went to live in a village, in a ruin, before ending up in a camp in Iraq. When she was 2 years old, we found out that she could not speak. She is now 5, and the problem has not yet been remedied. Her mental state is very bad. She cries, takes off her clothes, does not eat, does not play.

I hope that with the help of our relatives who live in Germany, my brother-in-law and my uncle, we will be able to access treatment. My husband in Syria worked at the market, sometimes selling vegetables, sometimes doing small chores. I hope he will find something to do to earn a living. I have worked as a child, with my father, in the fields.

Although things in Greece are better than before, you cannot call it a normal life. The fatigue is intense, the routine too, we sit all day in our container without being able to do anything. Living in such a small space with three children is very difficult, not only now, because of the pandemic, but it has been like this ever since we came.

I miss Syria and my village very much. When I left, I took some photos from when I was a child and the place where we lived. I think about it and tears come to my eyes. But the photos were left behind in Iraq, and now I miss them so much, it was the only thing I had to remember what I left behind. I miss my family too. My two brothers, with whom our relationship has been restored, are both disabled, and my father is blind. All of them are left behind, refugees in Iraq.

Terre des hommes has helped us a lot. They supported us in our effort to gain access to the local hospital for my baby who has trouble with movement and also covered medical expenses with private doctors, and also with my older daughter: Tdh psychologist is offering her mental health and psychosocial support sessions that are very helpful and contributed a lot to improving her condition. They also helped us with baby milk and medicine. Additionally, Tdh legal team offered us counselling to tackle procedures that were necessary. May we find similar support when we reach our destination.

I talk to my children about Syria, I tell them about my village and their grandparents. But they are still too young, they cannot understand. I do not care about anything, not even the pandemic, all I care about is for my daughter to get well, to be (truncated)

column48:
🎨 Red, green, yellow, blue... Life loves colour and colour is very much needed in the grey refugee camps. 🇬🇷 This is why our team in the open accommodation site in Koutsochero, Greece, decided to transform the dull cement corridors that facilitate the access of people with mobility impairments and of parents carrying prams.

🤩 To make the way to our offices a bit more fun, we painted a hopscotch playground as bright as could be. Since that day, the bland corridor has been all about laughing and playing and loved by children as well as by adults who feel like children.
 
🙌🏾 Even small things like this help at least 40 families build resilience and keep their hope for a better life. Our teams also provide these families with psychosocial and legal support within the framework of our child protection project.

ℹ️ Terre des hommes Ηellas  - Γη των ανθρώπων implements the child protection project in eight open refugee accommodation sites, in partnership with DRC Greece and IOM Greece, with support from the Asylum, Migration and Inclusion Fund #AMIF European Union #DGHOME #EUHome Affairs. 

🧡 Find out more here: http://tdh-europe.org/our-work/child-protection-for-refugees-in-mainland-greece/7150

column43: On 22 July 1960, Edmond Kaiser founded Terre des hommes, appalled by the suffering of the children victims of the Algeria war. In his charter, he made a promise: “As long as a child remains hungry, sick, abandoned, in misery or in pain, whoever and wherever s/he may be, the Terre des hommes movement, created for this reason, will pledge itself to the child’s immediate and complete rescue.” 6⃣0⃣ years later, our mission remains unchanged. We are committed to protecting children and defending their rights around the world, while constantly adapting our working methods. 🔗 Learn more about our history: www.tdh.ch/60years:=:https://www.tdh.ch/en/terre-hommes-celebrates-its-60th-anniversary

column48:
#COVID-19 #response 🇨🇭🤝🇧🇩 
Switzerland supports Terre des hommes in providing health services to Rohingya refugees and host communities in order to mitigate the effects of COVID-19. Terre des hommes facilitates the management of Teknaf’s Primary Health Center and has equipped it with 4 isolation beds and 2 emergency ambulances. The Centre remains fully operational during the pandemic, operating as pre-isolation and 24/7 referral point in coordination with the health authorities of Teknaf Upazila. This initiative is part of Switzerland’s BDT 70+ crore COVID-response support to Bangladesh à https://bit.ly/2UAmtXs:=:https://www.facebook.com/swissembassy.dhaka/posts/3035788293166866

column48:
Congratulations to our partner Praajak and all the girls who competed in our 2nd annual Kabaddi tournament, which was held last Friday in Kolkata. The tournament is part of our joint project titled 'Using Kabaddi to empower girls at risk of or affected by unsafe migration in West Bengal, India' where the main objective is to use Sport as a tool to empower and raise girls’ confidence so that they can make safer choices, whereby they can ultimately work towards creating a future they want to lead, which is void of child marriage, child labour, gender based violence and trafficking.

On Friday we were able to launch the 'Kabaddi for Protection Model’ which is an adaptation/contextualization of Tdh’s global Sports for Protection methodology. This methodology will be available and open source to all stakeholders and partners working in this space. 

In the Tournament the Siliguri team took home the Champions cup, however each of these girls are winners in their own rights and we couldn't be more proud of their determined and feisty approach to life.
Comic Relief: Red Nose Day and Terre des hommes UK

column48:
We held our first community screening of ‘Still I Rise’ infront of community members and 13 members from a survivors collective in West Bengal. It is important for us to get feedback from survivors on weather they felt the film represented their voice with truth and authenticity. The positive response we received was validating and encouraging.🌺 

“I was moved and could relate to how Amrah expressed how she felt when she was sold and trafficked and how after returning home the belief and strength she had within herself which helped her to rise as a “Bhaghini” (tigress), become less isolated and it also helped others around her” (survivors testimonial)

To view Still I Rise, click on the link here 🌺 https://vimeo.com/477015590 

Carousel media & Jeni Lee 🙏🏼

*photograph taken with informed consent and survivor is above 18 years of age*

column48:
Though the last three inspections only required minimal adjustments, on Wednesday the Italian coast guard detained our ship. Their reasoning? The Ocean Viking has carried more people on board than the number it is licensed to carry. We saved too many lives.

However, according to maritime law, people rescued from distress at sea are not to be considered "passengers" but "survivors". This is blatant harassment.

👉 Sign our petition now and demand the Italian authorities to release the Ocean Viking immediately! Link in the comment section.

📷 Laila Sieber

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Read here our joint statement written together with the other Child 10 2020 Awardees and Child10, in support of the findings and recommendations to states laid down in the report of the UN Special Rapporteur on trafficking in persons, especially women and children. In Europe, hundreds of unaccompanied children are outside a system of protection and exposed daily to trafficking and abuse. We call on European governments to protect the most vulnerable. #nochildalone
column46: Joint statement
column48:
On 2 July, the UN Human Rights Council discussed the recent report of the Special Rapporteur on trafficking in persons, especially women and children. The report stresses the undeniable link between migration and human trafficking and stresses that “trafficked persons’ rights can be fully protected only if migrants’ rights are protected”. 

The Child10 2020 Awardees who have partnered up with Child10 this year to address trafficking of children along the migration routes towards Europe, have written a joint statement in support of the findings and recommendations to states set out in this report. Trafficking and exploitation of children along the migration routes towards Europe is happening every day. We need our governments to act now!

You can read the statement here:
https://child10.org/2020/07/14/joint-statement-comment-to-the-report-of-the-un-special-rapporteur-on-trafficking-in-persons-especially-women-and-children-2/

column43: On #WorldHumanitarianDay today, we would like to pay tribute to all those who dedicate themselves to helping others, sometimes risking their lives. At Terre des hommes, 2500 people around the world are committed to helping more than four million children and members of their communities every year. Whether a social worker, a nurse, a driver, or a psychologist, whether he or she works in logistics or human resources, each staff member is a link in this big solidarity chain. Thank you for being our #RealLifeHeroes 🧡

column48:
Check it out #PXU Family: Frito-Lay and Feed the Children are supplementing a quarter-million meals for students this Fall, and #PXU is one of the many districts receiving support. How awesome is that!

To provide some much-needed relief during the #COVID19 pandemic, Frito-Lay has partnered with Feed the Children, a leading nonprofit focused on alleviating childhood hunger, to launch the "Building the Future Together" initiative to support thousands of students across the United States. The program will provide shelf-stable food to supplement more than a quarter-million meals and distribute 500,000 pantry staples, school supplies, snacks, books, hand sanitizer, and personal care items to schools.

column47: United Nations OCHA occupied Palestinian territory
column48:
More than 35,000 Palestinians were injured between 30 March 2018 and 31 October 2019 during demonstrations along the Israel’s perimeter fence enclosing Gaza, alongside 212 who were killed. Mohammed was one of those injured.

In 2019, with funding allocated by the Humanitarian Fund for the occupied Palestinian territory, he became one of 11,340 people who received case management, psycho-social support and other interventions from Terre des hommes.

“The sessions helped me get rid of the fear and embarrassment I felt for having my leg cut off,” he says. “My coach says I’m one of the best players. I’m happy when I play. It doesn’t matter whether I win or lose; the important thing is that I play with my friends... I have become more self-confident.”

Read more: ochaopt.org/content/protecting-vulnerable-children-gaza-0:=:https://www.ochaopt.org/content/protecting-vulnerable-children-gaza-0

column48:
👩🏽‍⚕️ "COVID-19 Digital Health Innovation has brought a discovery to my life and helped me to think outside of the box", says Priya Priyadershi, an Auxiliary Nurse Midwife in Bandhuwa Health Sub-Centre from Namkum Block, India. 

📲 Priya is a champion of our project that improves primary healthcare and #Covid19 diagnosis in rural areas through a mobile application on digital tablets. Within just one month, she was able to screen 2155 patients by using the application. 

🧡 Priya is passionate about strengthening access of the community to the public health system. She was excited to share her achievements and story within this project: 

🗣 "Every morning I travel a long distance from my house to reach the health centre. Working as a healthcare worker in the last 12 years has helped me to understand the culture, perceptions and real needs of the community in Namkum. I am an honest worker and committed to my job, despite the many hurdles I am faced with. One of my biggest challenges has been maintaining hard copies of patient reports, and this challenge was further increased when the COVID-19 pandemic hit. 

This project has given me the opportunity for varied trainings and coaching support, which has been very encouraging and motivating. Being able to register and capture patients details digitally, with such ease, uniformity and efficiency has been a great support and addressed one of my great challenges of hardcopy data management. The innovative applications are helping me to reach more patients then I did previously, and I am able to revisit patient records, which earlier was not possible. Within one month I was able to screen 2155 patients while using the application. I am very proud of this achievement."

ℹ Our project titled "Digital Health Innovation for COVID-19 response in India" is implemented with the generous funding from TaiwanICDF財團法人國際合作發展基金會. The project is being piloted in three selected blocks of Ranchi district in collaboration with our partner Doctors For You  (DFY) and with support from the National Health Mission, Government of Jharkhand. 

💡 Learn more about Terre des hommes IeDA project - a digital solution to save children's lives: https://www.tdh.ch/en/ieda

column48:
We took part in the online event "Experiences, interventions, and reflections for protecting children during a pandemic" with Save the children, University of Strathclyde OECD #CovidLog4P Terre des hommes End Violence Partnership.

"For children and young people like myself, giving a voice to the voiceless becomes a responsibility. That’s why it’s important to put children in the forefront of advocacy and help develop their capacities," said Prathit, a child rights activist and youth advisor for #CovidUnder19.

"#CovidUnder19 data showed that children felt that their rights were not being upheld or respected in governments' responses to the pandemic. Many children felt forgotten, not listened to and reported that they did not receive adequate information," said Kristen Hope from Terre des hommes.

"Findings of the Covid 4P Log app remind us that structural inequalities are hampering our efforts to end violence against children. While this is not new to us, we know that it is worsening with Covid-19," said Jennifer Davidson from University of Strathclyde.

column43: 💧🤲🏽 Tdh and partners are developing Gravit’eau, a mobile handwashing station which uses an automatic water recycling system to deal with water shortages in crisis situations. Waste water is collected in a tank and then automatically filtered by a membrane. The system works by gravity. The technology enables water to be recycled without the use of electricity, without any complex maintenance and without a continuous supply of chemical products. The filtration membrane is so fine that it does not let bacteria or viruses pass through. Water for washing hands flows by means of a foot pump. “Washing hands reduces 50% of cases of diarrhoea and pneumonia among young children and restricts to a great extent the spread of infectious diseases and epidemics such as cholera and Ebola. Gravit’eau was developed to be a simple to use solution”, explains Bruno Pascual, our expert in water, sanitation and hygiene in emergency situations. #GlobalHandwashingDay 🔗 www.tdh.ch/en/projects/graviteau-washing-your-hands-recycled-water:=:https://www.tdh.ch/en/projects/graviteau-washing-your-hands-recycled-water

column43: Thank you for bringing HOPE to thousands of vulnerable children!! We asked you to help support our World of Children Heroes on the front lines of the COVID-19 pandemic, and you responded!! With our Emergency COVID-19 Challenge Grant Fund, we raised $220,000! These urgently needed funds will support for the most vulnerable children, who have been severely impacted by the unforeseen and unintended consequences of this pandemic. Because of your generosity, we will be able to support over 30 of our World of Children Heroes with emergency food, water, sanitation, hygiene supplies, PPE, safety, and essential medical care , to help save and empower thousands of children they serve across the globe! Never underestimate the impact you can make on a child’s life. Today, more than ever, we are grateful for your support!🙏🏼

column43: With today's #Mondaymemories, we are closing our 60-year-anniversary🥲 We will end it as we started it, with a portrait of Edmond Kaiser who founded Terre des hommes in 1⃣9⃣6⃣0⃣. Kaiser's vision was to help children in need through pure action. It was never a question of good charity or a good conscience, but a right of children that had to be restored. This objective is outlined in our charter: "As long as one child remains hungry, sick, abandoned, in misery or in pain, whoever and wherever s/he may be, the movement Terre des hommes, created for this reason, will pledge itself to the child’s immediate and complete rescue." 🔗 Get to know more about our story by visiting https://60.tdh.ch:=:https://60.tdh.ch/en/

column43: 🧡 Our Friday smile comes from Mali today. "The child was not in the right position. It made my delivery difficult, but the midwife used the techniques she had learned to help me give birth and to reanimate my child who wasn't breathing at birth," says Djeneba, the girl's mother. In remote areas of Mali, the lack of qualified personnel makes it difficult to attend births in good conditions. Maternal and newborn mortality therefore remain high. Thanks to an innovative approach, Terre des hommes teaches health personnel how to save lives in case of complications at birth. 🔗 Read the article here: www.tdh.ch/en/news/woman-must-not-lose-her-life-giving-life:=:https://www.tdh.ch/en/news/woman-must-not-lose-her-life-giving-life

column43: [1/6] More than 900,000 Rohingya refugees live in Cox’s Bazar, Bangladesh, making it the largest refugee camp in the world. Most of them were forced to flee Myanmar due to sectarian violence in August 2017. Over half of the refugees are children. During this week, you will learn more about Tdh’s work to provide services in primary healthcare, child protection and water & hygiene to help the most vulnerable children and families. Covid-19 has added a layer of complexity for both refugee families and organisations like Terre des hommes that support them. Our teams are constantly innovating to adapt activities and continue to offer support while minimising the health risks to the children and staff.
column47: Photos from Terre des hommes's post
column50: U.S. Department of State:  Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [2/6] In Cox’s Bazar, Tdh runs a primary healthcare centre where refugee families have access to services such as newborn care, treatment for childhood illnesses, and nutrition services. In 2020, 64,000 consultations were delivered. A second primary healthcare centre will be constructed with the support of U.S. Department of State: Bureau of Population, Refugees, and Migration We also train community volunteers in the camps on screening children and mothers and detecting malnutrition symptoms. They refer the severe acute malnutrition cases to Tdh treatment centres where they receive appropriate medical attention and counselling sessions.
column47: Photos from Terre des hommes's post

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [3/6] In our child friendly spaces, we offer psychosocial support activities such as structured play, art and games that contribute to develop children’s emotional, motor skills and creativity. This also improves the child’s resilience and wellbeing. We target children experiencing or at risk of abuse, neglect, exploitation or violence. Tdh also trains staff, volunteers, community members and adolescents on child protection practices in order to increase their knowledge and capacity to protect children and youth.
column47: Photos from Terre des hommes's post

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [4/6] In several areas of the refugee camp in Cox’s Bazar, lack of access to proper sanitation facilities and waste disposal services is a major challenge. The density of the population results in the latrines quickly filling up, and inadequate desludging services can lead to pits overflowing and contaminating surrounding water sources. Tdh is operating a fecal sludge management center (sewage management) to tackle this problem as well as maintaining and rehabilitating latrines. Our teams also raise awareness among the refugee community on handwashing and other hygiene and menstrual hygiene practices. In December 2020 alone, almost 3000 people benefitted from these services.

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [5/6] While the humanitarian aid initially focused on the emergency response for life-saving activities in the camps, we are moving towards more sustainable approaches which mitigate the impact of the refugee influx on the Bangladeshi communities. In Teknaf, around 130,000 refugees live within the host community. The pressure on land, prices and work opportunities can generate inter-group tensions. Tdh initiated a conflict resolution project which will train and accompany representatives from both communities to solve their differences peacefully and set the tone for respectful settlement of issues.

column48:
The Oklahoma Trucking Association just presented the annual fleet safety awards virtually through a pre-recorded Zoom meeting.

One of our drivers, Robert Rossi, was named 1 of 12 Oklahoma Professional Drivers.  In addition, Robert earned the title of Oklahoma Driver of the Year!  This is the first time one of our OTR Safety Professionals has earned this prestigious award.

FTCT won 2nd place in our division for safety and, for the third consecutive year and 5th time in the past 7 years, we were awarded the Oklahoma Grand Trophy for Safety!

We are so excited and thank each member of the FTCT team for their hard work and dedication to safety.  Congratulations, FTCT team!!

Oklahoma Trucking Association

column43: [1/5] “I can be your friend too!” – was the motto of a school event in Romania, dedicated to the social and educational inclusion of Roma children. This week, we will share with you how, during the past two years, we helped Roma migrant children to have access to non-discriminatory education in Romania, France, and Spain. At least 90% of Roma people in Romania live in poverty. To improve their situation, many families often choose to go abroad for some time. France and Spain are among their main destination countries. Ethnic discrimination is one of the children’s many problems, as are poverty or lack of housing, food, clothes, transportation, access to Internet and to public services. More than 50% of the Roma migrant children are not enrolled in school. Children face adaptation and integration difficulties both in the new country and when they return to Romania. Through our project, teachers, students, parents and child protection professionals from Romania, France and Spain have united their voices into one, saying “MISTO AVILEAN!” (“Welcome!”, in Romani language) to Roma children. Stay tuned to learn more!
column47: Photos from Terre des hommes's post

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [2/5] School must be an inclusive, friendly, and welcoming place for all children, everywhere! But this is not always the reality for Roma migrant children. The bureaucratic procedures and teachers’ limited experience of working with Roma families on the move influence the low school enrolment of Roma children. In our international project “MISTO AVILEAN!”, we trained 450 teachers in Romania, France, and Spain to provide culturally sensitive and adapted content and to use interactive inclusive methods. Teachers learned about Roma identity, their culture and social organisation, anti-Roma prejudice, the school-family rupture, and national and EU anti-discrimination legislation. Together with our partners, we have also created an international online platform, where more than 300 teachers from 40 schools in the three countries can communicate and collaborate, exchange experience and good practices. We discuss with decision-makers at national and European level to adopt policies and procedures that remove barriers and facilitate Roma children’s access to non-disruptive compulsory education.
column47: Photos from Terre des hommes's post

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [3/5] Let’s say welcome to school to Roma children! Last year, we organised several school events in Romania to promote the inclusion of Roma children. More than 1300 children and adults of all ethnicities came together to celebrate diversity and prove that school is a friendly place. The events included drawing, photo and costume exhibitions, poetry, music and dance shows, traditional games, theatre plays, as well as online guided meetings. Children also came up with messages of inclusion and expressed them in various creative forms. «Without education, dreams remain only dreams! Make your dreams come 1!» is the message around which we build all our activities,” said Loredana Matei, a teacher in the Sălaj County, Romania.
column47: Photos from Terre des hommes's post

column18: Terre des hommes is the leading Swiss child relief agency, improving the lives of millions of the world's most vulnerable children. Visit www.tdh.ch or watch vimeo.com/253387418
column43: [4/5] Working with parents is essential for improving the school attendance of Roma children. One of the main focuses of our “MISTO AVILEAN” project was to build the child-parent-school relationship. We encouraged and helped teachers in Romania, France, and Spain to understand Roma culture and connect with Roma parents, so that they all team up for the best interest of the child. “If you invite parents and children to your office, you have won their trust. It means you have treated them with respect. They are your equal. They will return this respect”, said a school director in Romania, who believes it is important to establish a relationship of trust and open communication. “Once Roma families decide to migrate, we need to keep in touch with parents and other schools, so that we are aware of the situation and development of the child while abroad. But most often, we know nothing of the sort,” said another teacher. Through our project, we aimed to address this challenge and create ways of collaboration among schools in different countries.

column43: Support SOS Children's Villages in India as it responds to this crisis. Please help by donating now: https://bit.ly/39vUKiU
column48:
Cyclone Nivar made landfall on 26th morning at 2.30 am (wind speed up to 130 km/hour) at Kottapuram near Pondicherry.
SOS Children's Villages of India is trying to reach out to the families who have lost their homes due to this cyclone. They do not have the necessary food provision to survive on, and many people have lost their clothes. Daily wagers and fishermen are really suffering and are not able to go to work.
SOS Children’s Villages of India is trying to reach and support 146 beneficiary families with necessary food items, bedsheets, tarpaulin and other necessities to protect the vulnerable children and their families.
We are in urgent need of funds to support these families.
Please help us by donating now: https://bit.ly/39vUKiU 

#SOSIndia #NoChildAlone #ThickerThanBlood #CycloneNivar #NivarCyclone #Nivar #CycloneAlert #CycloneRelief #SaveFamilies #Cyclone

column43: 2021 marks 10 years of war in Syria. The conflict that began in 2011 has since become the "worst man-made disaster since the Second World War" according to the UN. Just after war broke out, we mobilised to bring humanitarian aid to families who had just arrived in Egypt, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, Greece and the Balkans, in camps or host communities, or on migration routes. This generally involves basic necessities and emergency psychological support. Over time and as the conflict evolves, the needs of children and families change and new issues emerge. In collaboration with local partners, our teams work with refugee children and families and host communities to uphold children’s rights. Together, we fight against the negative impacts of this humanitarian crisis on them, like poverty, violence, child exploitation, early marriage, or school drop-out. Tdh is also building the capacities of local organisations, community members and the authorities for sustainable improvement. #Syria10 🙏🏼 Please donate to support children and their families affected by the war in Syria www.tdh.ch/donate/syria:=:https://www.tdh.ch/en/nous-soutenir/donner/urgence?urgence=19250&montant=50

column43: 2021 marque les dix ans de la guerre en Syrie. Le conflit qui a débuté en 2011 est depuis devenu la «pire catastrophe provoquée par l'homme depuis la Seconde Guerre mondiale», selon l’ONU. Après que la guerre a éclaté, nous nous sommes mobilisé·e·s pour apporter une aide humanitaire aux familles qui venaient d’arriver en Egypte, en Jordanie, au Liban, en Irak, en Grèce et dans les Balkans. Nous avons commencé à travailler dans les camps, les communautés d’accueil etsur les routes migratoires en fournissant notamment du matériel de première nécessité, du soutien psychologique d’urgence, et en créant des espaces dédiés aux enfants. Au fil du temps et de l’évolution du conflit, les besoins des enfants et des familles changent et de nouvelles problématiques émergent. En collaboration avec des partenaires locaux, nos équipes travaillent avec les enfants, les familles réfugié·e·s et les communautés d’accueil pour faire respecter les droits des enfants. Ensemble, nous luttons contre les impacts négatifs de cette crise humanitaire, comme la pauvreté, la violence, l’exploitation des enfants, le mariage précoce, la déscolarisation. Terre des hommes développe également les compétences des organisations locales, des membres des communautés et des autorités pour un impact durable. #Syria10 🙏🏼 Faites un don pour soutenir les enfants et leurs familles victimes de la guerre en Syrie. www.tdh.ch/donner/syrie:=:https://www.tdh.ch/fr/nous-soutenir/donner/urgence?urgence=737&montant=50

column43: 2021 jährt sich der Krieg in Syrien zum zehnten Mal. Der Konflikt, der 2011 ausbrach, ist laut der UNO zur «schlimmsten von Menschen verursachten Katastrophe seit dem Zweiten Weltkrieg» geworden. Nach dem Kriegsausbruch engagierten wir uns, um Familien humanitäre Hilfe zu leisten, die in Ägypten, Jordanien, Libanon, Griechenland, im Irak und auf dem Balkan neu angekommen waren. Wir begannen, in Flüchtlingslagern, in den Aufnahmegemeinschaften und auf den Migrationsrouten zu arbeiten, wobei wir insbesondere Güter des täglichen Bedarfs und psychologische Soforthilfe bereitstellten und spezielle Räume für Kinder schufen. Im Laufe der Zeit und der Entwicklung des Konflikts verändern sich die Bedürfnisse von Kindern und Familien und es tauchen neue Probleme auf. In Zusammenarbeit mit lokalen Partnern arbeiten unsere Teams mit den Kindern, den Flüchtlingsfamilien und den Aufnahmegemeinschaften, um zu gewährleisten, dass die Kinderrechte eingehalten werden. Zusammen mit ihnen bekämpfen wir die negativen Auswirkungen dieser humanitären Krise: Armut, Gewalt, Ausbeutung von Kindern, Kinderehen, Schulabbruch. Tdh entwickelt zudem die Kompetenzen von lokalen Organisationen, von Angehörigen der Gemeinschaften und Behörden, um eine nachhaltige Wirkung zu erzielen. #Syria10 🙏🏼 Spenden Sie, um Kinder und ihre Familien zu unterstützen, die vom Krieg in Syrien betroffen sind. www.tdh.ch/spenden/syrien:=:https://www.tdh.ch/de/nous-soutenir/donner/urgence?urgence=19251&montant=50

column48:
👼🤱 Συνεχίζεται η πολύ σημαντική πρωτοβουλία την οποία ανέλαβε η ομάδα ψυχολογικής και ψυχοκοινωνικής υποστήριξης της Tdh Hellas για τις μητέρες με μικρά παιδιά στις ανοιχτές δομές φιλοξενίας αιτούντων άσυλο.  Αυτή την εβδομάδα συνολικά 27 μητέρες και φροντιστές παιδιών που διαμένουν στη δομή του Σκαραμαγκά είχαν τη δυνατότητα να παρακολουθήσουν τη συνεδρία ενημέρωσης από την ψυχολόγο μας, Νασρίν Aχμάντι, σχετικά με την εκπαίδευση τουαλέτας για παιδιά 0-6 ετών, αλλά και για ζητήματα που αφορούν στη νυχτερινή ενούρηση και στους τρόπους αντιμετώπισης της και αναζήτησης υποστήριξης,  για παιδιά όλων των ηλικιών.

🆘Η εκπαίδευση τουαλέτας είναι ένα πολύ σημαντικό ορόσημο της παιδικής ηλικίας, που σχετίζεται και επηρεάζει όλη τη μετέπειτα ψυχοκοινωνική εξέλιξη του παιδιού, κυρίως σε ό,τι αφορά στην ανάπτυξη της αυτονομίας και της ελεύθερης βούλησης. 

🌞Στη διάρκεια της συνάντησης και μέσα από διαδραστικές ασκήσεις, οι μητέρες εμπλούτισαν τις γνώσεις τους για τα ορόσημα στην ανάπτυξη του παιδιού, ενημερώθηκαν για πρακτικούς τρόπους με τους οποίους μπορούν να βοηθήσουν οι ίδιες τη διαδικασία στα πλαίσια της διαβίωσής τους μέσα στους καταυλισμούς, να μάθουν να αναγνωρίζουν το σημείο όπου είναι απαραίτητη η συμβολή του ειδικού,  αλλά και να ενισχυθούν στο ρόλο τους ως γονέων και φροντιστών.

🌞Η εκπαίδευση τήρησε  όλα τα μέτρα προστασίας από τον Covid19, και στο τέλος, στις συμμετέχουσες προσφέραμε βοηθητικά καθίσματα τουαλέτας για τα παιδιά τους.

🎯Στο Σκαραμαγκά, όπως και σε 8 άλλες περιοχές της ηπειρωτικής Ελλάδας, οι ομάδες μας παρέχουν υπηρεσίες παιδικής προστασίας σε ανοιχτές δομές φιλοξενίας αιτούντων άσυλο και προσφύγων σε οικογένειες με παιδιά, σε συνεργασία με την DRC Greece, τον IOM Greece και με την υποστήριξη του Ταμείου για το Άσυλο, τη Μετανάστευση και την Ένταξη #AMIF της Ευρωπαϊκής Ένωσης #DGHOME #EUHomeAffairs  🇪🇺

Θα θέλαμε να ευχαριστήσουμε την οργάνωση Dråpen i Havet (Drop in the Ocean) για τη φιλοξενία και τη συνεργασία τους στην ενημέρωση και την εγγραφή των γονέων στην ομάδα μας.

"What worries young Syrians like me the most are the struggles with education and the lack of opportunities. I don't know what my future will be like, but I will continue to do my best!” - Rama is a young 24-year-old Syrian refugee who volunteered for Terre des hommes' projects in Egypt. #Syria10 🙏🏼 Please donate to support children and their families affected by the war in Syria www.tdh.ch/donate/syria:=:https://www.tdh.ch/en/nous-soutenir/donner/urgence?urgence=19250&montant=50

Je ne sais pas de quoi mon futur sera fait, mais je vais continuer à faire de mon mieux !» Rama est une jeune réfugiée syrienne de 24 ans qui s’engage bénévolement dans les projets de Terre des hommes en Egypte. #Syria10 🙏🏼 Faites un don pour soutenir les enfants et leurs familles victimes de la guerre en Syrie. www.tdh.ch/donner/syrie:=:https://www.tdh.ch/fr/nous-soutenir/donner/urgence?urgence=737&montant=50

Ich weiss nicht, wie meine Zukunft aussehen wird, aber ich werde weiterhin mein Bestes geben!» Rama ist eine 24-jährige Syrerin, die sich als Flüchtling in Ägypten freiwillig für die Projekte von Terre des hommes engagiert. #Syria10 🙏🏼 Spenden Sie, um Kinder und ihre Familien zu unterstützen, die vom Krieg in Syrien betroffen sind. www.tdh.ch/spenden/syrien:=:https://www.tdh.ch/de/nous-soutenir/donner/urgence?urgence=19251&montant=50
