This visit embodies not only the significance of teaching the children about Greek culture, but also highlights the important work that our volunteers do with the training and guidance of The HOME Project Child Protection Unit to help the kids develop and learn. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Within the context of COVID-19 prevention measures and delays in the asylum and family reunification procedures, our Legal Coordinator frequently conducts group informative legal workshops, in addition to one to one sessions for all children under our care to inform them on their rights and obligations. Access to legal aid and representation constitutes an integral and vital part of our child protection model. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: After many months of remaining indoors, children under our care have begun to spend more time together outside. The HOME Project child protection unit has developed our summer activities plan providing to the children with many fun playing games and experiencing the city and nature while still taking appropriate safety precautions. #nochildalone

column18: Learn more about SOS Children's Villages International here: www.sos-childrensvillages.org
column46: Child Helpline International Every child should have free and unrestricted access to child helpline services, including particularly vulnerable children
column48:
Child helplines should be accessible to all children and young people. Governments and the ICT sector have a role to play to ensure that they are. The Covid-19 pandemic has particularly highlighted the need for child friendly, remotely accessible services.
Read our report: https://bit.ly/2R0JHHY:=:https://issuu.com/chi-childhelplineinternational/docs/voices_covid-19
Hear our Call for Action: https://bit.ly/3f1M3za:=:https://www.childhelplineinternational.org/our-work/news/covid-call-for-action/
And share if you agree!

#EveryChildHasAVoice #Covid-19 #CallForAction #Voices

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: Today is Giving Tuesday, and we would greatly appreciate your support. Despite incredible obstacles this year, The NYSPCC never stopped delivering on its mission to help children heal from the affects of abuse and neglect. Our programs transitioned to telemedicine so that children could still benefit from our services. With many families facing so many hardships due to COVID-19, our services were, and still are, needed more then ever. We hope you will consider a gift today - any amount would make an incredible difference in the life of a child. Go to nyspcc.org/donation to donate today
column46: Together we give. December 1, 2020

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Girls under our care are participating in a storytelling project delivered by a member of our volunteer team. The aim of the workshop is to create a story out of an experience in their country of their origin. It can be a myth, a recipe, a trivial personal thing, or something one has heard, it can be an old legend, a saying, or whatever one wants. Storytelling creates and develops relations based on mutual trust among those living together. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Today on World Environment Day, we recognize and appreciate the importance of a sustainable, clean and healthy environment. At The HOME Project, we aim to teach the children social and environmental values necessary for shaping a better future for society as a whole. Agricultural educational activities build a strong sense of community and empower our efforts in creating healing environments for the children under our care. #nochildalone #worldenvironmentday #greening #gogreen

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Per Heggenes, CEO of our invaluable partner IKEA Foundation, and chairman of our Advisory Board visited us in Athens. Thanks to IKEA Foundation's extraordinary support this far The HOME Project has provided a safe home to more than 600 lone refugee children. Per’s genuine care and steadfast leadership inspires us to continue our work into the future. Children and staff caught up with Per and his wife Karen during a wonderful picnic at the National Garden. Per and Karen, our Home is your Home! #nochildalone
column47: Photos from The HOME Project's post

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Children under The HOME Project care decided to decorate a shelter’s wall by cultivating fresh herbs and plants. Through our work, we remain dedicated to motivating children and ensuring a healthy and healing environment for all of them. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: A girl from our shelter for unaccompanied minor girls and minor mothers with their babies has been accepted to be relocated to France, who was staying with us for a long time. The HOME Project staff and girls under our care surprised her with a farewell walk. We continue our efforts in providing the most healing and nurturing conditions for these children and we are looking forward to seeing them opening their wings and creating their own future. #nochildalone

column43: Minor girls under our care have found dance as a source of relaxation and a way of expressing their feelings. Through dance classes, they also bond as a community, reduce their stress and maintain a healthy body and mind. #nochildalone #dance

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Taking all the appropriate safety precautions, children under our care had a nice evening out playing soccer at the park. Sports activities give the chance to children to learn the value of team spirit, friendship, and respect both in sports and life. #nochildalone

column43: One of The HOME Project child protection model fundamental pillars is our pedagogical support, emphasizing the participation of activities within the shelter such as cooking a meal together. We are amazed by our children’s creativity who decided to prepare their handmade fresh pasta. #nochildalone

Children enjoyed sports and being welcomed in such a strong community. These experiences promote and teach our children the value of team spirit, friendship and respect both in sports and in life. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Girls under our care, from our shelter for unaccompanied minor girls and minor mothers with their babies, spent an afternoon at The Benaki Museum and took the chance to see important artifacts that unfold Greek history. Part of The HOME Project mission is to create a safe environment for the children where they can feel welcomed in our country and get familiar with its culture. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: We are thrilled to welcome back from his first year at Sciences Po our Youth Ambassador Amadou Diallo. He is now working as an intern at our offices supporting daily operations and our youth engagement program while visiting our shelters and sharing his experience with children and youth under our care. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.
column43: Despite the end of the school year, girls under our care continue their education by having lessons at the back yard of The HOME Project shelter, which is operated in collaboration with Movement On The Ground. After a difficult year with online lessons attendance, offering educational opportunities in a safe environment is vital not only for children’s skills empowerment but also for their social integration. We wish at the next academic year all students return in person to schools with safety. #nochildalone

column18: The HOME Project is a non-profit organization set up to address the needs of unaccompanied refugee children.

column43: Happy #FlashbackFriday everyone! This photo from 1896 is of a child who came into the care of The NYSPCC due to homelessness and abuse. The child was forced to sweep the streets and people’s homes in order to pay his pimp. The NYSPCC was able to separate the child from his abuser and find him a loving home only six months later. column46: In honor of Black History Month, the NYSPCC celebrates the heroic efforts of Daniel Blue. Blue was a late nineteenth century free Black man who upon witnessing the abuse of a young Black girl (Edith, 12) by her slaveholder, stepped in and rescued her. Blue went to court and freed Edith from the clutches of her slaveholder and petitioned the court to become her legal guardian. His request was granted and Edith went on to live a happy and long life with Blue and his family, free from her abuser.

To read more on her incredible work, please go to https://socialwelfare.library.vcu.edu/people/perry-fredericka-douglass-sprague/ . . . . . . . . . #nyspcc #blackhistorymonth
column46: In honor of Black History Month The NYSPCC celebrates the incredible work of Fredericka Douglas Sprague Perry. Granddaughter of abolitionist Frederick Douglas, Perry spent most of her life advocating for healthcare to African American children in Kansas City. Concerned with the lack of foster care homes for Black children, Perry founded the Colored Big Sister Home for Girls whose mission was to find homes for girls from broken families. The Colored Big Sister Home opened in 1934 and Perry remained active there until her death in 1943....

column46: The NYSPCC stands with gymnasts in their ongoing search for justice concerning the horrific abuse they endured at the hands of John Geddert. While Geddert's suicide will make this journey that much more difficult and painful for the women who suffered his abuse, The NYSPCC is confident that they will nevertheless prevail in their struggle to make their voices heard so we, as a society, can prevent such crimes from ever occurring again.

column43: In 1874, Henry Burgh, Elbridge T. Gerry, John D. Wright, and Etta Wheeler, saved Mary Ellen from a life of abuse. Her case sparked the formation of The NYSPCC. To learn about this monumental case, come back on our Founder’s Day, April 27. To learn more about The NYSPCC Archive, contact our Archivist and visit our website. . . . . #nyspcc #endchildabuse #childabuseprevention #archives #history #letkidsbekids

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: Etta Wheeler advocated for the protection of Mary Ellen Wilson, whose infamous abuse story led to the creation of The NYSPCC. To honor her heroic actions which sparked the child protection movement, on October 13-16th, 1913, Wheeler was invited to attend the 37th annual meeting of the American Humane Association's national conference in Rochester, New York. Wheeler was the guest speaker and presented her keynote address, The Story of Mary Ellen, which was later published by the American Humane Association, called The Story of Mary Ellen: Which started the Child Saving Crusade. The NYSPCC constructed a memorial that was placed on Fifth Avenue, between 104th Street to 105th Street. . . . . #nyspcc #endchildabuse #childabuseprevention #archives #history #letkidsbekids

column46: NY SPCC In 2019 The NYSPCC conducted 219 Safe Touches workshops at 24 schools in New York City reaching ,756, children. column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: The case of Mary Ellen was the first documented instance of child abuse in the U.S. This historic case led to the creation of The NYSPCC and the child protection movement. In 1874, eight-year-old Mary Ellen was being severely abused and neglected by her foster parents. A missionary worker, Etta Wheeler, brought the case to the local police, who refused to intervene. Wheeler persisted, and brought the case to Henry Burgh and Elbridge T. Gerry of The ASPCA. Although it sounds unbelievable today, they had to use animal cruelty laws to rescue Mary Ellen from her abusers. This incredible case clearly showed the great need for child protection laws and advocate agencies, and so on April 27, 1874 The NYSPCC was incorporated. To find out more about Mary Ellen’s story and to stay up to date with things happening at The Society, follow us on social media or reach out to our Archivist to ask questions! . #nyspcc #children #endchildabuse #endchildabusenow #saveachild #endabuse #WeCanPrevent #LetKidsBeKids #endit #archive #photography #history #vintage #film #photo #photoarchive #archives #archivestreasures #archival #sepia #blackandwhite #archivesofinstagram #timewarp #specialcollections #throwbacks #digitization #genealogy #Americanhistory #specialcollections #CAPMonth

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: Gymnastic coaches and staff spend many hours with their athletes and sometimes they know them better than their parents do. They can model behavior that promotes healthy body boundaries and can implement best practice policies and procedures to ensure athletes are adequately safeguarded from abuse. If you are a current club owner or coach, register for this FREE training through the Athletes are Children First Initiative, a partnership between The NYSPCC and The Athlete Assistance Fund. Head to our website using the link in our bio.
column46: FLOOR CHILD SEXUAL ABUSE PREVENTION FOR GYMNASTICS COACHES June 10, 2021, 1-2:30 pm ET Virtual Training, Zoom Free to attend Register at nyspcc.org NY|SPCC Children FIRST HF ASSISTANCE STANCE

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: The NYSPCC Training Institute is conducting two workshops at the upcoming National Gymnastics Association Education and Wellness Summit. These workshops will give gymnastics coaches and parents the tools to effectively and confidently keep athletes and gyms safe from sexual abuse. Participants will learn about the dynamics of child sexual abuse, appropriate athlete-coach boundaries, how to recognize signs and report abuse, and how to create a safe gym culture. The Athletes are Children First Initiative was developed in partnership with the Athlete Assistance Fund. For learn more about our initiative, go to https://athleteassistancefund.org/training/ or use the link in our bio.
column46: UPCOMING UPCOMINGCO CONFERENCE Jessica Trudeau Director of the Training Institute The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children TO SPEAK AT THE National Gymnastics Association Education and Wellness Summit Thursday, June 10 -Friday, June 11 To learn more and register, visit nationalgym.org NY|SPCC HF 1 SISTANCE ATHLETE FUND Children FIRST

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: In 1911, the siblings in this photo were being abused by their parents and forced into hard labor. Their parents were brought to the Children Courts based on a complaint given to The NYSPCC by a caring and concerned neighbor. The parents were found guilty on charges of abuse, maltreatment, and neglect. The photo on the left was the state of the children when they were rescued by The NYSPCC. The photo on the right was taken 6 months after being in the care of The NYSPCC, well cared for and thriving! The children were later adopted by a loving family. For more photos like this and to stay up to date with things happening at The Society, follow us on social media or reach out to our Archivist to ask questions! . . . #nyspcc #children #endchildabuse #endchildabusenow #saveachild #endabuse #WeCanPrevent #LetKidsBeKids #endit #archive #photography #history #vintage #film #photo #photoarchive #archives #archivestreasures #archival #sepia #blackandwhite #archivesofinstagram #timewarp #specialcollections #throwbacks #digitization #genealogy #Americanhistory #specialcollections

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: Professionals who deal with child maltreatment are under a tremendous amount of stress trying to provide services to their clients and patients during the COVID-19 pandemic. This session, facilitated by Dr. Mary Pulido, will cover recognizing stress symptoms and responses, and provide coping strategies and tools to help child protection professionals manage their secondary traumatic stress and plan for self-care. To learn more and register, visit the link in our bio.
column46: UPCOMING WEBINAR part of APSAC & The New York Foundling Comprehensive Online Course for Child Welfare and Child Maltreatment Professionals Take a Deep Breath: Wellness for Child Protection Professionals During COVID-19 Dr. Mary Pulido Executive Director The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children Thursday, June 10 at 12:30pm ET To learn more and register, visit apsac.org/8week 8week Ip CTHOUNDING Knowledge NY|SPCC

Upon completion, participants will receive certification recognized by New York State. To register, visit the “upcoming trainings” link in our bio.

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: Child sexual abuse that occurs within sports not only has negative impacts on gymnast’s physical, mental, and emotional well-being, but it has also a negative impact on the sport, such as damage to reputation, loss of trust, loss of players and fans, and loss of sponsorship. For coaches, gym owners and gym staff interested in taking this FREE training through our partnership with the Athlete Assistance Fund, visit the “upcoming trainings” link in our bio.

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: Happy #FlashbackFriday everyone! In this charming 1924 photo, we see one of The NYSPCC teachers and her class of children after enjoying story-time. The NYSPCC not only rescued, but also housed children and kept them healthy, educated, and happy while awaiting to be reunited with their family or entered into adoption or foster care. For more photos like this and to stay up to date with things happening at The Society, follow us on social media or reach out to our Archivist to ask questions! . . . . #nyspcc #children #endchildabuse #endchildabusenow #saveachild #endabuse #WeCanPrevent #LetKidsBeKids #endit #archive #photography #history #vintage #film #photo #photoarchive #archives #archivestreasures #archival #sepia #blackandwhite #archivesofinstagram #timewarp #specialcollections #throwbacks #digitization #genealogy #Americanhistory #specialcollections

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: In 1891, the two brothers pictured here were found begging on the streets of New York City. Their parents had been abusive and when they fell into financial hardship, they abandoned the children. The photo on the left shows the state of the boys when they were found by The NYSPCC. The photo on the right was taken one year later, during which time the brothers were in the care of The NYSPCC, preparing to be adopted by a loving family. For more photos like this and to stay up to date with things happening at The Society, follow us on social media or reach out to our Archivist to ask questions! . . . #nyspcc #children #endchildabuse #endchildabusenow #saveachild #endabuse #WeCanPrevent #LetKidsBeKids #endit #archive #photography #history #vintage #film #photo #photoarchive #archives #archivestreasures #archival #sepia #blackandwhite #archivesofinstagram #timewarp #specialcollections #throwbacks #digitization #genealogy #Americanhistory #specialcollections

column12: The New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children (NYSPCC)
column43: The NYSPCC Executive Director, Dr. Mary Pulido was featured in a podcast hosted by TeachThought, to discuss the role of educators in school discipline and helping to prevent child abuse and neglect. TeachThought is a website for teachers, with the goal of helping to grow teachers and give them tools and resources to succeed. This interview serves as an excellent opportunity for The NYSPCC to spread its messaging to an audience comprised almost entirely of teachers, who are commonly the number one reporters of suspected child abuse and neglect. To listen to the podcast, head to the link in our bio.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: We dream of a world where no child goes to bed hungry, that's why we have teams in 10 countries around the world. Learn more about the work our International teams are doing here: https://www.feedthechildren.org/our-work/around-the-world/ or by visiting their Facebook pages! Feed the Children- Latin America & the Caribbean Feed the Children-Asia Feed the Children- Africa #DefeatHungerMonth #CancelHunger
column48: Feed the Children envisions a world where no child goes to bed hungry irrespective of who they are or where they are from because a hungry child can neither grow well nor be themselves. Supporting vulnerable families with food items allows kids to be themselves, continue being kids even during this pandemic period where food can be very scarce. #DefeatHungerMonth #ZeroHunger #CancelHunger

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Our team in Africa always works hard to help their communities grow, nourish and sustain. Working together is how we will beat hunger! #zerohunger #WorldFoodDay
column48:
To provide hope and resources to those without life’s essentials in the communities we serve, Feed the Children provides food assistance and other essentials to vulnerable members of these communities. We envision a world where no child goes to bed hungry which is in line with the second SDG of ensuring that we have #zerohunger in the world.

Let us GROW NOURISH SUSTAIN TOGETHER

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: The Feed the Children team in Africa has been working hard during #COVID19 to spread awareness about proper handwashing and sanitation awareness to help stop the spread of coronavirus and other diseases. They work closely with the government to ensure appropriate measures are being taken during the pandemic to keep families and employees safe. #International
column48: There is a need for all to have sustainable sanitation to go hand in hand with clean water and handwashing facilities. Such systems will help protect and maintain their health security and stop the spread of deadly infectious diseases such as COVID-19, cholera, and typhoid.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: COVID-19 has affected education for children around the world. Our team in Africa has been working hard to be able to continue providing students in the communities we serve with educational opportunities, food, access to clean water and education materials like books, pencils, shoes, etc. What an incredible team and amazing work! #Africa #Education
column48:
The wake of the COVID-19 pandemic has seen the interruption of education and many literacy and lifelong learning programs, affecting the lives of 1.6 billion students worldwide. 
Feed the Children has been stepping up collaborations with partners like Victor Munson in Kenya and Uganda to place education at the centre of recovery. By identifying and solving the access to water, many school-going children now have a chance of enjoying clean drinking water and better sanitation, which is critical in their development.
This is a move towards a more inclusive, safe, and sustainable society.

#FeedtheChildren #BrighterFutures

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Our Feed the Children team in Africa works hard to advocate for partnerships to be explored in their countries, to get the world back on track to achieve zero hunger by 2030. #Partnerships #ZeroHunger
column48:
From the recent #GlobalHungerIndex2020 projections by Welthungerhilfe, it is clear that the world is not yet ready to achieve the second 2030 Sustainable Development Goal (SDG) on zero hunger.
Among other constraints, lack of mechanization incentives for the farmers, as well as little or no extension work to make it possible for them to farm, has made it difficult for them to produce the volumes needed to achieve food security.
In all these, Kenya, like many other countries, suffers from undernourishment with many families lacking a meal due to abject poverty. This worsens the situation for vulnerable communities who are already struggling to get a meal on their tables.
At Feed the Children, we always advocate for partnerships to be explored, to return the global space on the right track towards the actualization of the 2030 SDGs.
#SDG2 #ZeroHunger

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: The importance of clean water is undeniable. With #WorldWaterDay next week, it's important we know the effects of dirty water on communities and how it impacts children's nutrition and education. Poor access to clean drinking water contributes to improper hygiene practices, disease spread, and decreased access to education. Due to the impacts of unclean water, many children in communities affected cannot attend classes because of disease or assist their families in gathering and cleaning water.
column48:
With #WorldWaterDay about to be commemorated, what is there to celebrate? Water is under extreme threat from a growing population, increasing demands of agriculture and industry, and the worsening impacts of climate change.
As societies balance the demands on water resources, many people’s interests are not being taken into account.
For us to achieve Sustainable Development Goal 6: water and sanitation for all by 2030, there is a need to understand that the value of water is much more than its price. Water has enormous and complex value for our households, culture, health, education, economics, and the integrity of our natural environment. 
If we overlook any of these values, we risk mismanaging this finite, irreplaceable resource.

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Happy #WorldWaterDay! How do you value water? #FeedtheChildren
column46: FEED CHiLDREN® MARCH 22 1111 WORLD WATER DAY ..therto ...there need understand that the value of water muh more than its price.
column48:
#WorldWaterDay celebrates water and raises awareness of the global water crisis, and a core focus on the observance is to support the achievement of Sustainable Development Goal SDG6: water and sanitation for all by 2030.
With this year's theme being VALUING WATER, the value of water is much more than its price. Water has enormous and complex value for our households, food, culture, health, education, economics, and the integrity of our natural environment. 
If these values are overlooked, there is a risk of mismanaging this finite, irreplaceable resource. #SDG6 will ensure there are water and sanitation for all. Without a comprehensive understanding of water’s 1, multidimensional value, we will be unable to safeguard this critical resource for the benefit of everyone.
Feed the Children in partnership with donors and beneficiary communities has invested in improving access to water through rooftop water harvesting in schools and construction of water pans. The move brings enormous value to the households, livelihoods, culture, and the environment.
How is water important to you?

column48:
Financial empowerment as a means of improving livelihood assures communities that they can be in a position to provide for their children since economic empowerment guarantees the creation of a world where no child goes to bed hungry.

#feedthechildren

column18: We believe in a world where no child goes to bed hungry.
column43: Our team at Feed the Children- Africa works hard to make sure Mothers receive the help they need. Whether it be through education and training about nutrition, or the importance of breastfeeding and monitoring the growth of their children., mothers can attend Care Groups that give them the knowledge and resources to help their communities thrive.
column48:
We are all about sharing! When Lead Mothers share the experience they have in practicing & coaching during Care Group Sessions with the community, we very well know that an entire community will benefit.
#shareyourgood #feedthechildren #Health #Livelihoods
